[[David Hannay]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2014 deaths, Australian movie actors, Australian movie producers, Deaths from cancer, New Zealand movie actors, Television producers

David Hannay (23 June 1939 – 31 March 2014) was an New Zealand-Australian movie producer. He worked with Greater Union and was an independent producer from 1977. Hannay was born in New Zealand.

Hannay died on 31 March 2014 from cancer, aged 74.

[[Wayne Henderson]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2014 deaths, African American musicians, American jazz musicians, American record producers, American trombonists, Musicians from Houston, Texas

Wayne Henderson (September 24, 1939 – April 5, 2014) was an American soul jazz and hard bop trombonist and record producer. In 1961, he co-founded the soul jazz/hard bop group The Jazz Crusaders.

Henderson died in Los Angeles, California at the age of 74.

[[Joe Turkel]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, Living people, Actors from New York City, American movie actors, American television actors

Joe Turkel (born July 15, 1927) is an American character actor of movie and television. He is mostly known for his roles in Blade Runner and in The Shining.

Turkel was born in Brooklyn, New York City. 

[[The Shining (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1980 drama movies, 1980s ghost movies, 1980 horror movies, American drama movies, American ghost movies, American horror movies, British drama movies, British horror movies, Haunted house movies, Movies about domestic violence, Movies about dysfunctional families, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Stanley Kubrick, Movies set in Colorado, Movies set in hotels, Works about alcoholism

The Shining is a 1980 American-British horror drama movie. It is set during winter in a hotel in rural Colorado. It was directed by Stanley Kubrick. It is based on Stephen King's book of the same name. It stars Jack Nicholson, Shelley Duvall, Danny Lloyd, and Scatman Crothers. It was released on May 23, 1980. Reviews improved greatly over the years.

[[Jonathan Rhys Meyers]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 births, Actors from Dublin, Irish movie actors, Irish television actors, Living people, Models, Irish movie producers, People from Cork (city)

Jonathan Rhys Meyers (born Jonathan Michael Francis O'Keeffe; 27 July 1977) is an Irish actor, movie producer and model. He is best known for his roles in the movies Velvet Goldmine (1998), Bend It Like Beckham (2002), Match Point (2005), Mission: Impossible III (2006), August Rush (2007) and From Paris with Love (2010).

Rhys Meyers was born in Drimnagh, Dublin and raised in Cork, County Cork in a Roman Catholic family.

[[Tenerife airport disaster]]

CATEGORIES: 1977, 1970s in Africa, 20th century in Spain, Aviation disasters in the 1970s, Canary Islands, March events

The Tenerife airport disaster happened on March 27, 1977, when two Boeing 747s collided on the ground of Los Rodeos Airport (now Tenerife North Airport). This crash killed 583 people onboard the two flights.

The crash was caused by many reasons. One reason is that as the KLM captain wanted to takeoff quickly so that he could return to Amsterdam. This made him misunderstand that he was cleared by Air Traffic Controller to takeoff and so he began to take off, eventually crashing into the Pan Am flight. At that time, the Tenerife North Airport did not have ground radar, so the controllers could not know that the KLM flight was taking off.

Another reason was the fog surrounding the airport. The bad weather reduced the visibility, meaning the pilots could not see each other and neither could the controllers see the two planes on the runway. Because of the fog, the pilots only saw each other at the last minute, when they could not have prevented the crash. If there was no fog, the KLM crew would have seen the Pan Am plane on the runway and would not have taken off.

It was the worst crash in the history of aviation.

[[John Hawkes (actor)]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 births, Actors from Minnesota, American movie actors, American television actors, Living people, Musicians from Minnesota

John Hawkes (born John Marvin Perkins; September 11, 1959) is an American actor and musician. His best known movie appearances are the Academy Award nominated role as Teardrop in Winter's Bone and his Golden Globe and Screen Actors Guild Award nominated role as Mark O'Brien in The Sessions. On television, he is known for his role as Sol Star on the HBO television shows Deadwood and as Dustin Powers on Eastbound & Down.

Hawkes was born in Alexandria, Minnesota.

[[Clive Owen]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, BAFTA Award winning actors, English movie actors, English stage actors, English television actors, Entertainers from Coventry, Golden Globe Award winning actors, Living people

Clive Owen (born 3 October 1964) is an English actor. He won a Golden Globe and a BAFTA Award and was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor for his role in the drama movie Closer (2004). He also gained fame for his roles in Close My Eyes (1991), Croupier (1998), Sin City (2005), Derailed (2005) Inside Man (2006), Children of Men (2006), and The International (2009). He is best known on television for his leading role in the ITV program Chancer from 1990 to 1991.

Owen was born in Coventry, Warwickshire. He has been married to Sarah-Jane Fenton since 1995. They have two daughters, Hannah and Eve. He is a supporter of the football club Liverpool.

[[Thomas Haden Church]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, Living people, Actors from California, American movie actors, American television actors, Movie directors from California, Screenwriters from California

Thomas Haden Church (born Thomas Richard McMillen; June 17, 1960) is an American actor, movie director and screenwriter. He first became known when co-starring in the 1990s sitcom Wings. He is best known for his movie appearances including as his Academy Award-nominated role in Sideways (2004) and his role as the Sandman in Spider-Man 3 (2007). He also directed the independent movie Rolling Kansas (2003).

Church was born in Woodland, California. He has two children with actress Mia Zottoli.

[[V. K. Murthy]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2014 deaths, Cinematographers, Disease-related deaths in India, People from Mumbai

V. K. Murthy (ವಿ. ಕೆ. ಮೂರ್ತಿ; 26 November 1923 – 7 April 2014) was an Indian cinematographer. During his career, he won two Filmfare Awards in the best cinematographer category. His best known movies are Pyaasa (1957), Kaagaz Ke Phool (1959) and Sahib Bibi Aur Ghulam (1962). For each of those movies, he won a Filmfare Award. He was born in Mysore, Kingdom of Mysore and lived in Mumbai for most of his life.

Murthy died on 7 April 2014 at his home in Bangalore, India. He was 90 years old.

Kerr began modeling at age 13. She started several organic skincare products.

[[Victoria's Secret]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 establishments in the United States, 1970s establishments in California, American clothing companies, Columbus, Ohio, Companies based in San Francisco

Victoria's Secret is an American company. It is the largest American seller of lingerie. It was founded in 1977 in San Francisco by Roy Raymond. Its headquarters are in Columbus, Ohio. The sales in 2012 were $6.12 billion. The company sells lingerie, women's clothing, and beauty products through catalogs and physical stores.

[[Lingerie]]

CATEGORIES: Underwear

Lingerie is a term for women's underclothes. In advertising, it suggests fashionable and alluring undergarments. Materials include silk, cotton, polyester, satin, nylon and lace.

The 20th century brought big changes in women's underwear. The idea of lingerie as a visually appealing undergarment was developed in the late nineteenth century by Lady Duff-Gordon of 'Lucile'. She was a pioneer in developing lingerie that freed women from more restrictive corsets.

[[Pittsburg State University]]

CATEGORIES: 1903 establishments in the United States, Colleges and universities in Kansas, 20th-century establishments in Kansas

Pittsburg State University is a university in the city of Pittsburg, Kansas. It has around 7,100 students, 5,900 who are undergraduates, and 1,200 who are graduate students. Most of the students live near Pittsburg. There are around the same number of boys as girls. A little more than three fourths of the students are Americans. For every 19 students there is 1 teacher or staff member. It is a member of the Kansas Board of Regents. Pittsburg State has endowments worth around $40,000,000. It also has a newspaper run by students called the Collegio.

Murder-Set-Pieces is a melodramatic horror movie of 2004. The movie has themes of lust, rape and cannibalism.

This movie was given a limited release as an NC-17 (no children 17 or under). It was later released by Lions Gate Home Entertainment with an R rating. The United Kingdom banned the movie.

Anal beads are a sex toy. They are beads on a string. They are put into the anus of a woman or man for sexual arousal. They can be made of many different materials, such as rubber, metal or glass.

[[Tahini]]

[[Rose water]]

Rose water (گلاب; golāb) is a distillate of rose petals originating in Persian cuisine. It is used in Persian, Arabic, and Turkish food.  It is also used as a perfume.

[[Orange flower water]]

CATEGORIES: Middle Eastern foods, Food ingredients, Citrus

Orange flower water is a distillate of bitter orange flowers. It is used in Middle Eastern and North African cooking.

[[Kanafeh]]

CATEGORIES: Desserts, Kurdish food, Middle Eastern foods

Kanafeh is a Middle Eastern cake. It is made from cheese and Kadaif.

[[Tea bag]]

CATEGORIES: Tea

A tea bag is a small bag of tea leaves. It is put in a cup with boiling water to turn it into tea. They can be made of paper or silk. A tea bag is often removed with a teaspoon, some have a string to remove it.

[[Kadaif]]

CATEGORIES: Desserts, Turkish food, Middle Eastern foods

Kadaif noodles are a type of thin Turkish noodles. They are made of flour and water that is poured through a sieve onto a hot metal cooking tray. The cooking time is very short. They are used to make Middle Eastern desserts and other foods around the Mediterranean Sea. It is a popular Turkish dessert like Baklava and Kanafeh.

The dough is made out of flour and water, combined into a thick batter. The batter is poured into a perforated tin having about fifteen "teeth." This tin is held over a metal hot plate. As the batter is poured through the tin onto the hot metal, the kadaife partially cooks and dries into long thin strands resembling noodles or shredded wheat. It is tightly rolled up into oblong rolls and packaged.

[[Anker Buch]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2014 deaths, Danish musical entertainers, Violinists

Anker Buch (25 March 1940 – 1 April 2014) was a Danish violinist. He was born in Vejgaard. He gained international recognition and played more than 7,000 concerts in most parts of the world. 

When Buch was 10 years old, he made his debut as a soloist at the Odd Fellow Palace in Aalborg.

Buch died on 1 April 2014 surrounded by his family members, aged 74.

[[Craig Biggio]]

Craig Biggio (born December 14, 1965) is an American former professional baseball player. He played for the Houston Astros between 1988 and 2007. He never played for another Major League Baseball team.

[[Mary Anderson]]

CATEGORIES: 1918 births, 2014 deaths, Actors from Birmingham, Alabama, American movie actors, American television actors, Deaths from natural causes

Mary Anderson (April 3, 1918 – April 6, 2014) was an American actress. She appeared in 31 movies and 22 television productions between 1939 and 1965. She was known for her role as Maybelle Merriweather in the 1939 movie classic Gone with the Wind. Anderson was born in Birmingham, Alabama.

[[Carlos Oneto]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2014 deaths, Peruvian entertainers, People from Lima

Carlos Alberto Oneto Villavicencio (5 May 1929 – 1 April 2014) was a Peruvian actor, television personality, and comedian. He was known as "Pantuflas" (Slippers). He created the comedy group "EL Tornillo" (The Screw).

Oneto died on 1 April 2014 in his hometown of Lima, Peru, aged 84.

[[Leo Bretholz]]

CATEGORIES: 1921 births, 2014 deaths, Austrian Jews, Austrian writers, Deaths from natural causes, Holocaust survivors, Writers from Vienna

Leo Bretholz (March 6, 1921 – March 8, 2014) was an Austrian writer and holocaust survivor. In 1942, he escaped from a train heading for Auschwitz. He has also written a book on his experiences, titled Leap into Darkness.

Bretholz died in Pikesville, Maryland from natural causes, aged 93.

[[Wrotham]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Kent

Wrotham is a village in Tonbridge and Malling, Kent, England. Nearly 2,000 people live in Wrotham. Its postcode is TN15.

[[Shinsuke Nakamura]]

CATEGORIES: 1980 births, Living people, Japanese professional wrestlers, Mixed martial artists, Japanese martial artists, People from Kyoto Prefecture

Shinsuke Nakamura is an Japanese professional wrestler and mixed martial artist. He currently works for World Wrestling Entertainment (WWE) on the SmackDown brand. He is a former three-time IWGP Heavyweight Champion, three-time IWGP Intercontinental Champion, one-time IWGP Tag Team Champion and was the winner of the 2011 G1 Climax, 2006 G1 Tag League and 2014 New Japan Cup tournaments.

At Invasion Attack 2014 on April 6, Nakamura defeated Hiroshi Tanahashi to win the IWGP Intercontinental Championship for the third time in his career. On June 21 at Dominion 6.21, Nakamura was defeated by Bad Luck Fale for the championship. Nakamura took part in the 2014 G1 Climax. In his block, he was able to win eight times and only suffered two losses. He was able to make it to the finals but lost to his Chaos stablemate Kazuchika Okada on August 10.

[[Paula Yates]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 births, 2000 deaths, British television presenters, Drug-related accidental deaths in the United Kingdom, Welsh writers

Paula Elizabeth Yates (24 April 1959 – 17 September 2000) was a British television presenter and writer. She was best known for her work on two television programmes, The Tube (1982–87) and The Big Breakfast (1992–85).

Yates was born in Colwyn Bay, north Wales. She was married to Irish musician Bob Geldof. Their children were Fifi Trixibelle Geldof (born 1983), Peaches Honeyblossom Geldof (1989–2014) and Little Pixie Geldof (born 1990). She was married to Geldof from 1986 until their divorce in 1996. She began a relationship with Australian musician Michael Hutchence. They had a daughter, Heavenly Hiraani Tiger Lily Hutchence Geldof (born 1996). In 1997, Hutchence killed himself. Soon after, Bob Geldof took full custody of their three children. 

Yates died from an accidental heroin overdose having been found dead on 17 September 2000 at her home in London, England. She was 41. After Yates' death, Geldof got custody of Tiger Lily, and later adopted her. Her daughter, Peaches, died from the same cause in April 2014.

[[Armin Mueller-Stahl]]

Armin Mueller-Stahl (born 17 December 1930) is a German actor, painter, writer and musician. He is best known for his Academy Award nominated role as Peter Helfgott in the Shine (1996).

Mueller-Stahl was born in Tilsit, East Prussia, German Empire (now Sovetsk, Kaliningrad Oblast, Russia). He moved to Berlin during World War II. He has been married to Gabriele Scholz since 1973. The couple live in Los Angeles, California.

[[Olympic Hockey Nagano '98]]

CATEGORIES: 1998 video games, Nintendo 64 games, Sports video games

Olympic Hockey Nagano '98 is an ice hockey game for the Nintendo 64. It was released in 1998. It is a re-release of Wayne Gretzky's 3D Hockey, but not endorsed by Wayne Gretzky.

This game has the license for the 1998 Winter Olympics that were in Nagano, Japan. The game is very similar to Wayne Gretzky's 3D Hockey. The only real differences are the box art, in-game titles, and some minor graphic changes (such as team logos and colors).

[[Jack Ingram]]

CATEGORIES: 1970 births, Living people, American country musicians, American guitarists, Singer-songwriters from Texas

Jack Ingram is an American country music singer. His first single on the U.S. country Top 40 chart was "Wherever You Are". That song hit number 63 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart. Ingram has had six other songs on the country Top 40: "Love You," a cover version of Hinder's "Lips of an Angel," "Measure of a Man," "Maybe She'll Get Lonely," "That's a Man" and "Barefoot and Crazy."

[[Máximo Cajal López]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2014 deaths, Ambassadors to France, NATO, People from Madrid, Spanish politicians

Máximo Cajal López (27 February 1935 – 3 April 2014) was a Spanish diplomat and ambassador. He was the Spanish ambassador to Guatemala in 1980 and was one of the two survivors of the burning of the Spanish Embassy. He was also ambassador to Sweden and France as well as Permanent Representative of Spain to NATO.

Cajal López died on 3 April 2014 in his hometown of Madrid. He was 79 years old.

[[Massimo Tamburini]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2014 deaths, Deaths from lung cancer, Italian artists, People from Emilia-Romagna, Rimini

Massimo Tamburini (28 November 1943 – 5 April 2014) was an Italian motorcycle designer. He is best known for designing for Cagiva, Ducati, and MV Agusta. He was also one of the founders of Bimota. Some of his designs were included in the Guggenheim Museum's The Art of the Motorcycle exhibit of 1998 and 1999. He was born in Rimini, Province of Rimini.

[[Chuck Stone]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2014 deaths, African American writers, American columnists, American journalists, American people of World War II, Cardiovascular disease deaths in North Carolina, Deaths from congestive heart failure, Writers from North Carolina

Charles Sumner "Chuck" Stone, Jr. (July 21, 1924 – April 6, 2014) was an American newspaper editor, columnist, journalist, and writer. He was a Tuskegee Airman during World War II. In the 1940s, he was the first African-American undergraduate in several decades at Wesleyan University. He graduated in the class of 1948 and serving as the commencement speaker. He later received a master's degree in sociology from the University of Chicago. He was the first president of the National Association of Black Journalists (NABJ, 1975–77). He was born in Hartford, Connecticut.

Stone died from congestive heart failure on April 6, 2014 in Chapel Hill, North Carolina. He was 89 years old.

[[Ásgeir Trausti]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, People from Reykjavík

Ásgeir Trausti Einarsson is an Icelandic singer-songwriter. In 2013 he started releasing music as Ásgeir. He lives in Reykjavík, Iceland. His first album, Dýrð í dauðaþögn, was released in 2012. An English version of the album called In the Silence was released in 2014.

[[Frans van der Lugt]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2014 deaths, Dutch Roman Catholics, Jesuits, Murders by firearm, People from The Hague, Roman Catholic priests

Franciscus Joseph Wilhelmus "Frans" van der Lugt (10 April 1938 – 7 April 2014), also known as Peter Frans, was a Dutch psychotherapist and later Jesuit priest. He left the Netherlands for the Middle East in the 1960s where he joined the Jesuits. He studied Arabic for two years in Lebanon. In 1966, he went to Syria, where he lived for nearly fifty years. He gained international fame at the beginning of 2014 when he made a number of YouTube videos asking the international community for help for the citizens of Homs. He was born in The Hague, South Holland.

Frans van der Lugt was shot dead by extremists from Al-Nusra Front on 7 April 2014 in Homs. He was 75 years old.

[[Norrie May-Welby]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 births, Australian activists, Australian LGBT people, Living people, Scottish LGBT people, Transgender and transsexual people

Norrie May-Welby (born 23 May 1961) is a Scottish-Australian transsexual person. Welby was the first person to be considered 'genderless'. 

[[George Shuffler]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, 2014 deaths, American bluegrass musicians, American guitarists, Disease-related deaths in the United States, Musicians from North Carolina

George Shuffler (April 15, 1925 – April 7, 2014) was an American bluegrass guitarist. He was an early expert of the crosspicking style. He began his career in 1946. He played with The Bailey Brothers, The Stanley Brothers and Ralph Stanley's Clinch Mountain Boys. In 2007, he received the North Carolina Heritage Award. In 2011, he was elected to the International Bluegrass Music Hall of Fame. He was born in Valdese, North Carolina.

Shuffler died on April 7, 2014 in Valdese, North Carolina. He was 88 years old.

[[Diplodocid]]

CATEGORIES: Diplodocids

Diplodocids, or members of the family Diplodocidae ("double beams"), are a group of sauropod dinosaurs. The family includes some of the longest creatures ever to walk the earth, including Diplodocus and Supersaurus, which may have reached lengths of up to 34.

With their peg-like teeth they could strip leaves from branches, and leave the grinding to gastroliths. They bacteria in their vast stomachs would break down the cellulose in the leaves, and the product would be absorbed further on in the alimentary canal.

The diplodocids have two sub-families:

Their cousins the brachiosaurs are put into a sister family. The much later titanosaurs were the last group of sauropods on Earth.

[[George Dureau]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2014 deaths, American artists, American photographers, Deaths from Alzheimer's disease, Disease-related deaths in the United States, People from New Orleans, Louisiana

George Dureau (December 28, 1930 – April 7, 2014) was an American visual artist. His career lasted forty years. He was known for charcoal sketches and black and white photography. His work was often called homoerotic. He was born in New Orleans, Louisiana.

Dureau died from Alzheimer's disease on April 7, 2014 at the Walden Healthcare Center in Kenner, Louisiana. He was 84 years old.

[[Roberto Mangabeira Unger]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, Living people, Brazilian politicians, People from Rio de Janeiro, Philosophers

Roberto Mangabeira Unger (born March 24, 1947) is a Brazilian philosopher and politician. Unger studied law at the Federal University of Rio de Janeiro.

Unger was born in Rio de Janeiro. At the time Unger's parents lived in the United States, but Unger's father had suffered a heart attack during a family visit to Brazil. This led to the family staying in Brazil for longer than planned and Unger being born there. When Unger's father recovered, Unger's family went back to New York. Unger grew up on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. 

[[Ned O'Gorman]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2014 deaths, American educators, American poets, Cancer deaths in the United States, Deaths from pancreatic cancer, Writers from Connecticut, Writers from New York City, Writers from Vermont

Edward Charles "Ned" O'Gorman (September 26, 1929 – March 7, 2014) was an American poet and educator. Some of his best known works are The Harvesters' Vase (1968), The Flag the Hawk Flies (1972), The Wilderness and the Laurel Tree: A Guide for Teachers and Parents on the Observation of Children (1972) and Prophetic Voices: Ideas and Words on Revolution (1969). He was born in New York City, New York and was raised in both Southport, Connecticut and Bradford, Vermont.

O'Gorman died from pancreatic cancer on March 7, 2014 at his home in Manhattan. He was 84 years old.

[[Faversham]]

Faversham is a market town in Swale, Kent, England. Nearly 20,000 people live in Faversham. Its postcode is ME13. 

[[Swale]]

Swale is a borough in Kent, South East England. About 140,000 people live in Swale. It was created on 1 April 1974. Its headquarters are in Sittingbourne.

[[Sittingbourne]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Kent

Sittingbourne is an industrial town in Swale, Kent, England. It is located east of Gillingham. About 62,500 people live in Sittingbourne.  Its postcodes are ME9 and ME10.

[[Tonbridge and Malling]]

CATEGORIES: 1974 establishments in England, Kent boroughs

Tonbridge and Malling is a borough in Kent, South East England. About 125,000 people live in the borough. It was created on 1 April 1974. Its headquarters are in West Malling.

[[Grand Duchy of Oldenburg]]

CATEGORIES: Former states in Germany, Former monarchies of Europe, 1814 establishments, 1918 disestablishments in Germany, 1810s establishments in Germany

The Grand Duchy of Oldenburg was a state in Europe. It was in the area that today is Germany. It was created out of the smaller Duchy of Oldenburg. The state was created at the Congress of Vienna in 1814 but ceased to exist after the German Revolution in 1918. The capital of the state was Oldenburg. The Grand ducal family lived at the Schloss Oldenburg in the capital. 

[[Paruyr Hayrikyan]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, Living people, Crime victims, People from Yerevan, Political activists

Paruyr Hayrikyan (Պարույր Հայրիկյան, born July 5, 1949, Yerevan) is an Armenian political activist and a former dissident. Hayrikyan was a internationally-known political prisoner in USSR. In 1987 he founded "National Self-Identification" Union. He is known for his struggle for the independence of Armenia. 

In 2013 he was shot and wounded during his bid for the presidency.

Saraya-Jade Bevis (born 17 August 1992) is an English professional wrestler currently she works for the WWE where she competes under the ring name Paige. She is a two-time WWE Divas Champion and one-time NXT Women's Champion. She is also known under the ring name Britani Knight, which she used while performing on the independent circuit.

[[Denise Nickerson]]

CATEGORIES: Actors from New York City, Singers from New York City, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, Deaths from seizure, Deaths from pneumonia, Accountants, 1957 births, 2019 deaths

[[Head tax (Canada)]]

CATEGORIES: Taxation in Canada, History of Canada

The Chinese head tax was a fixed fee charged to each Chinese person entering Canada. The head tax was first levied after the Canadian parliament passed the Chinese Immigration Act of 1885. It was meant to discourage Chinese people from entering Canada after the completion of the Canadian Pacific Railway. The tax was abolished by the Chinese Immigration Act of 19That act stopped all Chinese immigration excep business people, clergy, educators, student, and other categories.

[[Key Management Service]]

CATEGORIES: Microsoft

KMS (Key Management Service) is one of the methods to activate Microsoft Windows and Microsoft Office. Activation ensures that the software is obtained from and licensed by Microsoft. KMS is used by volume license customers, usually medium to large businesses, schools, and non-profits. Individual computers do not need to contact Microsoft, although the KMS server does. KMS clients must be activated at least once every 180 days. A KMS client will try to activate once every 7 days, and if it fails it will try again every 2 hours. The KMS server can be automatically detected by DNS if the proper DNS record is present, or it can be manually entered using the slmgr command. There must be at least 25 KMS-activated computers (5 for Windows Server) on the network to use KMS. If the KMS activation fails (for example, because the KMS server is not available or there are less than 25 computers on the network), a watermark telling the user to activate Windows will appear in the bottom right corner of the screen.

[[Kyle Chipchura]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 births, American Hockey League players, Anaheim Ducks players, Arizona Coyotes players, Canadian ice hockey centres, Ice hockey people from Alberta, Living people, Montreal Canadiens players, Phoenix Coyotes players

Kyle Douglas Glen Chipchura (born February 19, 1986) is a Canadian professional ice hockey centre. He currently plays for the Arizona Coyotes of the National Hockey League (NHL). He has also played for the Montreal Canadiens and Anaheim Ducks.

[[Suicide risk assessment]]

CATEGORIES: Suicide

A suicide risk assessment (SRA) is used to decide an individual's suicide risk (how likely they are to kill themselves).  This is a very important first step in helping a person who is thinking of killing themselves.  It is best done by a mental health professional, like a counselor.  A good, complete risk assessment can lead to a person getting the treatment and help they need, which can reduce or end suicidal symptoms. 

The first part of an SRA is talking to a doctor - or other trained mental health worker - who asks specific questions about what the person is thinking about, how they feel, and what is going on in their life.  (This is called a clinical interview).

The second part of the SRA uses one or more tests that have been proven to measure suicide risk.  These tests are called "scales."  A scale is a way of measuring something.  Some of these scales have been shown to be very reliable, such as the Suicidal Affect-Behavior-Cognition Scale (SABCS)  and the Columbia-Suicide Severity Rating Scale (C-SSRS).

A suicide risk assessment is not always completely right about a person's suicide risk.  Still, usually it gives a risk score that is helpful for making important decisions about what treatment the person needs. 

The risk of suicide may change over time.  It may become higher or lower for different reasons.  For example, treatment (like counseling or medicines) may work, making the person feel better, or not work.  Or the person's life may change in good or bad ways (for example, they may get or lose a job, go to a new school, get a boyfriend or girlfriend, or break up with one).

Because the risk of suicide can change over time, the suicide risk assessment has to be done more than once while the person is in treatment. If the person is in the hospital for treatment, it has to be done before they are sent home.

A suicide risk assessment can be important in helping save the life of a suicidal person.  But an article in a journal called Suicide & Life-Threatening Behavior, written in 2012, says that SRAs are often not done, and that many mental health care workers have little or no training in how to do a suicide risk assessment.

Hospitals, doctors, and counselors can be sued for negligible death if a suicidal person goes to them for help, but they never did a suicide risk assessment.  Negligible death means that the hospital, doctor, or counselor did not do something they were supposed to do, and because of that, a person died.

[[Silent Hill 2]]

CATEGORIES: 2001 video games, Horror video games, PlayStation 2 games, PlayStation 3 games, Xbox 360 games, Xbox games, Windows games

Silent Hill 2 is a survival horror video game. It was developed by Konami Computer Entertainment Tokyo, as well as Creature Labs for the PC version and Hijinx Studios for the HD version. Silent Hill 2 was published by Konami. The game was the 2nd game in the Silent Hill video game series but is not a direct sequel to Silent Hill.

[[Nils Horner]]

CATEGORIES: 1962 births, 2014 deaths, Assassinated people, British journalists, British writers, Deaths by firearm, Swedish journalists

Nils Horner (5 December 1962 – 11 March 2014) was a Swedish and British journalist. He was a foreign correspondent for Sveriges Radio. He was the station's chief correspondent in Asia. He mainly worked in South Asia. In 2001, he won the Marcus Ölanderpriest for his efforts as a foreign correspondent. He was born in Borås, Borås Municipality, Västra Götaland County.

Horner was shot in the head and killed in an execution-style killing on 11 March 2014 in Kabul, Afghanistan. He was 51 years old. He was in Kabul covering the 2014 elections.

[[Pat Green]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 births, Living people, American country musicians, Musicians from San Antonio, Texas, Singers from San Antonio, Texas, People from Waco, Texas

Pat Green is an American country musician active since 1995. He was born in San Antonio, Texas and raised in Waco, Texas. Fifteen of his singles have charted on the Billboard Hot Country Songs charts.

[[Ivan Mercep]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2014 deaths, Architects, People from North Island

Ivan Mercep (1930 – 8 April 2014) was a New Zealand architect.

Mercep spent six years working and travelling overseas, before returning to New Zealand in 1960. In 1964, he became a registered architect in New Zealand. He helped design Hoani Waititi Marae in West Auckland and Waipapa Marae at the University of Auckland.

Mercep died in Auckland, New Zealand, aged 84.

[[Kjell Nupen]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, 2014 deaths, Artists, Cancer deaths in Norway, Norwegian people

Kjell Nupen (September 5, 1955 – March 12, 2014) was a Norwegian contemporary artist. During the 1980s the people disappeared from his pictures and were replaced by motifs from nature. 

His later paintings are focused on themes such as calmness. He became especially known for the colour Nupen blue, in which he used a lot of in his paintings.

Nupen was born in Kristiansand, Norway. He died there on March 12, 2014 from cancer, aged 58.

[[David Henshaw]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2014 deaths, Cartoonists, New Zealand artists, People from North Island

Thomas David Henshaw (1939 – 23 March 2014) was a New Zealand cartoonist. He was known for his drawings of rural life in his "Jock" cartoons. His a career spanning over 40 years. His cartoons were published in the New Zealand Farmer for 34 years.

Henshaw was born in Kimbolton, New Zealand. He died on 23 March 2014 in Tamahere, New Zealand, aged 74.

[[Liv Dommersnes]]

CATEGORIES: 1922 births, 2014 deaths, Actors from Oslo, Deaths from natural causes, Norwegian movie actors, Norwegian stage actors, Norwegian television actors

Liv Dommersnes (née Strømsted 28 September 1922 – 6 April 2014) was a Norwegian actress and reciter of poetry. She was best known for being a member of the group that founded Studioteatret in 1945. She was born in Oslo (then known as Kristiania). She was married to actor Jens Bolling from 1945 to 1952, and to physician Ivar Dommersnes from 1968 until his death in 1994.

Dommersnes died from natural causes on 6 April 2014 in Oslo. She was 91 years old.

[[Joseph Willaert]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2014 deaths, Belgian painters, Cardiovascular disease deaths in Belgium, Deaths from stroke, People from West Flanders

Joseph Willaert (1936 – 2 April 2014) was a Belgian painter. He was known for his abstract paintings. He mostly hung his paintings in train stations or public areas. Some of his art has been internationally displayed in many museums.

Willaert was born in Diksmuide. He died on 2 April 2014 in Oostende, Belgium from complications of a stroke, aged 78.

[[Michael Prinz von Preußen]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2014 deaths, Writers from Berlin

Michael Prinz von Preußen (22 March 1940 – 3 April 2014) or Michael, Prince of Prussia, was a German writer and royalty. He was the son of Louis Ferdinand, Prince of Prussia. He was the godfather of Georg Friedrich, Prince of Prussia. He studied in Freiburg. He wrote many biographies about his family members. He was born in Berlin.

Michael died from an illness on 3 April 2014 in Thanheim, aged 74.

[[Paul Lüönd]]

He died on 3 April 2014 from a long illness in Switzerland, aged 63.

[[Zeituni Onyango]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, 2014 deaths, Cancer deaths in the United States, Deaths from breast cancer, Deaths from respiratory failure, Obama family, People from Nairobi

Zeituni Onyango (z zay; 29 May 1952 – 7 April 2014) was the half-aunt of United States President Barack Obama. She was the half-sister of Obama's late father Barack Obama, Sr.. She is called "Aunti Zeituni" in Obama's memoir Dreams from My Father. She was a computer programmer.

She was a native of Kenya. In 2000, she came to the United States illegally and in 2002 sought political asylum in the United States citing violence. Kenya and East Africa saw a rise in violence in the 2000s. Her case was denied in 2004 but she remained in South Boston, Massachusetts, before she got legal representation. Her case was leaked in the final days of the 2008 U.S. presidential election in which Obama was the Democratic candidate. She was given asylum in 2010.

Onyango died from breast cancer and a respiratory ailment on 7 April 2014 in Boston. She was 61 years old.

[[The Hardy Boyz]]

CATEGORIES: WWE teams and stables

The Hardy Boyz is a professional wrestling tag team. The team members were real-life brothers Matt and Jeff Hardy. The Hardy Boyz are best known for competing in World Wrestling Federation/Entertainment (WWE). They were known for competing in ladder matches and Tables, Ladders, and Chairs matches. They also worked for Total Nonstop Action Wrestling (TNA) for a short time. The team first started in independent promotions around North Carolina in 1993.

The team signed with the WWF in 1998. They joined Gangrel to form The New Brood in August 1999. During their time in the WWF, they were managed by Terri for a short time before they were managed full-time by their real-life friend Lita. When Lita joined, the team was known as "Team Xtreme". They split up in 2002 and reunited in 2006 to feud with MNM before they decided to focus on singles competition. Jeff left the company in August and Matt left in late 2010.

They both reunited in January 2011 in Total Nonstop Action Wrestling (TNA) where they were members of the Immortal stable. Matt was released from the company in August 2011 after he was arrested for driving while intoxicated.

[[Babymetal]]

Babymetal is a Japanese metal band. The members are Suzuka Nakamoto, Yui Mizuno and Moa Kikuchi. The band started in 2010. Their first album Babymetal was released on February 26, 2014 in Japan.

[[OkCupid]]

OkCupid is a free friendship, dating and social networking website. The website is part of the "Match Developing" unit of IAC/InterActiveCorp's Match division. In 2014 the website had 12 million users.

Steven Arthur Pinker (born September 18, 1954) is a Canadian-American experimental psychologist. He has written six popular psychology books. He is a Harvard College professor.

[[John Shirley-Quirk]]

John Shirley-Quirk CBE (28 August 1931 – 7 April 2014) was an English bass-baritone. He was a member of the English Opera Group from 1964 to 1976. He was known for performing and recording the operatic and vocal works of Benjamin Britten. He was born in Liverpool, Lancashire (now Merseyside).

Shirley-Quirk died on 7 April 2014 in Bath, Somerset. He was 82 years old.

[[Josep Maria Subirachs]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2014 deaths, Deaths from Parkinson's disease, Disease-related deaths in Barcelona, People from Barcelona, Spanish painters, Spanish sculptors

Josep Maria Subirachs i Sitjar (ʒuˈzɛb məˈɾi.ə suβiˈɾaks; 11 March 1927 – 7 April 2014) was a Spanish sculptor and painter of the late 20th century. His best known work is probably the Passion Façade of the basilica of the Sagrada Família in Barcelona.

Subirachs was born in Barcelona. He died there from Parkinson's disease on 7 April 2014. He was 87 years old.

[[Duchy of Savoy]]

CATEGORIES: 1860 disestablishments, Dukes and Duchesses of Savoy, Former monarchies in Italy, House of Savoy, 1416 establishments, Establishments in France, Establishments in Italy, 15th century establishments in Europe, 19th century disestablishments in Europe, Disestablishments in France, 1860s disestablishments in Italy

The Duchy of Savoy was a monarchy in northern Italy and southwest France. It was ruled by the Savoy family. They took their name from the territory. From 1416 to 1562, the capital of the state was Chambéry. From 1562 to 1713 after which the capital was Turin. The heir to the throne was usually given the title of Prince of Piedmont.

The main residence of the family was the Royal Palace of Turin.

It was originally a county but raised to a Duchy in 1416. It greatly increased in size due to the Kingdom of Sardinia being added to the Savoy family possessions. Parts of the Duchy of Milan had also been added before. The small duchy was a neighbour to the Duchy of Parma as well as the larger wealthier Grand Duchy of Tuscany both of which would later form close relationships with eachother often through marriages between princes and princesses. 

In 1860, under the terms of the Treaty of Turin, the Duchy of Savoy was annexed by France. The last Duke of Savoy, Victor Emmanuel II, became King of Italy and the country was united into modern Italy.

[[Emmanuel III Delly]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2014 deaths, Disease-related deaths in the United States, Eastern Catholics, Iraqi people, Patriarchs

Mar Emmanuel III Delly (26 October 1927 – 8 April 2014) was an Iraqi Catholic leader. He was the Patriarch Emeritus of Babylon of the Chaldeans and former Primate of the Chaldean Catholic Church. His name in Arabic is مار عمانوئيل الثالث دلّي. In Syriac it is ܡܪܝ ܥܡܢܘܐܝܠ ܬܠܝܬܝܐ ܕܠܝ. He was born in Tel Keppe.

Delly died on 8 April 2014 at a hospital in San Diego, California in the United States. He was 86 years old.

[[Edvard Grimstad]]

Edvard Grimstad (29 March 1933 – 3 April 2014) was a Norwegian politician. He was a member of the Centre Party. He served as an MP from 1989 until 1997. He was born in Råde, Østfold.

Grimstad died from natural causes on 3 April 2014 in Oslo. He was 91 years old.

[[Gyula Szabó]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2014 deaths, Hungarian movie actors, Hungarian stage actors, Hungarian television actors

Gyula Szabó (15 July 1930 – 4 April 2014) was a Hungarian actor. He won two Mari Jászai Prizes. He appeared in forty movies between 1953 and 2002. He is best known for appearing in movies such as Ifjú szívvel (1953), Kiskrajcár (1953), Hintónjáró szerelem (1955), Egy pikoló világos (1955), Kölyök (1959), Két emelet boldogság (1960), A tizedes meg a többiek (1965), Hahó, Öcsi! (1971), Defekt (1977), and A Hídember (2002). He was born in Kunszentmárton, Jász-Nagykun-Szolnok County.

Szabó died on 4 April 2014 at the age of 83.

[[Republic of Ezo]]

CATEGORIES: 1869 establishments in Japan, 1860s disestablishments in Japan, Former countries in Asia, Former republics, History of Japan, States and territories established in the 19th century, States and territories disestablished in the 19th century

Republic of Ezo, was a short-lived state in 1869 in the area that is now Hokkaido, Japan. It was established by former Tokugawa shogunate retainers. It was against the new imperial government. It was later defeated by Imperial forces.

[[Oddworld Inhabitants]]

CATEGORIES: Video game series, Fictional universes, Oddworld

Oddworld Inhabitants is a video game and film company founded in 1994 by Lorne Lanning and Sherry McKenna. The company is known for creating the Oddworld Quintology series released from 1997 to 2005. The series includes: Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee, Oddworld Abe's Exoddus, Oddworld: Munch's Oddysee and Oddworld: Stranger's Wrath, as well as two Gameboy and one Gameboy Advance games that were short versions of Abe's Oddysee, Abe's Exoddus, and Munch's Oddysee. They were titled: Oddworld Adventures, Oddworld Adventures II, and Munch's Oddysee. 

In 2005, Oddworld Inhabitants temporarily redirected their focus into the film industry, and eventually released a science fiction thriller called Citizen Siege.

They then released games under Just Add Water (Developments) UK LTD where they only sell digital products as of 2008 when the original PC games went up on Steam. They also made available the original PS1 games on the Playstation Network store in 2010 for the PS3 and PSP. The classics were made available for PS Vita in August 2012.   

They started work by porting the original Xbox version of Oddworld: Stranger's Wrath to PC. They then made an HD version and had several improvements made to it and it was released in 2011 for the PC and PS3. In 2012 Oddworld announced that Abe's Oddysee was getting a complete remake game from the ground up and its title which was chosen by fans is called Oddworld: New 'n' Tasty. They also released Oddworld: Munch's Oddysee HD for PS3 in December 2012. 

In 2013, it was announced that New 'n' Tasty will be coming in Spring 2014 and at the Game Developers Conference in California.  

[[Rapetosaurus]]

CATEGORIES: Titanosaurs

Rapetosaurus is a genus of sauropod dinosaur. It lived in what is now Madagascar from 70 to 66 million years ago, at the end of the Cretaceous period. Only one species, Rapetosaurus krausei, has been found. Like other sauropods, Rapetosaurus was a quadrupedal herbivore.

The discovery of Rapetosaurus was the first time a titanosaur had been recovered with an almost perfectly intact skeleton, complete with skull. It has helped to clarify some difficult issues in this large group of sauropod dinosaurs. It provides a baseline for the reconstruction of other titanosaurs that are known only from partial remains.

By the early part of the Upper Cretaceous all sauropods, except the titanosaurs, were extinct. The titanosaurs were the dominant herbivores of the Upper Cretaceous on the southern continents which made up Gondwana. Their reign was cut short by the Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event.

[[Volatiles]]

CATEGORIES: Geology, Astronomy, Chemical elements

In planetary science, volatiles are the group of chemical elements and compounds with a low boiling point. They are often found in the crust or atmosphere of a planet or moon. Examples of volatiles are nitrogen, water, and ammonia.

[[Beat Happening]]

CATEGORIES: 1982 establishments in the United States, 1980s American music groups, 1990s American music groups, 2000s American music groups, 2010s American music groups, American pop music groups, Indie bands, Musical groups established in 1982, Olympia, Washington, 1980s establishments in Washington (state)

Beat Happening is an American indie pop band from Olympia, Washington. Calvin Johnson, Heather Lewis, and Bret Lunsford started the band in 1982 after meeting at The Evergreen State College. The band has released five studio albums.

[[Hubei]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of China

Hubei (湖北; Postal map spelling: 

Hupeh) is a province of the People's Republic of China. The name of the province means "north of the lake" i.e. "north of Lake Dongting". The provincial capital is Wuhan.

[[Joseph E. Johnston]]

CATEGORIES: Confederate Army generals, 1807 births, 1891 deaths, People from Virginia

Joseph E. Johnston (February 3, 1807 – March 21, 1891) was a Confederate army general. He fought in the American Civil War. He was born in Virginia in 1807. He graduated from the U.S. Military Academy in 1829. He fought in the Second Seminole War and Mexican-American War. When the Civil War started, Johnston resigned from the U.S. army and joined the Confederate army. He was the second commander of the Army of Northern Virginia. He was wounded at the Battle of Seven Pines. He commanded the Army of Tennessee during the Atlanta Campaign. He was fired in July 1864. He was then placed back in command of the Army of Tennessee in March 1865. He commanded the army during the Battle of Benonville. He surrendered his army in April 1865. He died in 1891 in Washington, D.C.

[[Gansu]]

CATEGORIES: Gansu, Provinces of China

Gansu (甘) is a province of the People's Republic of China. The capital is Lanzhou, in the southeast part of the province.

It has an area of 454,430 km². As of 2010 about 25,575,000 people were living here; in 2018, the population is 26,257,000.

Most people of Gansu are Han Chinese.

The province is mountainous in the south but flat in the north.

The Gobi Desert lies partly in Gansu, and the Yellow River flows in the south.

It contains the geographical centre of China.

Gansu Province has a dry continental climate with cold winters and hot summers.

[[Army of Tennessee]]

CATEGORIES: Confederate States of America, Armies, 1862 establishments in the United States, 1860s disestablishments in the United States, 1865 disestablishments

The Army of Tennessee was a Confederate field army during the American Civil War. It fought in the Western Theater for most of the war. It was formed from the Army of Mississippi in November 1862. It surrendered in April 1865 in North Carolina.

[[Lanzhou]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in China, Gansu

Lanzhou (兰州; Postal map spelling: Lanchow) is the capital and largest city of Gansu in Northwest China. As of the 2010 census, 3,616,163 people lived in the city, and 2,177,130 lived in the built-up area (urban) of 1088.

[[Field army]]

CATEGORIES: Army

A field army is a military formation. It is made up of two or more corps. Two or more field armies can form an army group. A field army is usually commanded by a general or a lieutenant general.

[[Arrondissements of the Gers department]]

CATEGORIES: Arrondissements of France, Lists of arrondissements of France

There are 3 arrondissements in the Gers department. The French departments, and in other countries, are divided into arrondissements, which may be translated into English as districts (in some cases, as boroughs).  The capital of an arrondissement is called a subprefecture.

If the prefecture (capital) of the department is in an arrondissement, that prefecture is the capital of the arrondissement, acting both as a prefecture and as a subprefecture.

Arrondissements are further divided into cantons and communes.

The arrondissements of the Gers department are:

.

[[Arrondissement of Auch]]

CATEGORIES: Arrondissements of France

The arrondissement of Auch is an arrondissement of France.  It is part of the Gers département in the Occitanie region. Its capital is the city of Auch.

[[Donkey punch]]

CATEGORIES: Sexual acts

The donkey punch is an act during sexual intercourse. Some people wrongly think that if a man putting his penis in his partner's vagina or anus punches the back of their neck, the vagina and anus will become very tight, giving more pleasure to the man. In fact, no such reflex exists. In 2004, the pornography actress Gia Paloma was the first person to person to receive a donkey punch in a film.

[[Victor Emmanuel II of Italy]]

CATEGORIES: 1820 births, People from Turin, Kings and Queens of Sardinia, Princes and Princesses of Savoy, 1878 deaths, Kings and Queens of Italy

Victor Emmanuel II (Vittorio Emanuele Maria Alberto Eugenio Ferdinando Tommaso; 14 March 1820 – 9 January 1878) was king of Sardinia from 1849 until 17 March 1861. On that date, he took the title King of Italy to become the first king of a united Italy since the 6th century. He held that title until his death in 1878. The Italians called him "Father of the Homeland" (Padre della Patria).

Victor Emmanuel was born at the Palazzo Carignano in Turin. He was born the heir to the title of Prince of Carignano, which was one of the most senior members of the Sardinian royal court behind the monarch himself. He became ruler of the Kingdom of Sardinia when his father abdicated.

[[Arrondissement of Condom]]

CATEGORIES: Arrondissements of France

The arrondissement of Condom is an arrondissement of France.  It is part of the Gers département in the Occitanie region. Its capital is the city of Condom.

[[Arrondissement of Mirande]]

CATEGORIES: Arrondissements of France

The arrondissement of Mirande is an arrondissement of France.  It is part of the Gers département in the Occitanie region. Its capital is the city of Mirande.

[[Gers (river)]]

CATEGORIES: Rivers of France, Nouvelle-Aquitaine, Occitanie

The Gers is a French river that flows through the Hautes-Pyrénées, Gers and Lot-et-Garonne departments, in the Occitanie and Nouvelle-Aquitaine regions. The Gers department is named after this river.

The river's source is in the Pyrenees and is a left tributary of the Garonne river. In general, it flows from south to north.

[[Virginie Korte-van Hemel]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2014 deaths, Catholic People's Party politicians, Christian Democratic Appeal politicians, Deputy government ministers of the Netherlands, Aldermen of the Netherlands, Dutch councillors, Dutch lawyers, Dutch Roman Catholics, Dutch women politicians, Former members of the House of Representatives of the Netherlands, Members of the Senate of the Netherlands, Politicians from North Brabant

Virginie Norbertina Maria Korte-van Hemel (May 8, 1929 – April 3, 2014) was a Dutch politician. She was a member of the CDA on behalf of the House and Senate. In the cabinets Lubbers I and Lubbers II, she was Secretary for Justice.

She was also an alderman of Bussum from 1970 to 1974.

Hemel was born in Bergen op Zoom and died in Bussum, aged 84.

[[Jacques Castérède]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2014 deaths, Deaths from natural causes, French composers, French pianists, Musicians from Paris
