Castérède died on 6 April 2014 in Dijon from natural causes, aged 87.

[[Čedo Vuković]]

CATEGORIES: 1920 births, 2014 deaths, Deaths from disease, Montenegrin people, Writers

Čedo Vuković (28 September 1920 -  7 April 2014) was a Montenegrin writer. He wrote many books for children. Some of them include; "Svemoćno oko" (Allmighty Eye), "Letjelica profesora Bistrouma" (Flying Machine of Professor Brightmind) and "Tim Lavlje srce" (Lion-heart Team). Vuković was born in Đulići, Andrijevica city in north-eastern Montenegro. 

Vuković died in Budva after long-illness on April 7, 2014, aged 93.

[[A. N. R. Robinson]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2014 deaths, Presidents of Trinidad and Tobago, Prime Ministers of Trinidad and Tobago

Arthur Napoleon Raymond Robinson (16 December 1926 – 9 April 2014) was a Trinbagonian politician. 

He was the third President of Trinidad and Tobago, serving from 19 March 1997 to 17 March 2003. He was also Trinidad and Tobago's third Prime Minister, serving from 18 December 1986 to 17 December 1991.

Robinson helped create the International Criminal Court.

Robinson died at the St Claire Medical Center, in Port of Spain, aged 87.

[[Port of Spain]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in the Caribbean, Settlements in Trinidad and Tobago

Port of Spain is the capital city of Trinidad and Tobago. About 49,031 people live here. It is the third largest city in the country. It served as its capital since the 1700s.

[[Chaguanas]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in the Caribbean, Settlements in Trinidad and Tobago

Chaguanas is the largest city of Trinidad and Tobago. About 84,000 people live here. In 1990, it was made a borough.

[[San Fernando, Trinidad and Tobago]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in the Caribbean, Settlements in Trinidad and Tobago

San Fernando is the second largest city of Trinidad and Tobago. About 50,000 people live here. It used to be a borough, but was made into a city in 1988. Pitch Lake is located here.

[[George Maxwell Richards]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from congestive heart failure, Alumni of the University of Cambridge, Presidents of Trinidad and Tobago

George Maxwell Richards, TC, CM (1 December 1931 – 8 January 2018) was a Trinidadian politician. He was the fourth President of Trinidad and Tobago. He was in office from 2003 to 2013.

Richards died in Port of Spain on 8 January 2018 of congestive heart failure at the age of 86.

[[List of presidents of Trinidad and Tobago]]

CATEGORIES: Presidents of Trinidad and Tobago

The President of Trinidad and Tobago is the person who is in charge of the country of Trinidad and Tobago. They help the country and its people. The office was created in 1976 after being declared independent. The first President was Ellis Clarke.

[[Kamla Persad-Bissessar]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, Living people, Prime Ministers of Trinidad and Tobago, Commonwealth Chairpersons-in-Office

The Rt Hon. Kamla Persad-Bissessar PBS SC MP (born 22 April 1952) is a Trinidadian and Tobagonian lawyer and  politician who was the seventh Prime Minister of Trinidad and Tobago from 26 May 2010 to 9 September 2015. She was the country's first female Prime Minister, Attorney General, and Leader of the Opposition. She is also the first woman of Indian origin to be a prime minister in a country outside of India and South Asia.

[[Basdeo Panday]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, Living people, Prime Ministers of Trinidad and Tobago

Basdeo Panday (born May 25, 1933) is a Trinidadian politician. He was the fifth Prime Minister of Trinidad and Tobago. He served as Prime Minister from 1995 to 2001.

[[Anthony Carmona]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, Living people, Presidents of Trinidad and Tobago

Anthony Thomas Aquinas Carmona, SC, ORTT (born March 7, 1953) is a Trinidadian politician. He is the fifth President of Trinidad and Tobago. He became president in 2013.

[[Ellis Clarke]]

CATEGORIES: 1917 births, 2010 deaths, Presidents of Trinidad and Tobago

Sir Ellis Emmanuel Innocent Clarke, TC, GCMG (28 December 1917spaced ndash30 December 2010) was a Trinidadian politician. He was the second and last Governor-General of Trinidad and Tobago and the first President of Trinidad and Tobago. He was one of the people who created Trinidad and Tobago's 1962 Independence constitution.

[[Karlheinz Deschner]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2014 deaths, Disease-related deaths in Germany, Former Roman Catholics, German activists, Humanists, Writers from Bavaria

Karl Heinrich Leopold Deschner (23 May 1924 – 8 April 2014) was a German researcher, humanist, activist and writer. He was known in Europe for his in-depth and strong dislike towards Christianity in general and the Catholic Church. This was the subject of many of his articles and books. His best known work was the 10 volume opus Christianity's Criminal History (Kriminalgeschichte des Christentums, Rowohlt Verlag GmbH, Reinbek). He was born in Bamberg, Bavaria, Weimar Republic.

Deschner died on 8 April 2014 in Haßfurt, Bavaria, Germany. He was 89 years old.

[[Noor Hassanali]]

CATEGORIES: 1918 births, 2006 deaths, Presidents of Trinidad and Tobago

Noor Mohamed Hassanali, TC (13 August 1918 – 25 August 2006) was a Trinidadian politician. He was the second President of Trinidad and Tobago. He served from 1987 to 1997.

[[Patrick Manning]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2016 deaths, Deaths from acute myeloid leukemia, Prime Ministers of Trinidad and Tobago, Commonwealth Chairpersons-in-Office

Patrick Augustus Mervyn Manning (17 August 1946 – 2 July 2016) was a Trinidadian politician. He was the fourth Prime Minister of Trinidad and Tobago. He served from 17 December 1991 to 9 November 1995 and again from 24 December 2001 to 26 May 2010.

Manning died on 2 July 2016 at a hospital in San Fernando from acute myeloid leukemia, aged 69.

[[Eric Williams]]

CATEGORIES: 1911 births, 1981 deaths, Alumni of the University of Oxford, Deaths from throat cancer, Prime Ministers of Trinidad and Tobago

Eric Eustace Williams (25 September 1911 – 29 March 1981) was a Trinidadian politician. He served as the first Prime Minister of Trinidad and Tobago. He served as prime minister from 1962 until his death in 1981. 

He was also a known Caribbean historian, and is widely thought as "The Father of The Nation" to Trinidadians. 

Williams died from throat cancer in Port of Spain, Trinidad and Tobago, aged 69.

[[Hans Albert]]

CATEGORIES: 1921 births, Living people, German philosophers, People from Cologne

Hans Albert (born February 8, 1921) is a German philosopher. He was born in Cologne. He lives in Heidelberg.

His fields of research are Social Sciences and General Studies of Methods. He is a critical rationalist, giving special attention to rational heuristics (problem solving).

[[Danielle Darrieux]]

CATEGORIES: 1917 births, 2017 deaths, Accidental deaths from falls, French centenarians, French movie actors, French stage actors, French television actors, People from Bordeaux

Danielle Yvonne Marie Antoinette Darrieux (1 May 1917 – 17 October 2017) was a French actress and singer. She has appeared in more than 110 movies since 1931. She is one of France's great movie stars and her eighty year career.

Darrieux was born in Bordeaux, France. She died on 17 October 2017 in Bois-le-Roi, France from complications of a fall, aged 100 year old. For her long service to the motion picture industry, in 1985 Danielle was given an Honorary César Award. 

[[Mandy Patinkin]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, Actors from Chicago, Singers from Chicago

Mandel Bruce "Mandy" Patinkin (born November 30, 1952) is an American actor and tenor singer. He is known for his roles in Alien Nation (1988), Yentl (1983), and Dick Tracy.

[[Aino-Maija Tikkanen]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2014 deaths, Deaths from natural causes, Finnish movie actors, Finnish stage actors, Finnish television actors

Aino-Maija Tikkanen (2 November 1927 – 3 March 2014) was a Finnish actress. She appeared in 15 movies between 1954 and 2010. She was born in Turku.

Tikkanen died on 3 March 2014 in Helsinki. She was 86 years old.

[[Yvette Chauviré]]

CATEGORIES: 1917 births, 2016 deaths, Entertainers from Paris, French ballet dancers

Yvette Chauviré (22 April 1917 – 19 October 2016) was a French prima ballerina and actress. She was born in Paris. Her dancing career was from 1937 to 1972. She was the étoile of the Paris Opera Ballet, and later its director. She was the holder of the Légion d'Honneur. 

She died at her home in Paris on 19 October 2016, aged 99.

[[Wendell H. Ford]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2015 deaths, Deaths from lung cancer, Governors of Kentucky, United States senators from Kentucky, US Democratic Party politicians, People from Owensboro, Kentucky, Lieutenant Governors of Kentucky

Wendell Hampton Ford (September 8, 1924 – January 22, 2015) was an American politician. He served for twenty-four years in the U.S. Senate and was the 53rd Governor of Kentucky. He was the first person to be successively elected lieutenant governor, governor, and U.S. senator in Kentucky history.

Ford died in Owensboro, Kentucky from lung cancer, aged 90.

[[Dale Bumpers]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, 2016 deaths, Accidental deaths from falls in the United States, People with Alzheimer's disease, Governors of Arkansas, United States senators from Arkansas, US Democratic Party politicians

Dale Leon Bumpers (August 12, 1925 – January 1, 2016) was an American politician. He served as the 38th Governor of Arkansas from 1971 to 1975. Bumpers served in the United States Senate from 1975 until his retirement in January 1999.

After his retirement from the Senate, Bumpers, a self-declared close friend of President Clinton, acted as defense attorney during Clinton's impeachment trial. He gave an impassioned closing argument during the Senate trial.

Bumpers died on January 1, 2016 at his home in Little Rock, Arkansas from complications from a fall at the age of 90. Bumpers was suffering from Alzheimer's disease at the time of his death.

[[Lakhdar Brahimi]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, Living people, Algerian politicians, African diplomats

Lakhdar Brahimi (Algerian pronunciation: læxdˤɑr bræhiːmi; الأخضر الإبراهيمى; born 1 January 1934) is an Algerian diplomat and politician. He is the United Nations envoy and advisor. Since August 2012, he was the United Nations and Arab League Special Envoy to Syria.

[[Fernando Henrique Cardoso]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, Living people, Presidents of Brazil, Civil servants, People from Rio de Janeiro

Fernando Henrique Cardoso (feɾˈnɐ̃dw ẽjˈʁiki kaʁˈdozu; born June 18, 1931), also known by his initials FHC (ˈɛfjɐˌɡaˈse) is a Brazilian politician. He was the 34th President of Brazil. He served for two terms from January 1, 1995 to December 31, 2002.

[[Shimabara Rebellion]]

CATEGORIES: History of Japan, 1630s, Rebellions in Asia

Shimabara Rebellion, was an uprising in southwestern Japan.  It lasted from December 17, 1637 until April 15, 1638, during the Edo period.  It largely involved peasants, most of them Catholic Christians.

[[Vladimir Zinchenko]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2014 deaths, Disease-related deaths in Russia, Russian educators, Psychologists, Russian writers

Vladimir Petrovich Zinchenko (Владимир Петрович Зинченко; 10 August 1931 – 6 February 2014) was a Russian psychologist, academician, educator and writer. He got a Ph.D. in 1957. He was also an editor-in-chief of the journal of Cultural-Historical Psychology. He was born in Kharkiv, Soviet Union (now Ukraine).

Zinchenko died on 6 February 2014 in Moscow, Russia. He was 82 years old.

[[Thomas Kurzhals]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, 2014 deaths, Deaths from cirrhosis, Disease-related deaths in Germany, German composers, Keyboardists, People from Thuringia, Rock musicians

Thomas Kurzhals (13 December 1953 – 2 January 2014) was a German keyboardist, composer and musician. He was best known as a member of the rock bands Stern-Combo Meißen and Karat. He was born in Ronneburg, Thuringia, East Germany.

Kurzhals died from liver cirrhosis on 2 January 2014 in Glauchau, Saxony. He was 60 years old.

[[Dominique Baudis]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2014 deaths, Cancer deaths in France, French journalists, French mayors, Politicians from Paris, Writers from Paris

Dominique Baudis (bodi; 14 April 1947 – 10 April 2014) was a French ombudsman, journalist and politician. He was the Mayor of Toulouse, Haute-Garonne from March 1983 until January 2001. He was also a member of DL and later of the leading centre-right Union for a Popular Movement. He was born in Paris.

Baudis died from cancer on 10 April 2014 in Paris. He was 66 years old.

[[West Malling]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Kent

West Malling is a small market town in Tonbridge and Malling, Kent, England. Its postcode is ME19.            

There are many historical sites in West Malling that make it a popular place to visit. There are many shops. There is a population of between 3,000 and 5,000 people. St Mary's church is at the top of the High Street.           

[[Kaleph Jõulu]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2014 deaths, Estonian educators, Estonian people, Estonian writers

Kaleph Jõulu (15 November 1927 – 22 January 2014) was an Estonian educator, writer and folklore collector. He was best known for his book Maailma 33333 rahvatarkust (2013). He won the Rahvaluule kogumispreemia (Folklore Prize) four times (1994, 1996, 1997, 2007). He was born in Rapla, Rapla County.

Jõulu died on 22 January 2014 in Viljandi, Viljandi County. He was 86 years old.

[[Nigel Evans]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 births, Former Conservative MPs (UK), Gay men, LGBT politicians, Living people, Members of the British House of Commons for English constituencies, People acquitted of rape, People acquitted of sex crimes, Politicians from Swansea, Welsh LGBT people

Nigel Martin Evans (born 10 November 1957) is a British politician. He was born in Swansea, Wales. He has been the Member of Parliament for Ribble Valley since 1992. He was a Conservative until 2013. Since then he has been an Independent. He was First Deputy Chairman of Ways and Means from 2010 to 2013.

[[Karin Dreijer Andersson]]

CATEGORIES: 1975 births, Living people, Swedish singers

Karin Elisabeth Dreijer Andersson (born 7 April 1975), also known by her stage name Fever Ray, is the lead singer of The Knife. 

[[Władysław Filipowiak]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2014 deaths, Archaeologists, Deaths from natural causes, Polish academics, Polish writers

Władysław Filipowiak (29 April 1926 – 31 March 2014) was a Polish professor, writer, and archaeologist. He was a former director of the National Museum in Szczecin. 

He was the author of over 200 publications in the field of early medieval archeology. In the past year has been an Honorary Citizen of the Commune Wolin. Filipowiak was born in Kaczycach, Poland.

Filipowiak died on 31 March 2014 in Szczecin, Poland from natural causes, aged 87.

[[Owen Chadwick]]

CATEGORIES: 1916 births, 2015 deaths, British educators, English historians, English rugby union players, Sportspeople from Kent, Writers from Kent

William Owen Chadwick, OM, KBE, FBA, FRSE (20 May 1916 – 17 July 2015) was a British professor, writer and prominent historian of Christianity. He was also a rugby union player. 

Chadwick was born in Bromley, Kent, England. He died at the age of 99 on 17 July 2015.

[[Albert Brooks]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, Screenwriters from California, Movie directors from California, Actors from Beverly Hills, California, Comedians from Los Angeles County, California

Albert Lawrence Brooks (born Albert Lawrence Einstein; July 22, 1947) is an American actor, voice actor, writer, comedian, and director. He was known for his roles in Modern Romance (1981), Lost in America (1985), Defending Your Life (1991), Finding Nemo (2004), The Simpsons Movie (2007), and Drive (2011).

Brooks was born in Beverly Hills, California.

[[Carlo Maria Martini]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2012 deaths, Cardinals of the Roman Catholic Church, Deaths from Parkinson's disease, Disease-related deaths in Italy, Italian Roman Catholics, Jesuits, People from Piedmont, Roman Catholic archbishops

Carlo Maria Martini, S.J., (15 February 1927 – 31 August 2012) was an Italian Jesuit and cardinal of the Catholic Church. He was Archbishop of Milan from 1980 to 2002.

Martini was born in Orbassano, Kingdom of Italy. He died in Gallarate, Italy on 31 August 2012 from Parkinson's disease, aged 85.

[[Jean Giraud]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2012 deaths, Cancer deaths in France, Cartoonists, Deaths from lymphoma, French artists, French writers

Jean Henri Gaston Giraud (8 May 1938 – 10 March 2012) was a French artist, cartoonist, and writer. He was known for his comic Blueberry. His pseudonym was Mœbius or Gir.

Giraud was born in Nogent-sur-Marne. He died on 10 March 2014 in Paris from lymphoma, aged 73.

[[Wisława Szymborska]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2012 deaths, Deaths from natural causes, Polish essayists, Polish poets, Polish Nobel Prize winners, European translators

Wisława Szymborska-Włodek, Maria Wisława Anna Szymborska v (2 July 1923 – 1 February 2012) was a Polish poet, essayist, and translator. She was the recipient of the 1996 Nobel Prize in Literature.

Szymborska was born in Prowent. She died on 1 February 2012 at home in Kraków from natural causes, aged 88.

[[Joe Dini]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2014 deaths, Businesspeople from Nevada, Deaths from heart failure, Disease-related deaths in Nevada, Politicians from Nevada, Writers from Nevada, US Democratic Party politicians

Joseph E. "Joe" Dini, Jr. (March 28, 1929 – April 10, 2014) was an American politician for the Democratic Party and business man. He was elected to the Nevada State Assembly for the 38th district (which includes Lyon County, Storey County and parts of Carson City) in 1967 and served until 2001. He also owned the Dini's Lucky Club from 1960 until 2007. He was born in Yerington, Nevada.

Dini died from heart failure after an illness on April 10, 2014 at a hosptial in Reno, Nevada. He was 85 years old.

[[Vicco von Bülow]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2011 deaths, Cartoonists, Deaths from natural causes, German comedians, German movie actors, German movie directors, German television actors, Television directors, Writers from Brandenburg

Bernhard-Victor Christoph-Carl von Bülow, short: Vicco von Bülow, alias Loriot (12 November 1923 – 22 August 2011) was a German comedian, humorist, cartoonist, movie director, actor and writer.

He is best known for his cartoons, the sketches from his 1976 television series Loriot, alongside Evelyn Hamann, and his two movies, Ödipussi (1988) and Pappa Ante Portas (1991).

Von Bülow was born in Brandenburg an der Havel. He died on 22 August 2011 in Ammerland at Lake Starnberg, Germany from natural causes, aged 87.

[[Andrew Wyeth]]

CATEGORIES: 1917 births, 2009 deaths, American artists, American painters, Disease-related deaths in the United States, People from Pennsylvania, Congressional Gold Medal recipients

Andrew Newell Wyeth (ˈ WY; July 12, 1917 – January 16, 2009) was an American visual artist, primarily a realist painter, working mostly in a regionalist style. He was one of the best-known U.S. artists of the middle 20th century.

Wyeth was born in Chadds Ford, Pennsylvania. He was the youngest of N.C. Wyeth's five children. His siblings included artists Henriette Wyeth and Carolyn Wyeth as well as inventor Nathaniel Wyeth. In 1940, he married Betsy James, who would often model in his paintings.

On January 16, 2009, Wyeth died in his sleep in Chadds Ford after a brief illness. He was 91 years old.

[[Kathleen O'Malley]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors

Kathleen O'Malley (born March 31, 1924) is an American retired actress. Her career began as a child. Her father was actor Pat O'Malley. Her screen debut came in 1926 in one of his movies, My old Dutch.

She appeared in many television series such as Cover Girl, Lady on a Train, Two Tickets to Broadway, Maverick, Rawhide and General Hospital.

[[Francesco Cossiga]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2010 deaths, Deaths from respiratory tract infection, Disease-related deaths in Rome, People from Sardinia, Presidents of Italy, Prime Ministers of Italy

Francesco Cossiga (26 July 1928 – 17 August 2010) was an Italian politician. He was the 8th President of Italy, serving from July 1985 to April 1992. He was the 42nd Prime Minister of Italy, serving from August 1979 to 1980.

Cossiga was born in Sassari, Sardinia. He died on 17 August 2010 in Rome, Italy from a respiratory infection, aged 82.

[[Matteo Renzi]]

CATEGORIES: 1975 births, Living people, Mayors, People from Florence, Politicians from Tuscany, Prime Ministers of Italy

Matteo Renzi (matˈtɛo ˈrɛntsi; born 11 January 1975) is an Italian politician. He is the 56th and current Prime Minister of Italy. He became Prime Minister on 22 February 2014. Before, he was the President of Florence Province from 2004 to 2009 and the Mayor of Florence from 2009 to 2014. He resigned on 5 December 2016.

[[Bayn Johnson]]

CATEGORIES: 1958 births, Living people, Actors from New Orleans, Louisiana, American dancers, American guitarists, Singers from New Orleans, Louisiana, Musicians from New Orleans, Louisiana

Bayn Johnson (born in November 4, 1958) is an American former actress, electric guitarist, and singer. She was born in New Orleans, Louisiana. She appeared on season 1 (1969-1970) of Sesame Street. She also appeared as "Kelly (The Short Circus kid band member)" on seasons 3-4 (1973-1975) of The Electric Company.

[[Sue Townsend]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2014 deaths, British children's writers, Cardiovascular disease deaths in England, Deaths from stroke, English playwrights, English novelists, English screenwriters, Organ transplant recipients, People from Leicester, Republicans, Writers from Leicestershire

Susan Lillian "Sue" Townsend, FRSL (2 April 1946 – 10 April 2014) was an English novelist and playwright. She was best known as the author of the Adrian Mole books. Most of her works combined comedy with social commentary and also wrote purely dramatic works. She was born in Leicester, Leicestershire.

Townsend was diagnosed with diabetes in the 1980s. She received a kidney from her elder son in 2009. She had a stroke in 2012. She died on 10 April 2014 at her home in Leicester after having another stroke. She was 68 years old.

[[Chinghiz Aitmatov]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2008 deaths, Ambassadors of the Soviet Union, Deaths from pneumonia, Deaths from renal failure, Disease-related deaths in Bavaria, Kyrgyzstani people, Soviet writers

Chyngyz Aitmatov (Чинги́з Тореку́лович Айтма́тов) (12 December 1928 – 10 June 2008) was a Soviet-Kyrgyz author and diplomat. He wrote in both Russian and Kyrgyz. He is a famous author in Kyrgyzstan's literature. His best-known work abroad is a novel The Day Lasts More than a Hundred Years, which has folklore and science fiction elements.

Aitmatov was born on 12 December 1928 in Sheker village, Kirghiz ASSR, USSR. 

Aitmatov was first the ambassador for the Soviet Union and later for Kyrgyzstan, to the European Union, NATO, UNESCO and the Benelux countries. In 1963, he was honored with the Lenin Prize for his works in literature.

Aitmatov died on 10 June 2008 from kidney failure and pneumonia in Nuremberg, Germany, aged 79.

[[Division of Forde]]

CATEGORIES: Electoral divisions of Australia, Queensland, 1984 establishments in Australia

The Division of Forde is an Australian Electoral Division in Queensland. It was set up in 1984, and is named after Frank Forde, Prime Minister of Australia in 1945. At first it covered the southern suburbs of Brisbane, but changes have moved the area of the division into the semi-rural areas south of the city. This includes Beenleigh, Bethania, Boronia Heights, Chambers Flat, Cornubia, Eagleby, Edens Landing, Loganholme, Logan Reserve, Mount Warren Park, Ormeau Hills, Park Ridge, Tanah Merah, Upper Coomera, Waterford, Waterford West and Windaroo as well as parts of Daisy Hill, Heritage Park, Loganlea, Munruben, Ormeau, Park Ridge South and Shailer Park.

[[Müllerian agenesis]]

CATEGORIES: Syndromes

Müllerian agenesis is a rare birth defect also called Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome or MRKH. People with the syndrome are born without vaginas, cervixes, and wombs, despite being biologically female. Queen Amalia of Greece had the syndrome. People with the syndrome cannot get pregnant because they do not have wombs.

[[Division of Groom]]

CATEGORIES: Electoral divisions of Australia, Queensland, 1984 establishments in Australia

The Division of Groom is an Australian Electoral Division in Queensland. It was set up in 1984 and named for Sir Littleton Groom, former Speaker of the Australian House of Representatives. He represented the Division of Darling Downs, which covered much of the same area.

It is in the rural areas west of Brisbane and includes Toowoomba, Australia's second largest inland city. Other towns include Oakey and Pittsworth.

[[Time of the Season]]

CATEGORIES: 1968 songs, Pop songs

"Time of the Season" (where the breaths, sighs and flutish pianish organ were heard) is a single from The Zombies. It is a ballad about emotions in the Summer of Love. Colin Blunstone is lead singer.

The song hit #3 on the Billboard Hot 100, and #1 in Canada. It did not chart in Britain.

The song was sampled and covered by quite a few artists in the years after.

[[Harald Nugiseks]]

CATEGORIES: 1921 births, 2014 deaths, Anti-Communists, Deaths from natural causes, Estonian people, European military people, Recipients of the Knight's Cross, SS officers, Waffen-SS people

Harald Nugiseks (22 October 1921 – 2 January 2014) was an SS-Oberscharführer (Sergeant) in World War II. He served at his own free will in the 20th Waffen Grenadier Division of the SS (1st Estonian) of the Waffen SS. He was also one of the four Estonian soldiers who received the Knight's Cross of the Iron Cross. He was born in Karjaküla, Särevere Parish, Järva County.

Nugiseks died from natural causes on 2 January 2014, aged 92.

[[Sonny Ruberto]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2014 deaths, American baseball players, Cancer deaths in the United States, Cincinnati Reds players, San Diego Padres players, Sportspeople from New York City

John Edward "Sonny" Ruberto (January 2, 1946 – March 25, 2014) was an American baseball backup catcher and pinch runner. He played in the Major League Baseball (MLB) and played two seasons for the San Diego Padres (1969) and the Cincinnati Reds (1972). He was born in the Staten Island borough of New York City, New York.

Ruberto died from cancer on March 25, 2014 in Ave Maria, Florida. He was 68 years old.

[[Tonie Nathan]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2014 deaths, Deaths from Alzheimer's disease, Disease-related deaths in the United States, Jewish American politicians, Jewish women politicians, Politicians from New York City, US Libertarian Party politicians

Theodora Nathalia "Tonie" Nathan (February 9, 1923 – March 20, 2014) was an American politician. She is the first woman, as well as the first Jewish person, to have got an electoral vote in a United States presidential election. She was the 1972 vice presidential nominee of the Libertarian Party and running mate of John Hospers. She was born in New York City.

Nathan died from Alzheimer's disease on March 20, 2014 in Eugene, Oregon. She was 91 years old.

[[Pam Tillis]]

CATEGORIES: Singers from Nashville, Tennessee, Singers from Florida, American singer-songwriters, American country musicians, 1957 births, Living people

Pamela Yvonne "Pam" Tillis (born July 24, 1957) is an American country music singer and actress. She began her career in 1981. In 1991, she had a song in the Top 40 on the Billboard Hot Country Songs for the first time.

Tillis has released many albums. Two of them are Put Yourself in My Place and Sweetheart's Dance.

Tillis was born in Florida. She was raised in Nashville, Tennessee. Her father is the late country music singer Mel Tillis.

[[WrestleMania 31]]

CATEGORIES: 2015 in professional wrestling, 2015 in California, Sports in California, WrestleMania, March 2015 events

WrestleMania 31 was a professional wrestling pay-per-view show made by WWE. It was held on March 29, 2015 at Levi's Stadium in Santa Clara, California. It was the thirty-first WrestleMania event held by the WWE. The event earned a record gate of $12.6 million. It also broke Levi's Stadium's attendance record by 6,177 people.

The main event saw Roman Reigns face Brock Lesnar for the WWE World Heavyweight Championship. During the match, Seth Rollins ran to the ring and cashed in his Money in the Bank contract which made the match a triple threat match. Rollins won the match and the championship. Another match on the card saw Sting compete in his first WWE match where he was defeated by Triple H. 

[[Richard W. Burkhardt]]

CATEGORIES: 1918 births, 2014 deaths, American academics, Deaths from natural causes, People from Newton, Massachusetts

Richard Wellington Burkhardt (May 18, 1918 – March 4, 2014) was an American academic. He was the 8th President of Ball State University, from 1978 to 1979. He retired in 1985. He was born in Newton, Massachusetts.

Burkhardt died from natural causes on May 18, 1918 in Muncie, Indiana. He was 95 years old.

[[Leopoldo María Panero]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2014 deaths, Deaths from heart failure, Spanish poets, Writers from Madrid

Leopoldo María Panero (16 June 1948 – 5 March 2014) was a Spanish poet. He was often placed in the Novísimos group. He had fifteen poetic releases between 1970 and 2004. He was born in Madrid.

Panero died from heart failure on 5 March 2014 in Madrid. He was 65 years old.

[[Alemayehu Atomsa]]

CATEGORIES: 1969 births, 2014 deaths, Deaths from food poisoning, Ethiopian politicians

Alemayehu Atomsa (አለማየው ፡ አቶምሳ; 12 February 1969 – 6 March 2014) was an Ethiopian politician. He served as the president of the Oromo Region, the largest of the country's regions, from 2010 until he resgined due to illness in 2014. He was born in Bonaya Boshe, Welega.

Atomsa died from food poisoning on 6 March 2014 at the Bumrungrad International Hospital in Bangkok, Thailand. He was 45 years old.

[[Brett Borgen]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2014 deaths, Novelists, Poets, Writers from Oslo

Brett Borgen (7 November 1934 – 11 March 2014) was a Norwegian novelist and poet. Her best known works were Fra en ikke helt vellykket skuespillerinnes dagbok (1972), Dualoger med Vår Herre and Isabella, sorgen og Don Juan (1977), En time med Jesus (1978), Den fortapte datter (1979), Heltinnen (1981). She also wrote the memoir Lillelord og Lady Brett (1985). 

She was born in Oslo. She died on 11 March 2014 in her hometown of Oslo. She was 79 years old.

[[Anius]]

CATEGORIES: People in Greek mythology

In Greek mythology, Anius was a king of Delos and priest of Apollo. He was the son of Apollo and Rhoeo.

Anius told the Greeks the Trojan War would not be won until the tenth year.

[[Lapiro de Mbanga]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 births, 2014 deaths, Cameroonian people, Cancer deaths in the United States, Hip hop musicians

Lambo Sandjo Pierre Roger (7 April 1957 – 16 March 2014), better known as Lapiro de Mbanga, was a Cameroonian singer. He is best known for his 1985 recording of “Pas argent no love” and for being imprisoned in 2008 after criticizing Cameroon president Paul Biya in the song “Constitution constipée” (“Constipated Constitution”). He was born in Mbanga, Southwest Region.

Mbanga died from cancer on 16 March 2014 in Buffalo, New York in the United States. He was 56 years old.

[[Lake Winnipeg]]

CATEGORIES: Lakes of Canada, Manitoba

Lake Winnipeg is a big lake in the province of Manitoba, Canada. It is north of the city of Winnipeg. It is the biggest lake in south Canada.

[[Palazzo Carignano]]

CATEGORIES: Turin, Palaces in Italy, Former royal residences

The Palazzo Carignano is a former palace in Turin, Italy. It was the residence of the Princes of Carignano, a line directly related to the royal family. It is famous for its unique rounded façade. It was also the birthplace of Princess Marie Louise of Savoy. It was the birthplace of Vittorio Emanuele II of Italy, the first king of Italy.  The building is near the larger Royal Palace of Turin.

[[Kia Forte]]

CATEGORIES: Kia automobiles, Sedans, 2000s automobiles, 2010s automobiles

The Kia Forte is a small automobile that is built by Kia Motors. The Kia Forte has had two generations, the newest one in 2014. In some places like Costa Rica, Australia and Brazil, the Forte is known as the Kia Cerato, which replaces its former automobile of the same name. The automobile is known as the Kia Cerato Forte in Colombia and Singapore and is known as the Naza Forte in Naza of Malaysia where it has been assembled since 2009.

[[Aularches]]

CATEGORIES: Orthoptera

Aularches miliaris is a grasshopper found in south and southeast Asia. It is protected by powerful chemical defences, and its warning colour signals its foul taste.

When it is disturbed or grabbed, it makes a sharp rasping noise with its thoracic segments. Then, if its thorax is pinched, it gives off a toxic foam. It squirts a clear viscous mucus with unpleasant smell and a bitter taste, faintly alkaline, with many bubbles. This foam comes out as a strong jet from openings in the thorax, and more gently from other openings in the body (ten in total). The foam heaps up around the insect and partly covers it.

[[Mitsubishi Outlander]]

CATEGORIES: Mitsubishi automobiles, Sport utility vehicles, 2000s automobiles, 2010s automobiles

The Mitsubishi Outlander is a mid-size crossover SUV that is built by Mitsubishi Motors. The Mitsubishi Outlander has had three generations, the newest one in 2012. When it was first introduced in Japan in 2001, the vehicle was known as the Mitsubishi Airtrek and it was based on the Mitsubishi ASX concept vehicle that was exhibited at the 2001 North American International Auto Show.

They chose the name Airtrek because it was to "describe the vehicle’s ability to transport its passengers on adventure-packed journeys in a 'free-as-a-bird' manner" and was "coined from Air and Trek to express the idea of footloose, adventure-filled motoring pleasure." The new name Outlander was chosen because it suggested a "feeling of journeying to distant, unexplored lands in search of adventure."

[[Camelops]]

CATEGORIES: Mammals of North America, Megafauna, Ungulates

Camelops is an extinct genus of camel which lived in North America during the Pleistocene. from two million years ago to about 10,000 years ago.

They were prey for the wolves, bears, lions and Smilodon. Camelops disappeared at the end of the last ice age, as did many other animals.

[[Steppe bison]]

CATEGORIES: Mammals of Asia, Mammals of Europe, Mammals of North America, Megafauna, Bovines

The steppe bison, or steppe wisent (Bison priscus), is an extinct bison. It lived on steppes in Europe, Central Asia, Beringia, and North America during the Quaternary. It is believed that it evolved somewhere in South Asia, That would mean it appeared  at about the same time and region as the aurochs, with which its descendants are sometimes confused.

The steppe wisent became extinct in the Pleistocene. It was replaced in Europe by the modern wisent species. It was replaced in America by Bison latifrons, then later Bison antiquus), and finally the modern American bison.

Steppe wisent occasionally appear in cave painting. They are in the famous Cave of Altamira and Lascaux. They have also been found in naturally ice-preserved form.

[[Perfume Genius]]

CATEGORIES: American LGBT people, Living people

Perfume Genius is the stage name for Mike Hadreas. Hadreas released his first album Learning in 2010. Pitchfork gave it a score of 8.2 out of 10. In 2012 he released his second album, Put Your Back N 2 It.

[[If You Asked Me To]]

CATEGORIES: 1989 songs, Pop songs, Celine Dion songs

"If You Asked Me To" is a popular single first performed by Patti LaBelle. The song was from the Licence to Kill movie soundtrack. It was also on LaBelle's album Be Yourself.

The song was released in 1989. It hit top ten on the Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs chart. Three years later, it hit #4 on the Billboard Hot 100. That version was done by Celine Dion in April 1992. Her version hit in America and Canada.

[[Sheepdog]]

A sheepdog is a dog trained to herd sheep. Many different breeds can be trained to do this task. One of the most common sheepdog breeds is the Border Collie. 

[[Lawrence Walsh]]

CATEGORIES: 1912 births, 2014 deaths, American centenarians, American judges, American lawyers, Deaths from natural causes, People from Nova Scotia, Politicians from New York City, United States Deputy Attorneys General

Lawrence Edward Walsh (January 8, 1912 – March 19, 2014) was an American lawyer and former U.S. District Court judge and Deputy Attorney General.

Walsh grew up in New York City. He was appointed Independent Counsel in December 1986 to investigate the Iran-Contra affair during the Ronald Reagan Administration.

Walsh died from natural causes at the age of 102 at his Nichols Hills, Oklahoma home.

[[Patrick Joseph McGovern]]

Patrick Joseph McGovern, Jr. (August 11, 1937 – March 19, 2014) was an American businessman. He was known for being chairman and founder of International Data Group (IDG). He was listed on the Forbes 400 list of the richest Americans in September, 2013 as having a net worth of $5.1 billion.

McGovern died on March 19, 2014, aged 76.

[[Ronald Selmour]]

CATEGORIES: Year of birth missing (living people), Living people, Canadian television actors

Ronald Selmour is a Canadian actor. He is well known for his role as Firecracker Man in ABC's Kingdom Hospital, Sundown in the Discovery Channel's TV miniseries Klondike and  The Butcher in the CW's Arrow.

Selmour has been involved in the performing Arts from the early years of his life. Though Profoundly religious, his father was very involved with local theatres taking him to see presentations throughout Port-au-Prince, Haiti. In the early 1980s the family made the difficult decision to let him go to Canada, stayed with his aunt while pursuing his studies. In Montreal, Quebec, there he made the acquaintance of several instrumental people in his life, teachers, professors and a mentor name Solly Levy who introduced him to the Comedia dell'arteSeptember 2021. Ever since then, the love for the craft became the guiding light in his life.

[[Geopolitics]]

CATEGORIES: Geography, Politics

Geopolitics is the study of how a country's geography (location, terrain, land size, climate, soil and raw materials) affect its foreign, economic and military policy. The word geopolitics comes from the words "geography" and "politics". 

[[Goji]]

CATEGORIES: Fruits, Nightshades

Goji, goji berry or wolfberry is the fruit of Lycium barbarum  and Lycium chinense. These are two very closely related species of boxthorn in the family Solanaceae (which also includes the potato, tomato, eggplant, deadly nightshade, chili pepper, and tobacco). The two species are native to Asia.

[[Alfredo Alcón]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2014 deaths, Argentine stage actors, Argentine movie actors, Actors from Buenos Aires

Alfredo Félix Alcón (alˈfɾeðo alˈkon; 3 March 1930 – 11 April 2014) was an Argentine theatre and movie actor. Alcón born in Buenos Aires. Widely considered one of the best, one of the most important and most acclaimed Argentine actors. 

He worked in more than 50 movies. His first movie was, El amor nunca muere (Love Never Dies), in 1955.

He died in Buenos Aires at the age of 84 from a respiratory illness.

[[Jesse Winchester]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2014 deaths, American activists, American country musicians, American folk musicians, American guitarists, American songwriters, Canadian musicians, Deaths from bladder cancer, Cancer deaths in the United States, Musicians from Louisiana, Musicians from Memphis, Tennessee

James Ridout Winchester (May 17, 1944 – April 11, 2014) known as Jesse Winchester, was an American musician and songwriter. He was known for being a Vietnam War activist. To avoid going to the war, he moved to Canada. He became a Canadian citizen in 1973, gained amnesty in the U.S. in 1977 and resettled there in the U.S. in 2002.

He recorded many songs with many musical artists. Some of them included Patti Page, Elvis Costello, Jimmy Buffett, Joan Baez, Anne Murray, Reba McEntire, The Everly Brothers and Emmylou Harris.

Winchester died at his home in Charlottesville, Virginia from bladder cancer, aged 69.

Jean Omer Beriziky (born 9 September 1950) is a Malagasy politician and diplomat. He was the Prime Minister of Madagascar from 2011 to 2014. He was elected in 2011.

[[Nandu Bhende]]

Sadanand Atmaram "Nandu" Bhende (नंदू भेंडे; c. 1956 – 11 April 2014) was an Indian musician, singer-songwriter and actor. He was best known for being a member of bands such as Nandu Bhende Band, Savage Encounter, The Brief Encounter and Velvette Fogg. He performed mostly under blues, pop, rock, and soul music genres.

Bhende died from a heart attack on 11 April 2014 in Mumbai, Maharashtra.

[[Didier Ratsiraka]]

Vice Admiral Didier Ratsiraka (4 November 1936 – 28 March 2021) was a Malagasy politician. He was the President of Madagascar from 1975 to 1993 and from 1997 to 2002. He was in exile from 2009 to 2011.

Ratsiraka died on 28 March 2021 in Antananarivo, Madagascar from the influenza at the age of 84.

[[Albert Zafy]]

Zafy died on 13 October 2017 at a hospital in Saint-Pierre, Réunion in France of a stroke at the age of 90.

Hery Martial Rakotoarimanana Rajaonarimampianina (born November 6, 1958) is a Malagasy politician. He was the 5th President of Madagascar from January 2014 until his resignation in September 2018.

[[Riina Gerretz]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2014 deaths, Deaths from disease, Estonian musical entertainers, European pianists

Riina Gerretz (8 July 1939 – 22 March 2014) was an Estonian pianist. She was best known for performing with artists such as Georg Ots, Tiit Kuusik, Hendrik Krumm, Ivo Kuusk, Anu Kaal, Margarita Voites, Jüri Gerretz, Ivo Juul, Yolanda Hernandez, Artur Rinne, Hannes Altrov, Pille Lill and Heidy Tamme. She worked mostly in her native Estonia as well as Finland. During her life, she had the surnames Põder (1939–1958),  Villum (1958–1961), Mikiver (1969–1971), Viljanen 1983–2002, Gerretz (until 2014).

Gerretz died after a long illness on 22 March 2014 in Tallinn. She was 74 years old.

Philibert Tsiranana (18 October 1912 – 16 April 1978) was a Malagasy politician and leader. He served as the first President of Madagascar from 1959 to 1972.

He died in Paris from a heart attack, aged 73.

[[Sirp]]

Sirp is the only cultural newspaper published in Estonia. It was first published on 5 October 1940. Until 2013, it was released in black and white.

[[Jerry Tarkanian]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2015 deaths, Deaths from respiratory failure, College basketball coaches, National Basketball Association coaches, Sportspeople from Ohio

Jerry Esther Tarkanian (August 8, 1930–February 11, 2015), also known as "Tark the Shark", was an American college basketball coach. Tarkanian was one of the most successful coaches in college basketball history, most notably at UNLV. He was a coach for the San Antonio Spurs from 1992 to 1993.

Tarkanian was born in Euclid, Ohio. On February 11, 2015, Tarkanian died at the age of 84 in Las Vegas, where he had been hospitalized days earlier after "difficulty breathing", aged 84.

[[Percy Lavon Julian]]

CATEGORIES: 1899 births, 1975 deaths, American chemists, Cancer deaths in the United States, Deaths from liver cancer, People from Montgomery, Alabama

Percy Lavon Julian (April 11, 1899 – April 19, 1975) was an American research chemist and a well known scientist in the chemical synthesis of medicinal drugs from plants. His works would lead to the invention of birth control pills. He was born in Montgomery, Alabama. 

Julian died in Waukegan, Illinois from liver cancer, aged 76.

[[La Wantzenau]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Bas-Rhin

La Wantzenau is a commune in the Bas-Rhin department, Alsace, France. It is close to Strasbourg. There are many Alsatian-style houses left in La Wantzenau. There are also modern houses.

[[Ill (France)]]

CATEGORIES: Rivers of France, Grand Est

The Ill is a river in France that flows through the plain of Alsace. It is an important left tributary of the Rhine river and the main river of Alsace. It flows through the Haut-Rhin and the Bas-Rhin departments in the Grand Est region.

The Chicago Public Library (CPL) is the public library system that serves the City of Chicago in the U.S. state of Illinois. It has over 80 libraries in the city. The system was made in 1873.

[[Chicago Public Schools]]

CATEGORIES: Chicago, Illinois, Schools in Illinois

Chicago Public Schools (CPS) is a system of public schools in the city of Chicago. It is the third largest school district in the United States. CPS reported having 681 schools including 472 elementary schools, 106 high schools, 96 charter schools, and 7 contract schools. The current interim superintendent is Dr. Janice K. Jackson since December 2017.

[[Englewood, New Jersey]]

Englewood is a city in southeastern Bergen County, New Jersey. It was established as a city in 1899. About 27,150 people live in Englewood. Actors John Travolta and Richard Lewis were born in Englewood. 

[[Vladimir Ivashko]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 1994 deaths, Disease-related deaths in Russia, Soviet politicians, Ukrainian politicians

Vladimir Antonovich Ivashko (Russian language: Влади́мир Анто́нович Ива́шко 28 October 1932 – 13 November 1994) was a Ukrainian politician. He was the leader of the Soviet Union for a short time. He became the leader in 1991. He ruled for five days until his political party was declared politically impotent and on 29 August 1991 it was banned.

Ivashko died from an "undisclosed long-illness" in Moscow, aged 62.

[[Pietro Ingrao]]

CATEGORIES: 1915 births, 2015 deaths, Civil servants, Communist politicians, Italian communists, Italian journalists, Politicians from Lazio

Pietro Ingrao (March 30, 1915 – September 27, 2015) was an Italian politician, journalist and former partisan. He had been, for many years, a senior figure in the Italian Communist Party (PCI). He served as President of the Chamber of Deputies from June 5, 1976 to July 19, 1979.

Ingrao was born in Lenola, Italy. He died on September 27, 2015 at the age of 100 in Rome.

[[Pairi Daiza]]

Pairi Daiza (before Paradisio) is a private-owned property that has 55 hectares. It is a zoo and a botanical garden open to the public in Hainaut, Belgium. It has more than 55 acres. In this zoo there are approximately 5,000 animals. Pairi Daiza is owned by Pairi Daiza Belgium SA.

The parks has many different animal species. It also has many different activities and attractions for children.

[[Latin School of Chicago]]

CATEGORIES: Buildings and structures in Chicago, Illinois, Schools in Illinois, 1888 establishments in the United States, 1880s establishments in Illinois

The Latin School of Chicago is a private elementary, middle, and high school in Chicago. The school was founded in 1888 by Mabel Slade Vickery. Latin School of Chicago is the oldest independent day school in the city of Chicago. Nancy Reagan studied at the Latin School.

[[Euclid, Ohio]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Ohio

Euclid is a city in Cuyahoga County, Ohio. It is near Cleveland. It has a population of 48,920 people. It was made a city in 1930.

[[Clovis point]]

CATEGORIES: Tools, North America

Clovis points are the characteristic spear-heads used by the North American Clovis culture. They date from about 13,500 years ago. They are called after the city of Clovis, New Mexico, where examples were first found in 1929.

To the right is a typical Clovis point. The length is 4–20 cm/1.5–8 inches, width: 2.5–5 cm/1–2 inches. The sides are parallel to convex, and show careful pressure flaking along the blade edge. The back end of the blade and base are shaped for hafting (attaching) to a wooden spear or knife-handle. 

[[Kingdom of Sardinia]]

CATEGORIES: 1324 establishments, 1861 disestablishments, Former monarchies in Italy, House of Savoy, 1320s establishments in Europe, Establishments in Italy, 1860s disestablishments in Italy

The Kingdom of Sardinia was a monarchy that ruled the Italian island of Sardinia. It was established in 1324. It was given to the House of Habsburg. They were eventually forced to give it to the House of Savoy. Since the House of Savoy also ruled Piedmont, the Kingdom was sometimes referred to as Sardinia-Piedmont. The Savoy family ruled from 1720 till 1861 when Italy officially united itself. Under the Savoy family, the capital of the state was Turin. The territory also included the city and surrounding land of Genoa. In Italian it was known as the Regno di Sardegna.

The kingdom was originally made up of the islands of Corsica and Sardinia. Sovereignty over both of those was claimed by the Popes. While under Spanish rule, the state was ruled by viceroys.

[[Brita Koivunen]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2014 deaths, Finnish singers, Jazz musicians, People from Helsinki

Brita Koivunen-Einiö (31 August 1931 – 12 April 2014) was a Finnish jazz and schlager singer. Some of her most famous songs include "Suklaasydän", "Sävel rakkauden" and "Mamma, tuo mies minua tuijottaa" all from the 1950s. She was born in Helsinki.

Koivunen died on 12 April 2014 in Helsinki, aged 82.

[[Bangladesh–Laos relations]]

Bangladesh–Laos relations refer to the bilateral relations between Bangladesh and Laos. Diplomatic relations between the two countries were officially started in 1988. Laos also supports Bangladesh getting observer status in ASEAN.

[[Norman Girvan]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2014 deaths, Accidental deaths from falls, Economists, Educators, Jamaican politicians

Norman P. Girvan (1941 – 9 April 2014) was a Jamaican economist, educator, and politician. He was Secretary General of the Association of Caribbean States from 2000 until 2004. He was born in Saint Andrew Parish, Surrey County.

Girvan suffered a fall in Dominica sometime in early 2014. He died on 9 April 2014 in Cuba, aged 72.

[[Michael Sheen]]

CATEGORIES: 1969 births, Living people, Officers of the Order of the British Empire, People from Newport, Welsh movie actors, Welsh stage actors, Welsh television actors, Welsh voice actors

Michael Christopher Sheen OBE (born 5 February 1969) is a Welsh actor. He was first known as a stage actor and appeared in plays such as Romeo and Juliet (1992), Don’t Fool With Love (1993), Peer Gynt (1994), The Seagull (1995), The Homecoming (1997) and Henry V (1997). He soon became a screen actor and had many roles in movies such as The American President (1995), The Deal (2003), The Queen (2006), Frost/Nixon (2008), The Twilight Saga: New Moon (2009), The Damned United (2009), Unthinkable (2010), Alice in Wonderland (2010), Tron: Legacy (2010), Beautiful Boy (2010), The Special Relationship (2010) and The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn – Part 2 (2012).

Sheen was born in Newport. He was in a relationship with English actress Kate Beckinsale from 1995 until 2003. They have a daughter, Lily Mo Sheen (born 1999 in London). In mid-2019 Sheen announced that he and his partner, Anna Lundberg, were expecting their first child together. The couple's daughter Lyra was born on 23 September 2019.

[[Apple Jacks]]

CATEGORIES: Breakfast cereals

Apple Jacks is a type of breakfast cereal made by the cereal maker Kellogg's. It has the flavor of apples and cinnamon. The cereal was invented by William Thilly and was introduced in 1965 as "Apple O's". Kellogg's Apple Jacks introduced "Cinnamon Jacks", a multi-grain cinnamon flavored cereal in 2013.

[[Esmeraldas River]]

CATEGORIES: Rivers of Ecuador

The Esmeraldas River is a river in northwestern Ecuador. It flows into the Pacific Ocean at the city of Esmeraldas. Among its tributaries is the Guayllabamba River which drains Quito.

[[Zarumilla River]]

CATEGORIES: Rivers of Ecuador, Rivers of Peru

The Zarumilla River is a river in South America. It marks the border between Peru and Ecuador. It is named after the Peruvian town of Zarumilla.

[[Tumbes River]]

CATEGORIES: Rivers of Ecuador, Rivers of Peru

The Tumbes River (Río Tumbes or Río Túmbez in Peru; Río Puyango in Ecuador), is a river in South America. The river's sources are located between Ecuadorian El Oro and Loja provinces. It borders Ecuador and Peru.

[[Pastaza River]]

CATEGORIES: Rivers of Ecuador

The Pastaza (formerly known as the Sumatara) is a large tributary to the Marañón River in the northwestern Amazon Basin of South America. It is in Ecuador.

[[List of Thomson MRT Line station names]]

CATEGORIES: Mass Rapid Transit (Singapore) stations, Rail transport lists

The Land Transport Authority (LTA) began conducting a public consultation exercise over the internet as well as through survey forms to gather public feedback on the naming of stations for the Thomson Line. Public consultation to source names for all the stations was held from 8 January 2013 to 17 February 2013. Three names for each station were shortlisted for public voting from 23 May 2013 to 17 June 2013.

[[Pinwheel galaxy]]

CATEGORIES: Galaxies

The Pinwheel galaxy (Messier 101, M101 or NGC 5457) is a face-on unbarred spiral galaxy in the constellation of Ursa Major, the Great Bear.

The galaxy is 21 million light-years (six megaparsecs) away from us. It was  first discovered by Pierre Méchain on March 27 1781. Charles Messier verified its position and included it in the Messier Catalogue as one of the last entries.

In 2006, NASA and the ESA released a very detailed image of the Pinwheel Galaxy, which was the largest and most detailed image of a galaxy by the Hubble Space Telescope at the time. The image was composed from 51 individual exposures, plus some extra ground-based photos.

[[Michael Fabricant]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, Living people, Conservative MPs (UK), Jewish British politicians, Members of the British House of Commons for English constituencies

Michael Louis David Fabricant (born 12 June 1950) is a British Conservative Party politician. He was the Member of Parliament for Mid Staffordshire from 1992-1997. He has been the MP for Lichfield since 1997. 

[[Bittern]]

CATEGORIES: Ciconiiformes

Bitterns are waterbirds, living mostly in freshwater sites. They are a type of heron, wading birds in the family Ardeidae. They are shorter-necked, and more secretive than other herons.  Most of them have good camouflage amongst the reeds where they make their nests.

Bitterns form a monophyletic subfamily of the herons, the Botaurinae.

Bitterns usually frequent reedbeds and similar marshy areas, and feed on amphibians, reptiles, insects, and fish. Unlike the similar storks, ibises, and spoonbills, herons and bitterns fly with their necks retracted, not outstretched.

They were called hæferblæte in Old English; the word "bittern" came to English from Old French.

Bitterns are in three genera. The genus Ixobrychus contains mainly small species. The genus Botaurus has the larger bitterns. There is a single species in a third genus, Zebrilus. The distribution of bitterns is pretty much worldwide.

[[Peter Liechti]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 births, 2014 deaths, Swiss movie directors, Swiss movie producers, People from St. Gallen

Peter Liechti (8 January 1951 – 6 April 2014) was a Swiss movie director. He directed over 100 Swiss-German movies. He was nominated for many awards. 

Most of his movies were shown at the Berlin International Film Festival (BIFF). Recently, he was awarded an honorary awards at the BIFF in 2013. He was born in St. Gallen, Switzerland.

Liechti died on 6 April 2014, aged 63.

[[Elmwood, Illinois]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Illinois

Elmwood is a city in Peoria County, Illinois. It is near the city of Peoria. 

[[Hockey Night in Canada]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 establishments in North America, 1950s television series, 1960s television series, 1970s television series, 1980s Canadian television series, 1990s Canadian television series, 2000s Canadian television series, 2010s Canadian television series, Canadian television series, National Hockey League, Radio programs, Sports television series, 1930s establishments in Canada

Hockey Night in Canada is a branding that is used for presentations of the National Hockey League (NHL) by CBC Sports. It started in 1931 on the CNR Radio network. It debuted on television on October 11, 1952. It has different segments during intermissions and between games including Don Cherry's Coach's Corner. 

On November 26, 2013, it was announced by the NHL that they had reached a 12-year, $5.2 billion deal with Rogers Communications for exclusive television and digital rights to all their national NHL broadcasts starting at the beginning of the 2014-15 season.

[[Behavioral economics]]

CATEGORIES: Socioeconomics, Economic theories

Behavioral economics is a smaller part of economics that combines what we know about psychology with what we know about economics. Normally, economics does not consider the way humans actually think, but instead, simplifies decision-making to make economic models easier to understand. However, this is not a complete picture of how the world, and economics, really works.  Normally, economists assume people are rational, meaning they make good decisions at the right times using all information. In real life, people do not do this. They are subject to problems with self-control, problems with time, and make different choices depending on how decisions are presented to them. Behavioral economists look at the world given problems and limitations that result when real humans are faced with decisions.

[[Tropical Storm Thelma]]

CATEGORIES: Tropical cyclones in Asia, 1991 in Asia, 20th century in the Philippines, 20th century in Vietnam

Tropical Storm Thelma was a 1991 tropical storm. Its winds were near 45-50 mph. It killed between 5,000 and 8,000 people in the Philippines. It hit Negros Occidental, Leyte Island, and Vietnam. The storm caused also about $28 million in damage.

After this, the name Thelma was not used for tropical storms. It was replaced by Teresa.

[[Jos Chabert]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2014 deaths, Alderman of Belgium, Brussels-Capital Region politicians, Christelijke Volkspartij politicians, Christen-Democratisch en Vlaams politicians, Disease-related deaths in Belgium, Flemish politicians, Government ministers of Belgium, People from Brussels-Capital Region

Jozef P. A. "Jos" Chabert (16 March 1933 – 9 April 2014) was a Belgian politician for Christen-Democratisch en Vlaams (Christian Democratic and Flemish; CD&V). He was a Minister of State from 24 November 2009 until his death. Before this, he was a member of the Parliament of the Brussels-Capital Region. He was born in Etterbeek, Brussels-Capital Region.

From 1965 to 1976 he was an alderman of Meise.

Chabert died on 9 April 2014 in Brussels, aged 81.

Emilee Wallace (born September 19, 1989) is an American actress.

[[Fred Kida]]

CATEGORIES: 1920 births, 2014 deaths, American cartoonists, American comics artists, Deaths from natural causes, People from New York City

Fred Kida (December 12, 1920 – April 3, 2014) was an American comic book and comic strip artist. He was best known for the 1940s aviator hero Airboy and his antagonist and sometime ally Valkyrie during the Golden Age of Comic Books. He was born in Brooklyn, New York City, New York.

Kida died from natural causes on April 3, 2014, aged 93.

[[Gene Kiniski]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2010 deaths, Canadian movie actors, Canadian professional wrestlers, Cancer deaths in the United States, Deaths from brain cancer, Former WWE wrestlers, Sportspeople from Edmonton

Eugene Nicholas "Gene" Kiniski (November 23, 1928 – April 14, 2010) was a Canadian professional wrestler and actor. He became one of the first World Champions in professional wrestling to have a former background in football, after Bronko Nagurski. Kiniski is best known for his time in many different NWA-owned territories where he won multiple championships.

Before starting his wrestling career, Kiniski played football with the Edmonton Eskimos of the Canadian Football League (CFL). On his team, Kiniski was joined by future professional wrestlers Wilbur Snyder and Joe Blanchard. Al Oeming and Stu Hart were at the Eskimos training camp when Kiniski was trying out for the team. Kiniski had a lengthy stint in the World Wide Wrestling Federation (WWWF) in 1964. During his time in the WWWF, Kiniski had matches against Bruno Sammartino and they had a match at Madison Square Garden on November 16, 1964. After he Kiniski thought he had pinned Sammartino on the second fall, he took the championship and left. He was counted out be kept the championship until they had a rematch on December 14.

On April 4, 2010, Jim Ross announced on his blog that Kiniski had "taken a turn for the worse and is battling to stay alive. 'Big Thunder's' cancer has spread to his brain and some speculate that is just a matter of time (before he dies)" Kiniski died on April 14, 2010 in Blaine, Washington.

[[Harry Melling]]

CATEGORIES: 1989 births, Actors from London, British child actors, English movie actors, English television actors, Living people

Harry Edward Melling (born 13 March 1989) is an English actor. He is best known for playing Dudley Dursley in the Harry Potter films. 

[[Scott Walker (singer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2019 deaths, Cancer deaths in London, American record producers, American singer-songwriters, Musicians from Ohio

Scott Walker (born Noel Scott Engel; January 9, 1943 – March 22, 2019) was an American-born British singer and record producer. He was born in Hamilton, Ohio. He became famous as the lead singer of the pop group The Walker Brothers in the 1960s. After The Walkers Brothers, broke up Walker released albums on his own. Walker was signed to 4AD Records. From 1965, he lived in the United Kingdom. He was an only child. On February 25, 2009, there was a tribute concert to Walker's music in Los Angeles.

Walker died at the age of 76 in London on March 22, 2019 from cancer.

[[Fine Wind, Clear Morning]]

CATEGORIES: 19th century paintings

Fine Wind, Clear Morning (also known as South Wind, Clear Sky and Red Fuji) is a woodblock print made by Hokusai. 

The art work was printed somewhere between 1830 and 1832 which was during the Edo period. It is the second print in the series, Thirty-six Views of Mount Fuji. It shows that in early autumn when the wind is southerly and when the sky is clear, the rising sun can turn Mount Fuji red.

[[Fred Ho]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 births, 2014 deaths, American activists, American composers, American jazz musicians, American playwrights, American saxophonists, Bandleaders, Cancer deaths in the United States, Deaths from colorectal cancer, People from Palo Alto, California, Writers from California

Fred Ho (侯维翰 Hóu Wéihàn; born Fred Wei-han Houn; August 10, 1957 – April 12, 2014) was an American jazz baritone saxophonist, composer, bandleader, playwright, writer, and social activist. He was known for his place in the African-American and Asian-American music movement. He was born in Palo Alto, California.

Ho died after a long battle with colorectal cancer at his home in Brooklyn, New York City. He was 56.

Alton Towers is a theme park in Staffordshire, England. It is near the town Alton.

It has seven large roller coasters and three smaller roller coasters.

Scott Mitchell Putesky (April 28, 1968 – October 22, 2017), more famously known as Daisy Berkowitz, was an American musician. He was the guitarist for Marilyn Manson until 1996.

Putesky met Brian Warner at a party in 1989. They started Marilyn Manson & the Spooky Kids. He left the band on May 8, 1996.

In March 2013, he  joined with THEE PAUSE, to form "The Daisy Kids".

[[Rolf Brem]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2014 deaths, Disease-related deaths in Switzerland, Illustrators, Swiss sculptors, People from Lucerne

Rolf Brem (12 February 1926 – 11 April 2014) was a Swiss graphic artist. He was best known as a draftsman, sculptor and illustrator. Many of his sculptures are on display all over Switzerland in public and art galleries. He was born in Lucerne.

Brem died on 11 April 2014 in Meggen, Canton of Lucerne, aged 88.

[[Palaeoclimatology]]

CATEGORIES: Climate change, Geology

Palaeoclimatology (or paleoclimatology) is the study of changes in climate over the entire history of Earth. Modern interest in climate change has caused a great increase in the climates of the past.

The climates of the past can only be studied by proxy. Data is got from rocks, sediments, ice and tree rings, corals, shells and microfossils. These records are used to work out the past states of the Earth's climate and its atmospheric system.

Studies of past changes in the life and ecosystems of the past may throw a light on the present. An example is the effect of climate on mass extinctions and the recovery of life after those extinctions.

Ground tissue is the name for a number of different kinds of tissue of plants. These kinds are usually classified by looking at the cell walls. There are three different main kinds:

[[Delegation (band)]]

[[Jelly bean]]

CATEGORIES: Candy

Jelly beans or jellybeans are a bean-shaped candy. They have a gel inside in a soft candy shell. They can come in many different flavors. They were created by William Schrafft and were first introduced in 1861. Schrafft wanted people to send the jelly beans that he made to soldiers during the American Civil War. 

[[Wall Street (1987 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1987 crime movies, 1987 drama movies, 1980s crime drama movies, 20th Century Fox movies, American crime drama movies, English-language movies, Manhattan in fiction, Movies directed by Oliver Stone, Movies set in New York City, Trading movies

Wall Street is a 1987 American crime drama movie directed by Oliver Stone. It stars Michael Douglas, Charlie Sheen, Daryl Hannah, Martin Sheen, Eli Wallach, Terence Stamp, and Hal Holbrook. It was released on December 11, 1987 to very positive reviews.

It was followed by a sequel, Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps.

The Fog is a 1980 American horror movie directed by John Carpenter. It is set in California. It stars Adrienne Barbeau, Jamie Lee Curtis, Tom Atkins, Janet Leigh, and Hal Holbrook. It was released to positive reviews on February 1, 1980.

A remake was made in 2005.

Mark Twain Tonight is a one man play starring Hal Holbrook as Mark Twain. His first performance as Twain was in 1954 in a college in Pennsylvania. Holbrook won a Tony Award for his performance as Twain. During this play, Holbrook tells some of Twain's stories or give some jokes about Twain's life.

[[Ernesto Laclau]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2014 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Argentine academics, Argentine scientists, People from Buenos Aires

Ernesto Laclau (laˈklau; 6 October 1935 – 13 April 2014) was an Argentine political theorist. He was a post-Marxist. His career began in 1986 as a professor at the University of Essex. He was born in Buenos Aires.

Laclau died of a heart attack in Seville, Spain, aged 78.

[[Harvey Pekar]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2010 deaths, American comics writers, American television personalities, American music critics, Drug-related accidental deaths in the United States, People with cancer, Writers from Cleveland, Ohio

Harvey Lawrence Pekar (ˈ; October 8, 1939 – July 12, 2010) was an American comic book writer, music critic and media personality. He is best known for his autobiographical American Splendor comic series. 

In 2003, the series inspired a well-received movie version of the same name.

Pekar was born in Cleveland, Ohio. He suffered from prostate cancer and clinical depression. He died in Cleveland Heights, Ohio from an accidental overdose of antidepressants fluoxetine and bupropion, aged 70.

[[Economic Recovery Tax Act of 1981]]

CATEGORIES: 1981 in the United States, Presidency of Ronald Reagan

The Economic Recovery Tax Act of 1981, also known as the ERTA or "Kemp-Roth Tax Cut", was a federal law signed into law in the United States in 1981. 

It was an act "to amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1954 to encourage economic growth through reductions in individual income tax rates, the expensing of depreciable property, incentives for small businesses, and incentives for savings, and for other purposes". 

[[Tax Reform Act of 1986]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 in the United States, Presidency of Ronald Reagan

The U.S. Congress passed the Tax Reform Act of 1986 (TRA) to simplify the income tax code, broaden the tax base and take away many tax shelters and other preferences. It was part of a set of bills known as the "Reagan tax cuts".

[[An American Life]]

CATEGORIES: 1990 books, Ronald Reagan, Autobiographies

An American Life is the 1990 autobiography by former American President Ronald Reagan. It was released almost two years after Reagan left office. The book reached number eight on The New York Times Best Seller list.

[[Liberal conservatism]]

CATEGORIES: Political philosophy, Conservatism

Liberal conservatism is a political ideology that combines elements of conservatism and economic liberalism. Liberal conservatives believe in the free market and laissez-faire economic policies combined with traditional conservative values, such as the belief in natural inequality, the importance of religion, and the value of traditional morality. In a way, liberal conservatism is the opposite of classical liberalism, a belief that supports both economic and individual freedom.

This term should not be confused for conservative liberalism, which is an offshoot of liberalism, not conservatism.

[[Conservative liberalism]]

CATEGORIES: Political philosophy, Liberalism

Conservative liberalism is a political ideology that can be best described as representing the right-wing of the liberal ideology. Conservative liberalism is a more positive and less radical version of classical liberalism. For example, the People's Party for Freedom and Democracy, a political party in the Netherlands is a conservative liberal party.

Conservative liberalism should not be confused for liberal conservatism, which is an offshoot of conservatism, not liberalism.

[[Brian Harradine]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2014 deaths, Deaths from stroke, Disease-related deaths in Australia, Independent politicians in Australia, Politicians from South Australia

Richard William Brian Harradine (9 January 1935 – 14 April 2014) was an Australian politician. He served as an independent member of the Australian Senate, from 1975 to 2005. He represented the state of Tasmania. He was the longest-serving independent federal politician in Australian history and a Father of the Senate.

Harradine died in Tasmania, Australia from a stroke, aged 79.

[[Economic liberalism]]

CATEGORIES: Political philosophy, Liberalism

Economic liberalism is a political ideology based on strong support for a market economy, private property in the means of production and opposition to government intervention in the economy, e.g. opposition to public ownership and opposing the regulation of industries. Economic liberals believe in the free market and laisse faire economic policies.

[[Philadelphia, Mississippi]]

Philadelphia is a city and a county seat of Neshoba, Mississippi, Mississippi, United States.  The population was 7,477 at the 2010 census.

[[List of WWE Champions]]

CATEGORIES: Lists of professional wrestlers, World Wrestling Entertainment championships

This is the title history of the WWE Championship. The title was introduced in 1963 by the then-World Wide Wrestling Federation (WWWF). It is recognized as the top championship in the WWE.

The wrestler with the most reigns as World Heavyweight champion is John Cena with 13. Ric Flair and John Cena hold the most recognized World Heavyweight championships, across multiple companies, tied with 16. The longest reigning champion is Bruno Sammartino, holding the championship for 7 years, 8 months, and 1 day from May 17, 1963, to January 18, 1971. The current champion is Bobby Lashley, who is in his 1st reign as champion.

[[Rafał Sznajder]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 births, 2014 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Disease-related deaths in Bulgaria, Fencers, Polish sportspeople

Rafał Jerzy Sznajder (13 October 1972 – 13 April 2014) was a Polish fencer. He competed in three Summer Olympic Games (1996, 2000 and 2004). He won a bronze medal at both the 1997 and 2001 World Fencing Championships. He was born in Będzin.

Sznajder died from a heart attack on 13 April 2014 in Plovdiv, Bulgaria. He was 41.

Diamanda Galás (born August 29, 1955) is an American avant-garde artist.

Galás was born and raised in San Diego, California, to Greek Orthodox parents. In 1982 her first album was released. In 1988 Galás joined ACT UP. In 1996 a book she wrote called The Shit of God was published. In 2005 Galás was given the Demetrio Stratos International Career Award.

[[Rossiyane]]

CATEGORIES: European people, Russia

Rossiyane (россияне) is a word that refers to citizens of Russia, that is, people holding a Russian passport. It is mean to differentiate between Russians as ethnicity, and includes Tatars, Bashkirs, Chuvash people, Chechens, etc. Rossiyane have a common history and share a common Russia-related culture.
