[[Aragón (river)]]

CATEGORIES: Rivers of Spain

The Aragón River (Río Aragón; Aragon Ibaia) is a river in northern Spain, one of the left-hand tributaries of the river Ebro.

The river gave its name to the historic Kingdom of Aragon and, then, to the modern Autonomous Community of Aragón.

[[Forêt de la Robertsau]]

CATEGORIES: Forests of France, Grand Est

The Forêt de la Robertsau (English: Robertsau Forest) is a forest in Strasbourg and La Wantzenau, France. People go jogging, biking, running and walking there. 

[[Enchanted forest]]

CATEGORIES: Forests, Fictional locations

An enchanted forest is a magical forest described in books. It is usually described in old tales and folklore. Usually the magic forest has bad effects rather than good ones.

[[Sesame Workshop]]

CATEGORIES: American entertainment companies, Non-profit organizations of New York, 1968 establishments in the United States, Cognition, Learning, Sesame Street

Sesame Workshop is a company established in 1968. It was called Children's Television Workshop (CTW) until 2000. The Workshop  is an American non-profit organization for the research and production of educational children's programs.

The Workshop oversaw the production of Sesame Street, a television show for pre-school children from low-income families. Two years were spent, from 1966 to 1968, researching, developing, and raising money for the new show. It was called "one of the most important television developments of the decade".

Sesame Street premiered on PBS in the United States in November 1969.

Co-founder Joan Ganz Cooney said of the CTW model: "From the beginning, we—the planners of the project—designed the show as an experimental research project with educational advisers, researchers, and television producers collaborating as equal partners". She described the collaboration as an "arranged marriage".

[[Justin Marie Bomboko]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2014 deaths, African politicians, Civil servants, Disease-related deaths in Belgium

Justin Marie Bomboko (1928 – 10 April 2014) was a Congolese civil servant. He was the Minister of Foreign Affairs for the Congo. He became minister in 1960. He is often called "The Father of Independence" for the Congolese.

Bomboko died from a long illness in Brussels, Belgium, aged 86.

[[Edna Doré]]

CATEGORIES: 1921 births, 2014 deaths, Actors from Kent, Deaths from emphysema, Disease-related deaths in Sussex, English television actors, People from Bromley

Edna Doré, née Gorring, (31 May 1921 – 11 April 2014) was a British actress. Doré was known for her bit-part roles in situation comedies. She is mostly known for playing the character of Mo Butcher in the BBC soap opera EastEnders (1988–1990). She was born in Bromley, Kent, England.

Doré died from emphysema at her Sussex, England home, aged 92.

[[Vilmos Zsigmond]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2016 deaths, Academy Award winners, American cinematographers, BAFTA Award winners, Hungarian people, Naturalized citizens of the United States

Vilmos Zsigmond, A.S.C. (June 16, 1930 – January 1, 2016) was a Hungarian-American cinematographer. He was known for his work in Close Encounters of the Third Kind. He won an Academy Award and a BAFTA Award during his career.

Zsigmond was born in Szeged, Hungary. He became an American citizen in 1962. Zsigmond died at his home in Big Sur, California at the age of 85.

[[Freeman Dyson]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2020 deaths, Accidental deaths from falls in the United States, Alumni of the University of Cambridge, American academics, American mathematicians, American physicists, English mathematicians, English physicists, Naturalized citizens of the United States, People from Berkshire, People who lost citizenship, Theoretical physicists, Wolf Prize winners, Princeton University faculty

Freeman John Dyson FRS (December 15, 1923 – February 28, 2020) was an English-born-American theoretical physicist and mathematician. He was known for his work in quantum electrodynamics, solid-state physics, astronomy and nuclear engineering. He gained a bachelor degree at the University of Cambridge. In 1957, he became an American citizen.

Dyson was born in Crowthorne, Berkshire, England, the son of George Dyson. Dyson died on February 28, 2020 at a hospital in Princeton, New Jersey from a fall, aged 96.

He won many scientific awards, including the Wolf Prize in Physics in 1981.

[[Harold Stassen]]

CATEGORIES: 1907 births, 2001 deaths, Deaths from natural causes, Governors of Minnesota, Politicians from Saint Paul, Minnesota, 1964 United States presidential candidates, 1968 United States presidential candidates, 1984 United States presidential candidates, 1988 United States presidential candidates, 1992 United States presidential candidates, US Republican Party politicians

Harold Edward Stassen (April 13, 1907 – March 4, 2001) was an American politician. He was a member of the Republican Party.

Stassen was born in West St. Paul, Minnesota. He studied at the University of Minnesota Law School.

He was the 25th Governor of Minnesota. He served as governor from 1939 to 1943. He ran for President of the United States nine times in the Republican primaries from 1944 to 1992 (1944, 1948, 1952, 1964, 1968, 1980, 1984, 1988, and 1992).

Stassen married Esther G. Glewwe in 1929. Their marriage would last until his death in 2001. They had two children; Glenn and Kathleen.

Stassen died in Bloomington, Minnesota from natural causes, aged 93.

[[Alan Cranston]]

CATEGORIES: 1914 births, 2000 deaths, Deaths from natural causes, Journalists from California, People from Palo Alto, California, 1984 United States presidential candidates, United States senators from California, US Democratic Party politicians, 20th-century American politicians, American military personnel of World War II, Stanford University alumni

Alan MacGregor Cranston (June 19, 1914 – December 31, 2000) was an American politician and journalist. He was the United States senator of California. He served as senator from 1969 to 1993. He was a member of the Democratic Party.

Cranston ran for President of the United States in 1984, but lost the Democratic Party primary to Walter Mondale.

Cranston died in Los Altos, California from natural causes, aged 86.

[[Ben Fernandez]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, 2000 deaths, Ambassadors of the United States, Politicians from Kansas, 1980 United States presidential candidates, 1984 United States presidential candidates, 1988 United States presidential candidates, US Republican Party politicians

Ben Fernandez (February 24, 1925 – April 25, 2000) was an American politician, financial consultant, World War II veteran, and special ambassador. He was America's first major-party presidential nominee of an Hispanic origin. He ran as a Republican. He ran for president in 1980, 1984, and in 1988.  First two, he lost to Ronald Reagan and the last to George H. W. Bush during the primaries.

[[Lowell P. Weicker, Jr.]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, Living people, Governors of Connecticut, 1980 United States presidential candidates, US Republican Party politicians

Lowell Palmer Weicker, Jr. (born May 16, 1931) is an American politician. He was the Governor of Connecticut. He served as governor from 1991 to 1995. Weicker was a Republican. He ran for President of the United States in 1980, but lost the primary to Ronald Reagan. 

Weicker, Jr. was born in Paris, France to American parents.

[[Cliff Finch]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 1986 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Disease-related deaths in Mississippi, Governors of Mississippi, 1980 United States presidential candidates, US Democratic Party politicians

Charles Clifton "Cliff" Finch (April 4, 1927 – April 22, 1986) was an American politician. He was the 56th Governor of Mississippi. He served as governor from 1976 to 1980. He was a Democrat. 

He ran for President of the United States in 1980, but lost the primary to Jimmy Carter.

Finch died in Batesville, Mississippi from a heart attack, aged 59.

[[Terry Sanford]]

CATEGORIES: 1917 births, 1998 deaths, Deaths from esophageal cancer, Governors of North Carolina, 1972 United States presidential candidates, 1976 United States presidential candidates, United States senators from North Carolina, US Democratic Party politicians

James Terry Sanford (August 20, 1917 – April 18, 1998) was an American politician and educator. He was the United States senator of North Carolina. He served as senator from 1986 to 1993. He was a Democrat.

Sanford ran for President of the United States in 1976, but lost the primary to Jimmy Carter.

Sanford died in Durham, North Carolina from esophageal cancer, aged 80.

[[Henry M. Jackson]]

CATEGORIES: 1912 births, 1983 deaths, Deaths from aortic aneurysm, People from Everett, Washington, Presidential Medal of Freedom recipients, 1972 United States presidential candidates, 1976 United States presidential candidates, United States senators from Washington, US Democratic Party politicians

Henry Martin "Scoop" Jackson (May 31, 1912 – September 1, 1983) was an American politician. He was the United States senator of Washington. He served as senator from 1953 to 1983. He was a member of the Democratic Party. 

He ran for President of the United States during the presidential elections in 1976, but lost to Jimmy Carter during the primary.

Jackson died in Everett, Washington from an aortic aneurysm, aged 71.

[[Mo Udall]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 United States presidential candidates, 1922 births, 1998 deaths, Deaths from Parkinson's disease, United States representatives from Arizona, US Democratic Party politicians

Morris King "Mo" Udall (June 15, 1922 – December 12, 1998) was an American politician. He was a member of the United States House of Representatives for Arizona's 2nd district. He served as a representative from 1961 to 1991. He was a member of the Democratic Party.

Udall ran for President of the United States in 1976, but lost to Jimmy Carter during the primaries.

Udall died in Washington, D.C. from complications of Parkinson's disease, aged 76.

[[Birch Bayh]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2019 deaths, Deaths from pneumonia, 1976 United States presidential candidates, United States senators from Indiana, US Democratic Party politicians, People from Terre Haute, Indiana

Birch Evans Bayh, Jr. (January 22, 1928 – March 14, 2019) was an American politician. He served as a United States senator of Indiana. He served as senator from 1963 to 1981. He was a member of the Democratic Party. He was born in Terre Haute, Indiana.

He ran for President of the United States in 1976, but lost to Jimmy Carter during the primary. He was known for co-authoring and introducing Title IX to the Senate. 

Bayh authored the twenty-fifth and the twenty-sixth amendments to the United States Constitution. His is the only non-founding father to author two amendments. He also proposed to remove the electoral college and to ratify the Equal Rights Amendment.

Bayh lost his re-election bid in 1980 to future Vice President Dan Quayle with a vote margin of 53.8% to 46.2%.

Bayh's son, Evan, is a former Indiana governor and senator. 

Bayh died on March 14, 2019 in Easton, Maryland from pneumonia, aged 91.

[[Larry Pressler]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, Living people, 1980 United States presidential candidates, United States senators from South Dakota, Independent politicians in the United States

Larry Lee Pressler (born March 29, 1942) is an American politician. He was the United States senator of South Dakota. He served as senator from 1979 to 1997. He was a member of the Republican Party.

Pressler ran for President of the United States in 1980, but lost to Ronald Reagan during the primary. Pressler announced in 2013, that he would run for the senate seat as an Independent. He soon lost the election. 

Pressler was born in Humboldt, South Dakota.

[[Yongle Encyclopedia]]

CATEGORIES: Encyclopedias, Chinese culture

The Yongle Encyclopedia was a Chinese compilation of information. It was ordered by the Ming Dynasty emperor Yongle in 1403, and completed by 1408. It was the world's largest known general encyclopedia at its time, and held this record for six centuries. 

In the Chinese language it is: 永樂大典. This means The Great Canon or Vast Documents of the Yongle Era.

[[Los Altos, California]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in California, Settlements in Santa Clara County, California, Cities in the San Francisco Bay Area

Los Altos is a city in the San Francisco Peninsula around the San Francisco Bay Area, California. It has the population of 28,976 residents.

[[Wayne Morse]]

CATEGORIES: 1900 births, 1974 deaths, Deaths from renal failure, 1960 United States presidential candidates, United States senators from Oregon, Politicians from Wisconsin, People from Madison, Wisconsin, US Democratic Party politicians

Wayne Lyman Morse (October 20, 1900 – July 22, 1974) was an American politician. He was the United States senator of Oregon. He served as senator from 1945 to 1969. He was a member of the Democratic Party.

Morse ran for President of the United States in 1960, but lost the primary to John F. Kennedy.

Morse died in Portland, Oregon from kidney failure, aged 73.

[[Arthur H. Vandenberg]]

CATEGORIES: 1884 births, 1951 deaths, Cancer deaths in Michigan, Politicians from Grand Rapids, Michigan, Presidents pro tempore of the United States Senate, United States senators from Michigan, US Republican Party politicians

Arthur Hendrick Vandenberg (March 22, 1884 – April 18, 1951) was an American politician. Vandenberg was known for being part of the creation of the United Nations with Franklin D. Roosevelt.

Vandenberg was born in Grand Rapids, Michigan. He studied at the University of Michigan.

In 1906, Vandenberg was married to Elizabeth Watson. Watson died in 1917. They had three children. Vandenberg married Hazel Whittaker in 1918. Their marriage lasted until his death in 1951. They had no children. 

He was the United States senator of Michigan. He served as senator from 1928 until his death in 1951. He was also the President pro tempore of the United States Senate from 1947 to 1949.

Vandenberg was a member of the Republican Party. He ran for President of the United States in 1948, but lost the primary to Thomas E. Dewey. 

Vandenberg died in Grand Rapids, Michigan from cancer, aged 67.

[[Doctor Eggman]]

CATEGORIES: Fictional characters introduced in 1991, Sonic the Hedgehog characters, Video game antagonists, Video game bosses, Video game characters in movies

Dr. Ivo "Eggman" Robotnik is the main antagonist of Sonic the Hedgehog. He first appeared in 1991 in the game Sonic the Hedgehog for Sega Mega Drive.

[[Hal Smith (catcher)]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2014 deaths, American baseball players, Disease-related deaths in the United States, Pittsburgh Pirates players, Sportspeople from Arkansas, St. Louis Cardinals players

Harold Raymond "Hal" Smith (June 1, 1931 – April 12, 2014) was an American Major League Baseball catcher. He played for the St. Louis Cardinals from 1956 until 1961 and briefly for the Pittsburgh Pirates in 1965. He was born in Barling, Arkansas.

Smith died on April 12, 2014 in Fort Smith, Arkansas, aged 82. He was outlived by his wife and three children.

[[Megaflood]]

CATEGORIES: Floods

A megaflood is a flood which suddenly releases a huge amount of water. In geomorphology it is sometimes called an outburst flood. At the end of the last ice age, many large floods were caused by the collapse of ice sheets or glaciers which formed the dams of glacial lakes.

Examples of older outburst floods are known from the geological past of the Earth. Landslides, lahars, and volcanic dams can block rivers and create lakes. When the rock or earth barrier collapses, or is eroded, this triggers a flood. Lakes also form behind glacial moraines, which can collapse and create outburst floods.

[[Erik Erikson]]

CATEGORIES: 1902 births, 1994 deaths, American psychologists, Harvard University alumni, Jewish American academics, Jewish American scientists, Jewish German scientists, Jews who converted to Christianity, Naturalized citizens of the United States, People from Frankfurt, Refugees from Nazism, Scientists from Massachusetts

Erik Homburger Erikson (15 June 1902 – 12 May 1994) was a German-born American developmental psychologist and psychoanalyst. Erikson is known for his theory on psychosocial development of human beings. Erikson is also known for coining the phrase identity crisis. His son is Kai T. Erikson, a sociologist.

In 1970, Erikson won a Pulitzer Prize in General Nonfiction and won a U.S. National Book Award in the Philosophy and Religion category, both for Gandhi's Truth.

Erikson died at the Rosewood Manor Nursing Home in Harwich, Massachusetts on 12 May 1994.

[[Lucy (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2014 action movies, 2014 science fiction movies, English-language movies, French action movies, French science fiction movies, German movies, Taiwanese movies, Canadian movies, British action movies, British science fiction movies, American action movies, American science fiction movies, Movies set in China, Movies about drugs, Movies set in Paris, Science fiction action movies, Taipei, Telekinesis in movies, Movies directed by Luc Besson, Movies set in Rome

Lucy is a 2014 French science fiction superhero action movie. It is about street gangs, drugs and changing of the title character to superhuman. It was written and directed by Luc Besson and is set in Taipei. Scarlett Johansson plays Lucy. Morgan Freeman plays Norman.

The movie was released in July 2014 in the United States.

[[Air China Flight 129]]

CATEGORIES: 2002 in Asia, 2000s disasters in Asia, 21st century in South Korea, April events, Aviation disasters in Asia, Aviation disasters in the 2000s

Air China flight 129 is an international scheduled flight from Beijing to Busan. On April 15, 2002, the Boeing 767-2J6ER flying the route crashed into a mountain while trying to land at Busan-Gimhae International Airport. Of the 166 people on the aircraft, 129 were killed. Investigators determined that pilot error was the cause of the crash.

This was the first time an Air China crash killed people. It was also the worst plane crash in South Korea.

[[Lake Mattamuskeet]]

CATEGORIES: Lakes of the United States, Geography of North Carolina

Lake Mattamuskeet is a lake in the U.S. state of North Carolina.

[[Pinehurst Resort]]

CATEGORIES: Buildings and structures in North Carolina, Golf

Pinehurst Resort is a historic golf resort in Pinehurst, North Carolina. It is in the Coastal Plains.

[[Owen Woodhouse]]

CATEGORIES: 1916 births, 2014 deaths, Deaths from natural causes, New Zealand judges, New Zealand lawyers, Military personnel of World War II, Oceanic military people, People from North Island

Lieutenant Commander Sir Arthur Owen Woodhouse ONZ KBE DSC (18 July 1916 – 15 April 2014), better known as Owen Woodhouse, was a New Zealand lawyer, jurist and chair of government commissions. He was a member of the Supreme Court. He later served as President of the Court of Appeal from 1981 until 1986.

Woodhouse was born in Napier and studied at the University of Auckland. During World War II, he served as a lieutenant commander in the Royal New Zealand Naval Volunteer Reserve.

Woodhouse died from natural causes on 15 April 2014 in Auckland, aged 97.

[[Davidson Black]]

CATEGORIES: 1884 births, 1934 deaths, Canadian educators, Canadian scientists, People from Toronto, Canadian physicians

Davidson Black was a Canadian doctor who studied anatomy and anthropology.  In 1927, he led a team that discovered bone fossils from an early species of human beings in China. The fossils were about 750,000 years old. They belonged to the species Sinanthropus pekinensis or Peking Man. He and his team found these fossils near the village of Zhoukoudian, near Beijing.

Black was born in Toronto, Ontario on July 25, 1884.  He graduated from the University of Toronto. In 1921, he became a professor of anatomy in China at Peking Union Medical College.  He died on March 15, 1934.

[[Rhys Darby]]

CATEGORIES: 1974 births, Living people, New Zealand movie actors, New Zealand television actors, People from Auckland, Stand-up comedians

Rhys Montague Darby (born 21 March 1974) is a New Zealand actor and comedian. He is best known for playing Murray Hewitt, the band manager of Flight of the Conchords, in the HBO television series of the same name (2007–2009). He has since appeared in movies such as Yes Man (2008), The Boat That Rocked (2009), Diagnosis: Death (2009), Love Birds (2011), Arthur Christmas (2011), and What We Do in the Shadows (2014).

Darby was born in Auckland. He grew up in the suburb of Pakuranga. He was a soldier in the New Zealand Army. He is married to Rosie Carnahan. The couple have two children.

[[Albert Sidney Johnston]]

CATEGORIES: Confederate Army generals, 1803 births, 1862 deaths

Albert Sidney Johnston (February 2, 1803 – April 6, 1862) was a Confedeate general during the American Civil War. He was born in 1803 in Tennessee. He graduated from the United States Military Academy in 1826. He resigned from the U.S. army in 1834 after his wife died. He then joined the Texas army during the Texas Revolution and continued serving in it after Texas became a republic. In 1840 he resigned from the Texas army and moved to Kentucky.

Johnston rejoined the U.S. army for the Mexican–American War. By 1860 he was in charge of the U.S. army in California. He resigned in May 1861 after Texas joined the Confederate States of America. He was made a four star general in the Confederate army and put in charge of the Confederate units in Kentucky and Tennessee. He was killed at the Battle of Shiloh on April 6, 1862.

[[Brick Mansions]]

CATEGORIES: 2014 movies, 2010s action movies, 2010s crime movies, Canadian movies, Canadian thriller movies, French movies, Movie remakes, Movies set in Detroit, Michigan, Dystopian movies, Movies set in 2018

Brick Mansions is a 2014 French urban crime movie. The movie is about crimes in Detroit and plans to ruin the area. Paul Walker plays Damien Collier.

The movie was released on April 25, 2014. It is a remake of District 13.

[[John Bell Hood]]

CATEGORIES: Confederate Army generals, 1831 births, 1879 deaths

John Bell Hood (1831 – August 30, 1879) was a Confederate army general during the American Civil War. He was born in 1831 in Kentucky. He graduated from the United States Military Academy in 1853. After the Battle of Fort Sumter, he joined the Confederate army as colonel of the 4th Texas Infantry. In February 1862, he became commander of the Texas Brigade as a brigadier general. He became commander of a division in July 1862. He was wounded at the Battle of Gettysburg in July 1863. He was wounded again at the Battle of Chickamauga in September 1863. In late July 1864, he became commander of the Army of Tennessee.

After the war, Hood became a businessman. He married in 1868 and had eleven children. He died in 1879 during a yellow fever epidemic in New Orleans.

[[Brigade]]

CATEGORIES: Military

A brigade is a military unit in an army. Currently in most armies, a brigade is made up of several battalions. Up to World War II, a brigade had several regiments.

A brigade is commanded by a brigadier general, a brigadier, or a colonel.

[[Sportsnet 360]]

CATEGORIES: Canadian television networks

Sportsnet 360 is a Canadian English language cable and satellite television specialty channel. Sportsnet 360 is owned by Rogers Media. They show sports highlights, news, analysis programming as well as live sports coverage with basketball, college/university sports, mixed martial arts, professional wrestling, and soccer. 

The channel was first launched in 1994 and was known as Sportscope. It was relaunched in May 1997 under the name Headline Sports with channel licencing Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission.

The licence was rewritten by the CRTC to allow live sports programming and because of this, as well as legal issues with U.S. cable news channel CNN Headline News which also had a "Headline Sports" segment, the channel became known as The Score Television Network. 

On October 19, 2012, they were acquired by Rogers Media for $167 million. On July 1, 2013, Rogers renamed the channel Sportsnet 360.

[[Claire Denis]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, French educators, Living people, Movie directors from Paris

Claire Denis (born April 21, 1946) is a French movie director. In 1988, the first movie directed by Denis, Chocolat, was released. It was nominated for the Palme d'Or at the Cannes Film Festival.

[[Clarence]]

CATEGORIES: Cartoon Network series, 2014 television series debuts, English-language television programs

Clarence is a cartoon television show aired on the television channel "Cartoon Network".

[[Major general]]

CATEGORIES: Military ranks, Generals

A major general (or two-star general) is a rank in an army. It is between the ranks of lieutenant general and brigadier general. A major general usually commands a division. It comes from the older rank of sergeant major general. The disappearance of the "sergeant" in the title explains the apparently confusing system whereby a lieutenant general outranks a major general (although a major outranks a lieutenant, a lieutenant outranks a sergeant-major.) A Major general is addressed as "general".

[[Caledonian orogeny]]

CATEGORIES: Orogenies, Palaeozoic, Mountains of Norway, Mountains of the United Kingdom, Geography of Greenland, Geography of Scotland

The Caledonian orogeny was a mountain building era. It left its mark in the northern parts of the British Isles, the Scandinavian Mountains, Svalbard, eastern Greenland, northern Europe and the eastern United States.

The events occurred from the Ordovician to early Devonian, roughly 490390 million years ago (mya). It was caused by the closure of the Iapetus Ocean when the continents and lands of Laurentia, Baltica and Avalonia collided.

The Caledonian orogeny is named after Caledonia, the Latin name for Scotland. The name is not used for an absolute period of time: it applies only to the series of mountain-building events.

Part of the mountain chain ended up in modern North America, where it is called the Acadian orogeny (see Appalachian Mountains).

[[Sheila Jeffreys]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, Living people, Australian feminists, Australian LGBT people, Australian writers, Lesbian feminists, LGBT writers

Sheila Jeffreys (born 1948)  is a lesbian feminist activist. She was born in the United Kingdom. 

[[Armando Peraza]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2014 deaths, American jazz musicians, Cuban musicians, Deaths from pneumonia, Infectious disease deaths in the United States, Naturalized citizens of the United States, People from Havana

Armando Peraza (May 30, 1924 – April 14, 2014) was a Cuban-American Latin jazz percussionist. His career began during the 1950s. 

He performed with many professional artists such as Perez Prado, Machito, George Shearing, Charlie Parker, Tito Puente, Cal Tjader, and Carlos Santana. He was born in Havana, Cuba.

Peraza died from pneumonia on April 14, 2014 in San Francisco, California, aged 89.

[[Shirley Chisholm]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2005 deaths, African American politicians, African American writers, American educators, Cardiovascular disease deaths in Florida, Deaths from stroke, 1972 United States presidential candidates, Politicians from Brooklyn, United States representatives from New York, US Democratic Party politicians, Writers from Brooklyn

Shirley Anita St. Hill Chisholm (November 30, 1924 – January 1, 2005) was an American politician, educator, and writer. She was a member of the Democratic Party.

Chisholm was born in Brooklyn, New York City. She studied at Brooklyn College. 

She was a member of the United States House of Representatives for New York's 2nd district. She served as a representative from 1969 to 1983. 

She ran for President of the United States in 1972 as a Democrat. She lost the primary to George McGovern. Chisholm became the first major-party black candidate for President of the United States.

She was married to Conrad Chrisholm. Their marriage ended in divorce. Then she was married to Arthur Hardwick, Jr.. Their marriage would last until his death.

Chisholm died in Ormond Beach, Florida from a stroke. She was 80 years old.

[[Bill Bradley]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, Living people, United States senators from New Jersey, American educators, American basketball players, 2000 United States presidential candidates, Politicians from Missouri, Sportspeople from Missouri, Sportspeople from New Jersey, US Democratic Party politicians

William Warren "Bill" Bradley (born July 28, 1943) is an American politician, basketball player, and educator. He was a member of the Democratic Party.

Bradley was born in Crystal City, Missouri. He studied at Princeton University. 

Bradley served as a United States senator of New Jersey. He served as senator from 1979 to 1997.

He ran for President of the United States in 2000. He withdrew from the race. Al Gore would eventually win the Democratic Party ticket.

Bradley married Ernestine Bradley in 1974. Their marriage ended in divorce in 2007. They had one child. He is currently in a relationship with the director of the Lyndon Baines Johnson Library and Museum.

[[Shane Gibson (musician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1979 births, 2014 deaths, American guitarists, Disease-related deaths in the United States, Musicians from Florida, Musicians from Louisiana

Shane Paul Gibson (February 21, 1979 – April 15, 2014) was an American musician. He was best known as guitarist of Korn and stOrk. He was also a member Jonathan Davis and the SFA and L. Shankar. He was born in Houma, Louisiana and raised in Fort Walton Beach, Florida.

Gibson died due to complications from a blood clotting disorder on April 15, 2014 at a hospital in Birmingham, Alabama. He was 35.

[[Robert S. Kerr]]

CATEGORIES: 1896 births, 1963 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Governors of Oklahoma, United States senators from Oklahoma, US Democratic Party politicians

Robert Samuel Kerr (September 11, 1896 – January 1, 1963) was an American politician and businessman. He was a member of the Democratic Party.

Kerr was born in Ada, Oklahoma. He studied at Oklahoma Baptist University and for a short while at Oklahoma State University.

Kerr served as Governor of Oklahoma. He served as governor from 1943 to 1947. Then, Kerr was the United States senator of Oklahoma. He served as senator from 1949 to 1963.

Kerr ran for President of the United States in 1952. He lost the primary to Adlai Stevenson II. 

Kerr died from a fatal heart attack in Washington, D.C., aged 66.

[[Transcendence (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2014 drama movies, 2014 science fiction movies, American drama movies, American science fiction movies, English-language movies, Dystopian movies

Transcendence is a 2014 American science fiction drama movie directed by Wally Pfister. It is produced by Christopher Nolan. It stars Johnny Depp, Rebecca Hall, Kate Mara, Cillian Murphy, Paul Bettany, and Morgan Freeman.

Transcendence was released in New York City on April 10, 2014. It was released on April 18, 2014 in other cities and countries.

[[Interstellar (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2014 drama movies, 2014 science fiction movies, 2010s adventure movies, Academy Award winning movies, American adventure movies, American drama movies, American epic movies, American science fiction movies, British adventure movies, British drama movies, British science fiction movies, BAFTA Award winning movies, Movies composed by Hans Zimmer, Movies directed by Christopher Nolan, Movies set in Colorado, Movies set in the future, Saturn Award winning movies, Time travel movies, Apocalyptic movies, Dystopian movies

Interstellar is a 2014 British-American epic science fiction movie directed, co-written and produced by Christopher Nolan. It stars Matthew McConaughey, Anne Hathaway, Jessica Chastain, Bill Irwin, Ellen Burstyn, Michael Caine, Mackenzie Foy, Matt Damon, Casey Affleck and John Lithgow. It was released on November 5, 2014.

[[Following]]

CATEGORIES: 1998 crime movies, 1998 thriller movies, 1998 drama movies, 1990s crime thriller movies, 1990s drama thriller movies, 1990s mystery movies, British crime movies, British drama movies, British thriller movies, British mystery movies, Movies directed by Christopher Nolan, English-language movies, Movies about writers, Movies set in London, Movies set in the 1990s

Following is a 1998 British drama thriller movie directed by Christopher Nolan. It stars Jeremy Theobald, Alex Haw, Lucy Russell, and John Nolan. It was released on September 12, 1998. This was Christopher Nolan's first movie. It tells the story of a young man who follows strangers around the streets of London and is drawn into a criminal underworld when he fails to keep his distance.

As Christopher Nolan's debut feature, it was designed to be as inexpensive as possible to make: scenes were heavily rehearsed so that just one or two takes were needed, thus economising on 16 mm film stock, the production's greatest expense, and for which Nolan was paying from his salary. Without expensive professional lighting equipment, Nolan mostly used available light. Apart from writing, directing, and photographing the film, Nolan also helped in editing and production.Instead of fighting against the limitations of the production, Christopher Nolan allowed them to dictate everything from the film’s structure, to its handheld shooting style, to the 16mm film it was shot on.. to black-and-white stock and setting the scene during the day and place the characters next to windows or in natural sunlight as much as possible. Nolan has explained it in a detailed interview with VICE.

[[Memento (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2000 movies, 2000s mystery movies, 2000s thriller movies, American mystery movies, American thriller movies, English-language movies, Film noir, Movies about murderers, Movies about revenge, Movies directed by Christopher Nolan, Mystery thriller movies, Nonlinear narrative movies, American independent movies

Memento is a 2000 American mystery-thriller movie written and directed by Christopher Nolan, and produced by Suzanne and Jennifer Todd. The movie's script was based on a pitch by Jonathan Nolan, who wrote the 2001 story "Memento Mori" from the concept. Guy Pearce stars as a man who, as a result of an injury, has anterograde amnesia (the inability to form new memories) and has short-term memory loss approximately every fifteen minutes. He is searching for the people who attacked him and killed his wife, using an intricate system of Polaroid photographs and tattoos to track information he cannot remember.

The movie is presented as two different sequences of scenes interspersed during the movie: a series in black-and-white that is shown chronologically, and a series of color sequences shown in reverse order (simulating for the audience the mental state of the protagonist). The two sequences meet at the end of the movie, producing one complete and cohesive narrative.

Memento premiered at the 57th Venice International Film Festival on September 5, 2000, and was released in the United States on March 16, 2001. It was acclaimed by critics, who praised its nonlinear narrative structure and motifs of memory, perception, grief, and self-deception, and earned $39.9 million over a $4.5 million budget. Memento received numerous accolades, including Oscar nominations for Best Original Screenplay and Best Film Editing. The movie is now widely regarded as one of Nolan's finest works and one of the best movies of the 2000s. In 2017, the United States Library of Congress deemed the movie and selected it for preservation in the National Film Registry.

[[Mick Staton]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2014 deaths, Disease-related deaths in the United States, United States representatives from West Virginia, US Republican Party politicians

David Michael Staton (February 11, 1940 – April 14, 2014), better known as Mick Staton, was an American politician for the Republican Party. He was a member of the U.S. House of Representatives serving West Virginia's 3rd District from 1981 until 1983. He was born in Parkersburg, West Virginia.

Staton died on April 14, 2014 in Winchester, Virginia, aged 74. He was outlived by his wife and two adult children.

[[Insomnia (2002 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2002 movies, American thriller movies, Movies directed by Christopher Nolan

Insomnia is a 2002 American thriller movie directed by Christopher Nolan and written by Hillary Seitz. A remake of the 1997 Norwegian movie of the same name, it stars Al Pacino, Robin Williams, Hilary Swank, Maura Tierney, Martin Donovan, Nicky Katt, and Paul Dooley. The movie revolves around two Los Angeles homicide detectives investigating a murder in Nightmute, Alaska.

Released on May 24, 2002, Insomnia grossed over $113 million worldwide against a production budget of $46 million, and received critical praise for its screenplay, cinematography, direction, and acting, particularly Pacino's and Williams' performances.

[[Marksville, Louisiana]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Louisiana, Parish seats in Louisiana

Marksville is a city in Avoyelles Parish, Louisiana, United States. It has the population of 5,537 residents.

[[Stuart Symington]]

CATEGORIES: 1901 births, 1988 deaths, Cardiovascular disease deaths in Connecticut, United States Secretaries of the Air Force, 1960 United States presidential candidates, United States senators from Missouri, Businesspeople from Missouri, US Democratic Party politicians

William Stuart Symington, Jr. (June 26, 1901 – December 14, 1988) was an American businessman and politician. He was a member of the Democratic Party.

Symington was born in Amherst, Massachusetts. He studied at Yale University.

Symington was the first United States Secretary of the Air Force. He served as secretary from 1947 to 1950. Then he served as the United States senator of Missouri. He served as senator from 1953 to 1976.

Symington ran for President of the United States in 1960. He lost the primary to John F. Kennedy. 

Symington was married to Evelyn Wadsworth. Their marriage would last until her death in 1972. Symington resigned in 1976, four days before his term would end. They had one son, James W. Symington, former member of the United States House of Representatives. His cousin, Fife Symington, served as Governor of Arizona from 1991 through 1997.

Symington died in New Canaan, Connecticut from angina pectoris, aged 87.

[[John W. Byrnes]]

CATEGORIES: 1913 births, 1985 deaths, Cardiovascular disease deaths in the United States, Deaths from stroke, Disease-related deaths in Wisconsin, 1964 United States presidential candidates, United States representatives from Wisconsin, People from Green Bay, Wisconsin, US Democratic Party politicians

John William Byrnes (June 12, 1913 – January 12, 1985) was an American politician. He was a member of the Republican Party. 

Byrnes was born in Green Bay, Wisconsin. He studied at the University of Wisconsin-Madison.

Byrnes served in the Wisconsin Senate for Wisconsin's 2nd district from 1941 to 1945. Byrnes was a member of the United States House of Representatives for Wisconsin's 8th district. He served as a representative from 1945 to 1973.

Byrnes ran for President of the United States in 1964. He lost the primary to Barry M. Goldwater.

Byrnes was married to Barbara Preston. Byrnes died in Marshfield, Wisconsin from a stroke, aged 71.

[[Henry Cabot Lodge Jr.]]

CATEGORIES: 1902 births, 1985 deaths, 1964 United States presidential candidates, United States Ambassadors to the United Nations, United States senators from Massachusetts, US Republican Party politicians

Henry Cabot Lodge, Jr. (July 5, 1902 – February 27, 1985) was an American politician. He was a member of the Republican Party. He served as an ambassador of the United States to West Germany, South Vietnam, and to the United Nations. In 1960, he was Richard Nixon's running mate in the 1960 presidential election. They lost to John F. Kennedy. He ran for President of the United States in 1964, but lost the nomination to Barry Goldwater.

Lodge was born in Nahant, Massachusetts, USA. His father was George Cabot Lodge, a poet. He was the grandson of Senator Henry Cabot Lodge, great-great grandson of Senator Elijah H. Mills, and great-great-great-grandson of Senator George Cabot. His mother was Mathilda Elizabeth Frelinghuysen Davis, the great granddaughter of Senator John Davis. 

He had two siblings: John Davis Lodge (1903–1985), also a politician, and Helena Lodge de Streel (b. 1905).

Lodge attended St. Albans School and graduated from Middlesex School. In 1924, he graduated cum laude from Harvard University.

Lodge died in Beverly, Massachusetts from a long-illness at the age of 82.

[[Hiram Fong]]

CATEGORIES: 1906 births, 2004 deaths, Accidental deaths from falls in the United States, United States senators from Hawaii, 1964 United States presidential candidates, Politicians from Honolulu, Businesspeople from Hawaii, US Republican Party politicians

Hiram Leong Fong (Yau Leong Fong; October 15, 1906 – August 18, 2004) was an American politician and businessman. He was the first United States senator for Hawaii. He served as senator from 1959 to 1977. He was a member of the Republican Party.

Fong ran for President of the United States in 1964. He lost the primary to Barry M. Goldwater. He was the first Asian-American to run for President of the United States. Patsy Mink would follow him as the few Hawaiians to run for President.

Fong died in Kahaluu, Hawaii from complications of a fall, aged 97.

Marshfield is a city in Marathon County and in Wood County, Wisconsin. It has the population of 19,118 residents. 

[[Chris Parnell]]

CATEGORIES: 1967 births, Living people, Actors from Memphis, Tennessee, American movie actors, American stage actors, American stand-up comedians, American television actors, American voice actors, Singers from Memphis, Tennessee

Thomas Christopher "Chris" Parnell (p; born February 5, 1967) is an American actor, voice artist and comedian. He was a cast member on Saturday Night Live from 1998 to 2006 and played the role of Dr. Leo Spaceman on 30 Rock. In animation, he voices Cyril Figgis on the FX series Archer, Jerry Smith on Adult Swim's Rick and Morty and the narrator on the PBS series WordGirl. He also voices "The Progressive Box" in a series of advertisements by the Progressive Corporation.

[[Francis Gary Powers]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 1977 deaths, Aviation deaths in the United States, Burials at Arlington National Cemetery, Prisoners of war, Spies, American aviators, American military people, American inventors, People from Kentucky

Francis Gary Powers (Jenkins, Kentucky August 17, 1929 – Los Angeles, California, August 1, 1977) was an American pilot. He was known for piloting a Central Intelligence Agency U-2 spy plane which was shot down while flying a reconnaissance mission over the Soviet Union. This caused the 1960 U-2 incident, and played a large role in the Cold War.

Powers was held as a prisoner of war in the Soviet Union. On February 10, 1962, Powers was exchanged in a spy swap in Berlin. The exchange was for Soviet KGB Colonel Vilyam Fisher, known as "Rudolf Abel", who had been caught by the FBI and tried and jailed for espionage.  Powers credited his father with the swap idea. When released, Powers's total time in captivity was 1 year, 9 months, and 10 days. 

Powers died in Los Angeles County, California in a helicopter crash, aged 47.

[[Black Coal, Thin Ice]]

In 2014, the movie won the Golden Bear award at the Berlin International Film Festival.

[[ECW Heat Wave]]

CATEGORIES: Extreme Championship Wrestling

ECW Heat Wave was a professional wrestling event that was produced by Extreme Championship Wrestling (ECW). ECW began making it a pay-per-view starting in 1998. It ran from 1994 to 2000.

[[Stuart Hall (presenter)]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, Living people, BBC radio presenters, BBC television presenters, British game show hosts, British prisoners, British sex offenders, Child sexual abusers, English journalists, English radio personalities, English television presenters, People acquitted of rape, People from Derbyshire, Television personalities from Cheshire, Television personalities from Lancashire

James Stuart Hall Jr. (born 25 December 1929) is a British former radio and television presenter. He is a sex offender who is in prison. 

Hall was born in Ashton-under-Lyne, Lancashire, England. He was raised in Hyde, Cheshire and Glossop, Derbyshire. He studied at the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology. 

Hall presented light entertainment show It's a Knockout as well as sport coverage and news on the BBC. He is a lifelong Manchester City F.C. supporter. 

In April 2013, Hall was arrested and charged with having indecently assaulted 13 girls aged between 9 and 17, between 1967 and 1986. He was sentenced to 30 months imprisonment. His trial began at Preston Crown Court on 6 May 2014 for 15 counts of rape and five of indecent assault against two girls that allegedly happened from 1976–1981. He was convicted of two counts of indecent assault but was acquitted of all the other charges. 

== References == 

[[Site of Special Scientific Interest]]

CATEGORIES: Ecology, United Kingdom, Conservation

A Site of Special Scientific Interest (SSSI) is a type of legal conservation given to an area in the United Kingdom. They are sites of biological or geological interest, or both.

Any activity which might affect an SSSI is illegal unless the appropriate planning body gives permission. Owners of land must do what needs to be done to protect an SSSI which sits on their land. There may be grants available to help owners look after the site. 

[[Identity politics]]

CATEGORIES: Human rights

Identity politics is politics that focuses on the problems of groups based on identity. Examples of identity politics include Black nationalism, fat acceptance, feminism, and Nazism. "Identity politics" is often used as a negative term.

[[Stuart Hall]]

Stuart Hall may refer to 

[[Courtney Barnett]]

CATEGORIES: 1988 births, Australian singer-songwriters, Living people

Courtney Barnett (born c. 1988) is an Australian singer-songwriter and guitarist from Melbourne. Barnett was born in Tasmania. Barnett started playing guitar when she was 10. Barnett starts a UK tour in May.

[[Richard Russell Jr.]]

CATEGORIES: 1897 births, 1971 deaths, Deaths from emphysema, Disease-related deaths in Washington, D.C., Governors of Georgia (U.S. state), Presidents pro tempore of the United States Senate, United States senators from Georgia, US Democratic Party politicians

Richard Brevard Russell, Jr. (November 2, 1897 – January 21, 1971) was an American politician. He was a member of the Democratic Party. 

Russell was born in Winder, Georgia. He studied at University of Georgia School of Law.

Russell was the 66th Governor of Georgia. He served as governor from 1931 to 1933. He then served as the United States senator of Georgia. He served as senator from 1933 to 1971. 

Russell was the President pro tempore of the United States Senate. He served as president pro tempore from 1969 to 1971. Russell ran for President of the United States in 1948. He lost the primary to Harry S. Truman.

[[Dean Spade]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 births, Living people, American lawyers, American LGBT rights activists, Jewish activists, Jewish American academics, Jewish American LGBT people, Jewish American writers, Transgender and transsexual Jews, Writers from New York City

Dean Spade (born 1977) is an American lawyer, writer, and Associate Professor of Law at Seattle University School of Law. He started the Sylvia Rivera Law Project in 2002. In 2011 Spade's first book Normal Life: Administrative Violence, Critical Trans Politics, and the Limits of Law was published. The book was nominated for a 2011 Lambda Literary Award in the category of Transgender Nonfiction. 

Spade is of Jewish descent and is involved in transgender activities.

[[Batukeshwar Dutt]]

CATEGORIES: 1910 births, 1965 deaths, Disease-related deaths in India, Indian activists, Indian criminals, Prisoners sentenced to life imprisonment, Terrorists

Batukeshwar Dutt (18 November 1910 – 20 July 1965) was an Indian revolutionary. He created and planned bombings across India. He was sent to jail for life. He went on many hunger strikes, even when he was in jail. He was abused by many prisoners. He was born in Kanpur, British India.

Dutt died in New Delhi, India from a long illness, aged 54.

[[Winder, Georgia]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Georgia (U.S. state), County seats in Georgia

Winder is a city in Barrow County, Georgia. 

[[Newton, Massachusetts]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Massachusetts

Newton is a city in Middlesex County, Massachusetts.

[[Martin Creed]]

CATEGORIES: 1968 births, English artists, Living people, People from Glasgow, People from West Yorkshire, Wakefield

Martin Creed (born 1968) is a British artist. He won the Turner Prize in 2001. 

[[Gyude Bryant]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, 2014 deaths, African politicians, Civil servants, Presidents of Liberia

Charles Gyude Bryant (17 January 1949 – 16 April 2014) was a Liberian politician and businessman. He was the Chairman of the Transitional Government of Liberia. He served as chairman from 2003 to 2006. He was a member of the Liberian Action Party.

Bryant died at the John F. Kennedy Medical Center in Monrovia, aged 65. 

[[Karpal Singh]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2014 deaths, Civil servants, Lawyers, Road accident deaths, Malaysian politicians

Karpal Singh s/o Ram Singh (28 June 1940 - 17 April 2014) was a Malaysian lawyer and politician. He served as a Member of Parliament of Bukit Gelugor. He served as a MP from March 2004 until his death in April 2014. Singh was a member of the Democratic Action Party. He was born in George Town, Penang.

Singh died at the age of 73 in a car accident near Gopeng, Perak.

[[Henry Mancini]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 1994 deaths, Academy Award winning composers, American jazz musicians, American people of World War II, American pianists, Cancer deaths in the United States, Deaths from pancreatic cancer, Golden Globe Award winning composers, Grammy Award winners, Musicians from Cleveland, Ohio, Musicians from Pennsylvania

Enrico Nicola "Henry" Mancini (April 16, 1924 - June 14, 1994) was an American composer, conductor and arranger.

Mancini was born in Little Italy, Cleveland and raised in West Aliquippa, Pennsylvania. He served in the United States Army from 1943-1945.

Mancini's best known works include: The Pink Panther Theme, the Peter Gunn Theme, Moon River and Days of Wine and Roses. He won Grammy Awards, Academy Awards and a Golden Globe Award.

Mancini died aged 70 of pancreatic cancer in Los Angeles, California.

[[Ralph Morgan]]

CATEGORIES: 1883 births, 1956 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Presidents of the Screen Actors Guild, American movie actors, American stage actors, Actors from New York City

Ralph Morgan (July 6, 1883 – June 11, 1956) was an American movie, stage and character actor. He was the older brother of Frank Morgan. Morgan was the first President of the Screen Actors Guild. He appeared in over 100 movies and 35 stage shows.

Morgan died in New York City from a heart attack, aged 72.

[[Edward Arnold]]

CATEGORIES: 1890 births, 1956 deaths, Deaths from cerebral hemorrhage, Presidents of the Screen Actors Guild, American movie actors, American stage actors, Actors from New York City

Edward Arnold (Günther Edward Arnold Schneider; February 18, 1890 – April 26, 1956) was an American actor.

Arnold appeared in many blockbuster movies such as; You Can't Take With You, Mr. Smith Goes to Washington, Meet John Doe, Jonny Eager, and in The Toast of New York.

Arnold served as the President of the Screen Actors Guild. He served as president from 1940 to 1942.

Arnold died in Encino, California from a cerebral hemorrhage, aged 66.

[[George Murphy]]

CATEGORIES: 1902 births, 1992 deaths, Deaths from leukemia, Cancer deaths in Florida, Presidents of the Screen Actors Guild, American movie actors, American stage actors, American dancers, Politicians from Connecticut, United States senators from California, Actors from New Haven, Connecticut, Actors from California, US Republican Party politicians

George Lloyd Murphy (July 4, 1902 – May 3, 1992) was an American dancer, actor, and politician. He was a member of the Republican Party.

Murphy was born in New Haven, Connecticut. He studied at Yale University.

Murphy first served as President of the Screen Actors Guild. He served as president from 1944 to 1946. He then served as the United States senator of California. He served as senator from 1965 to 1971.

Murphy was married to Juliette Henkel-Johnson from 1926 until her death in 1973. Then he was married to Betty Duhon Blandi from 1982 until his death in 1992. He had two children; Dennis and Melissa.

Murphy died in Palm Beach, Florida from leukemia, aged 89.

[[Geoffrey Palmer (politician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, Living people, Prime Ministers of New Zealand, Deputy Prime Ministers of New Zealand

Sir Geoffrey Winston Russell Palmer (born 21 April 1942) is a New Zealand politician. He served as the 33rd Prime Minister of New Zealand. He served as Prime Minister from 8 August 1989 to 4 September 1990. 

Palmer was born in Nelson, New Zealand. 

[[Geoffrey Palmer (actor)]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2020 deaths, Actors from London, English movie actors, English stage actors, English television actors

Geoffrey Dyson Palmer OBE (4 June 1927 – 6 November 2020) was an English actor. He was known for his roles in British television sitcoms. Palmer played Jimmy Anderson in The Fall and Rise of Reginald Perrin, Ben Parkinson in Butterflies and Lionel Hardcastle in As Time Goes By.

Palmer was born in London, England. He died at his London home on 6 November 2020, aged 93.
