[[Gladwin, Michigan]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Michigan, County seats in Michigan

Gladwin is a city in Gladwin County, Michigan. It has the population of 2,933 residents.

[[The Rats of Tobruk]]

CATEGORIES: Military, World War II, 1941, 20th century in Africa

The Rats of Tobruk was the name given to the soldiers who held the Libyan port of Tobruk against the Afrika Corps, during the Siege of Tobruk in World War II. 

The siege started on 10 April 1941. It was relieved at the end of November.

Australian troops of the Australian 9th Division and the 18th Brigade of the Australian 7th Division under Lieutenant General Leslie Morshead made up more than half of the Allied presence in Tobruk. There were more than 14,000 men. The rest of the garrison was made up of 12,000 British (the 3rd Armoured Brigade, 4 artillery regiments) and Indian (the 18th King Edward's Own Cavalry) troops. 

During the three moonless periods between August and October, the Australian troops and Indian cavalry left by sea and were replaced by British 70th Infantry Division and the Polish Independent Carpathian Brigade with the Czechoslovak 11th Infantry Battalion under command.

[[Trust Company (band)]]

CATEGORIES: 1997 establishments in the United States, 1990s music groups, 2000s music groups, 2010s music groups, Alternative metal bands, American hard rock bands, Musical groups from Alabama, Nu metal bands, Post-grunge bands, 20th-century establishments in Alabama

Trust Company (also known by the typeset TRUSTcompany and TRUST*CO) is an American alternative metal/post-grunge band from Prattville, Alabama. 

Trust Company was formed in 1997 by lead singer Kevin Palmer and drummer Jason Singleton. They originally named the band 41 Down but changed it later to avoid being confused with Canadian punk rock band Sum 41. Palmer and Singleton would later recruit bassist Josh Moates and guitarist James Fukai. After they released a few demos and a self-titled album, the band was signed to Geffen Records. They released their debut album The Lonely Position of Neutral on July 23, 2002. The album features the single "Downfall" which received heavy exposure from MTV2. Their second studio album True Parallels was released on March 22, 2005. It featured the single "Stronger". In August 2005, Trust Company took a break to work on other projects and to rest. During the break, Palmer and Moates started a band called Amity Lane. On August 11, 2007, they announced that they were reuniting. The band released their third studio album Dreaming in Black and White on March 8, 2011. The album featured the single "Heart in My Hands".

[[Bridgeport, Chicago]]

CATEGORIES: Community areas of Chicago

Bridgeport, one of 77 community areas of Chicago, Illinois, is a neighborhood on the city's South Side, bounded on the north by the South Branch of the Chicago River. It is a working-class neighborhood on Chicago's south side. Five mayors of Chicago were born here. The neighborhood is known for being Irish.

[[Old Town, Chicago]]

CATEGORIES: Neighborhoods in Chicago

Old Town is a neighborhood in Chicago, Illinois. It is a historic neighborhood.

[[Goose Island (Chicago)]]

CATEGORIES: Neighborhoods in Chicago

Goose Island is a 160 artificial island in Chicago, Illinois. It is formed by the North Branch of the Chicago River on the west and the North Branch Canal on the east. It is about 1.5 long and 0.5 across at its widest point.

[[Lake View, Chicago]]

CATEGORIES: Community areas of Chicago

Lake View, also spelled Lakeview, is one of the 77 community areas of Chicago, Illinois, located on the city's North Side. The Uptown community area is to Lakeview's north, Lincoln Square to its northwest, North Center to its west and Lincoln Park to its south. 

The 2015 population of Lakeview was 98,212 residents, making it the largest of the Chicago community areas by population.

Lakeview unofficially includes smaller neighborhood enclaves: Sheridan Station Corridor, Boystown, Northhalsted, Southport Corridor, Wrigleyville, & Wrigley Plaza. Boystown, famous for its large LGBT population, holds the pride parade held each June. 

Wrigleyville, another popular district, surrounds Wrigley Field, home of the Chicago Cubs. Lakeview is home to the Belmont Theater District showcasing over 30 theaters and live performance venues located near the Belmont El station.  In 2013 Money Magazine named Lakeview as number 3 of its top 10 Big-city neighborhoods for its selection of Best Places to Live.

[[Lincoln Park, Chicago]]

CATEGORIES: Community areas of Chicago

Lincoln Park is a designated community area in North Side, Chicago, Illinois.

As of 2015, the neighborhood is primarily made up of young urban professionals, recent college graduates, and young families. The slang terms Trixie and Chad have their origins in Lincoln Park. The 2003 Chicago balcony collapse occurred in Lincoln Park.

[[Millennium Park]]

CATEGORIES: Parks in Chicago

Millennium Park is a public park in the Loop community area of Chicago, Illinois.

[[Magnificent Mile]]

CATEGORIES: Neighborhoods in Chicago, Roads in Chicago

The Magnificent Mile, or The Mag Mile, is a section of Chicago's Michigan Avenue. It begins from the Chicago River to Oak Street in the Near North Side.

[[Near South Side, Chicago]]

CATEGORIES: Community areas of Chicago

The Near South Side is a community area of Chicago in Cook County, Illinois, United States. 

It is located just south of the downtown central business district, the Loop, which is itself a community area. 

The Near South Side's boundaries (see map) are as follows: North—Roosevelt Road (1200 S); South—26th Street; West—Chicago River between Roosevelt and 18th Street, Clark Street between 18th Street and Cermak Road, Federal between Cermak Road and the Stevenson Expressway just south of 25th Street, and Clark Street again between the Stevenson and 26th Street; and East—Lake Michigan.

[[Near North Side, Chicago]]

CATEGORIES: Community areas of Chicago

The Near North Side is one of 77 community areas of Chicago, Illinois, United States. It is the northernmost of the three areas that constitute central Chicago, the others being the Loop and the Near South Side. The community area is located north and east of the Chicago River. 

To its east is Lake Michigan, and its northern boundary is the early 19th-century city limit of Chicago, North Avenue. Of the downtown community areas, the Near North Side has the second largest total area, after the Near West Side, the highest number of skyscrapers, and the largest population. 

With the exception of Goose Island and the remains of Cabrini-Green, to the west, the Near North Side is known for its rich neighborhoods, the Magnificent Mile, Washington Square Park, Gold Coast, Navy Pier, and its world-famous skyscrapers such as the John Hancock Center.

The Near North Side is the oldest part of Chicago.

[[Near West Side, Chicago]]

CATEGORIES: Community areas of Chicago

The Near West Side , one of the 77 community areas of Chicago, is on the West Side, west of the Chicago River and near to the Loop. 

The history of the Near West Side of Chicago includes the founding of Hull House, a prominent settlement house. The Great Chicago Fire started on the Near West Side. The area is home to the University of Illinois at Chicago (UIC), the United Center, Greektown, Chicago and the Illinois Medical District.

[[Cabrini–Green, Chicago]]

CATEGORIES: Neighborhoods in Chicago

Cabrini–Green is a neighborhood on the Near North Side community area on the north side of Chicago, Illinois. The neighborhood is known for being the location of the Cabrini–Green Homes, a public housing project in the city.

[[South Side, Chicago]]

CATEGORIES: Cook County, Illinois, Neighborhoods in Chicago

South Side is a major part of the city of Chicago, Illinois. It is in Cook County. This area of the city is divided by the Chicago River.

The South Side of Chicago was originally defined as all of the city south of the main branch of the Chicago River, but it now excludes the Loop.

South Side neighborhoods such as Armour Square, Back of the Yards, Bridgeport, and Pullman are where the middle-class residents of the South Side mainly live, while Hyde Park, the Jackson Park Highlands District, Kenwood, Beverly, Mount Greenwood, and west Morgan Park are where the upper-class people mainly live such as former President Barack Obama.

[[Forest Glen, Chicago]]

CATEGORIES: Community areas of Chicago

Forest Glen is one of the 77 official city community areas of Chicago, Illinois, located on the city's Northwest Side. It comprises the neighborhoods of Forest Glen, Edgebrook and Sauganash, with sub-neighborhoods of Sauganash Park, Wildwood, North Edgebrook and Old Edgebrook.

[[O'Hare, Chicago]]

CATEGORIES: Community areas of Chicago

O'Hare, located on the far northwest side of Chicago, Illinois, is one of the city's 77 official community areas. O'Hare International Airport is located within the boundaries of this community area. This community area is the only one that extends outside Cook County; the western edge (an area comprising the southwest part of the airport) is in DuPage County.

[[Edgewater, Chicago]]

CATEGORIES: Community areas of Chicago

Edgewater is a lakefront community area on the North Side of the city of Chicago, Illinois seven miles north of the Loop.

Edgewater was the northeastern corner of Lake View Township, an independent suburb which was annexed by the city of Chicago in 1889. Today, the Uptown community is to Edgewater's south, Lincoln Square to its west, West Ridge to its northwest and Rogers Park to its north.

[[Portage Park, Chicago]]

CATEGORIES: Community areas of Chicago

Portage Park is located on the northwest side of the City of Chicago, Illinois and is one of 77 officially designated Chicago community areas. 

Portage Park is bordered by the community areas of Jefferson Park and Forest Glen to the north, Dunning and the suburb of Harwood Heights to the west, Irving Park to the east and Belmont-Cragin to the south.

The area is notable for its Six Corners outdoor shopping district.

[[Irving Park, Chicago]]

CATEGORIES: Community areas of Chicago

Irving Park is one of 77 officially designated Chicago community areas located on the Northwest Side. It is bounded by the Chicago River on the east. It is named after the American author Washington Irving.

Old Irving Park, bounded by Montrose Avenue, Pulaski Road, Addison Street and Cicero Avenue, has a variety of housing stock, with Queen Anne, Victorian, and Italianate homes, a few farmhouses and numerous bungalows.

The CTA Blue Line runs through this neighborhood.

[[Irving Thalberg]]

CATEGORIES: 1899 births, 1936 deaths, Deaths from pneumonia, Infectious disease deaths in California, Movie producers from New York City

Irving Grant Thalberg (May 30, 1899 – September 14, 1936) was an American movie producer. He is known for producing many blockbusters during the silent movie era. The Irving G. Thalberg Memorial Award is named after him.

He produced Grand Hotel, China Seas, Camille, Mutiny on the Bounty, The Good Earth, and many more. He was born in Brooklyn, New York.

Thalberg died from pneumonia in Santa Monica, California, aged 37.

[[Peter Drummond-Murray of Mastrick]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2014 deaths, British businesspeople, People from Sussex, Royalty and nobility, Scottish people

William Edward Peter Louis Drummond-Murray of Mastrick (24 November 1929 – 13 April 2014) was a Scottish herald, Private Officer of Arms and banker. He was appointed Slains Pursuivant of Arms in 1982. He was born in Littlehampton, Sussex.

Drummond died in Edinburgh, Scotland, aged 84.

[[John Witherspoon (actor)]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2019 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Cardiovascular disease deaths in Los Angeles, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, American comedians, Actors from Detroit, Michigan

John "Pops" Witherspoon (born John Weatherspoon; January 27, 1942 – October 29, 2019) was an American actor and comedian. He had roles in several movies and television shows. He was mostly known his role in Friday series and as Granddad Robert Freeman in The Boondocks.

Witherspoon was born in Detroit, Michigan. He died at his home in Sherman Oaks, California on October 29, 2019 at the age of 77. The cause of death was a heart attack.

[[The Boondocks (TV series)]]

CATEGORIES: 2005 American television series debuts, 2014 American television series endings, Adult animated television series, American sitcoms, Adult Swim, Television series set in Chicago, Illinois, English-language television programs

The Boondocks is an American adult animated sitcom produced by Adult Swim. The series premiered in November 6, 2005. It is set in South Side, Chicago, Illinois.

[[Museum Campus]]

CATEGORIES: Neighborhoods in Chicago, Parks in Chicago

Museum Campus is a 57 museum park that sits near Lake Michigan in Chicago and surrounds three of the city's most famous museums. 

It is dedicated to the natural sciences: the Adler Planetarium & Astronomy Museum, the Shedd Aquarium, and the Field Museum of Natural History. It is also known for holding the Soldier Field football stadium and the Lakeside Center of the McCormick Place. 

It used to hold Meigs Field airport on Northerly Island before it was destroyed. The campus holds the southeast corner of Grant Park.

[[Chicago Reader]]

CATEGORIES: Newspapers in Chicago, 1971 establishments in the United States, 1970s establishments in Illinois

The Chicago Reader is a newspaper that is published in Chicago, Illinois, in the US. It is a tabloid. It was founded by college students from Carleton College in 1971.

[[Dewey Defeats Truman]]

CATEGORIES: Harry S. Truman, 1948 in the United States

"Dewey Defeats Truman" was a famously incorrect headline on the front page of the Chicago Tribune. It was published on November 3, 1948. 

It happened the day after incumbent United States President Harry S. Truman won an upset victory over Republican challenger and Governor of New York Thomas E. Dewey in the 1948 presidential election.

[[Savings and loan crisis]]

CATEGORIES: 1986, 1995, 20th century in the United States, Presidency of Ronald Reagan

The savings and loan crisis of the 1980s and 1990s (commonly dubbed the S&L crisis) was the failure of 1,043 out of the 3,234 savings and loan associations in the United States. It lasted from 1986 to 1995. In 1996, the General Accounting Office estimated the total cost to be $160 billion, including $132.1 billion taken from taxpayers.

The man behind the crisis was Charles Keating. He was sentenced for his involvement of the crisis. Some people blame Ronald Reagan for the crisis because he signed the Tax Reform Act of 1986 which some might think was a direct result of the crisis.

[[Chinatown, Chicago]]

CATEGORIES: Neighborhoods in Chicago

Chinatown is a neighborhood in Chicago, Illinois. It is a ethnic neighborhood for Chinese cultures. This is the second oldest Chinatown behind, Chinatown, San Francisco. 

[[Greenville, Mississippi]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Mississippi, County seats in Mississippi

Greenville is a city in Washington County, Mississippi. 

[[Lewis & Clark College]]

CATEGORIES: Colleges and universities in Oregon, Portland, Oregon, 1857 establishments in the United States, 19th-century establishments in Oregon

Lewis & Clark College is a private university in Portland, Oregon. The school was formed in 1867, and has about 3,600 students, and about 150 teachers. 

[[Jim Bolger]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, New Zealand businesspeople, Living people, Politicians from North Island, Prime Ministers of New Zealand, Republicans, Roman Catholics

James Brendan "Jim" Bolger ONZ (born 31 May 1935) is a New Zealand businessman and politician for the National Party. He was the 35th Prime Minister of New Zealand. He served as Prime Minister from 2 November 1990 to 8 December 1997.

Bolger was born in Opunake, Taranaki. He is a Roman Catholic and has been married to Joan Riddell since 1963. They have nine children.

[[Bill Henry]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2014 deaths, American baseball players, Boston Red Sox players, Cardiovascular disease deaths in the United States, Chicago Cubs players, Cincinnati Reds players, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Houston Astros players, National League All-Stars, Pittsburgh Pirates players, San Francisco Giants players

William Rodman "Bill" Henry (October 15, 1927 – April 11, 2014) was an American professional baseball left-handed pitcher. He played in Major League Baseball (MLB) between 1952 and 1969. All the teams he played for were: the Boston Red Sox, the Chicago Cubs, the Cincinnati Reds, the San Francisco Giants, the Pittsburgh Pirates, and the Houston Astros. He was born in Alice, Texas.

Henry died from a heart attack on April 11, 2014 in Round Rock, Texas. He was 86.

[[Aracataca]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Colombia, 1885 establishments, 19th-century establishments in Colombia

Aracataca is a city in Magdalena, Columbia. The city is known for being the birthplace of Gabriel García Márquez.

[[Round Rock, Texas]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Texas

Round Rock is a city in Williamson County, Texas, United States. As of 2010, 99,887 people live in Round Rock.

[[Aulis Rytkönen]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2014 deaths, 1952 Summer Olympics, Finnish footballers, Finnish Olympians

Taavi Aulis Rytkönen (5 January 1929 – 16 April 2014) was a Finnish footballer. He became the country's first professional player when he signed for France's Toulouse FC in 1952.

He was born in Karttula, Finland.

He played for Finland at the 1952 Summer Olympics in Helsinki. He also worked as national coach from 1975 to 1978. He was chosen Finland's Player of the Year in 1949, 1950, and 1952.

Rytkönen died in Helsinki, Finland, aged 85.

[[Karttula]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Finland, 2011 disestablishments in Europe

Karttula used to be a city in Finland. It was merged with another city Kuopio in 2011.

[[Alice, Texas]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Texas, County seats in Texas

Alice is a city and county seat of Jim Wells County, Texas.

[[Harry Brearley]]

CATEGORIES: English inventors, People from Sheffield, 1871 births, 1948 deaths

Harry Brearley (18 February 1871 – 14 July 1948) was an English metallurgist who invented stainless steel, that is, steel which does not rust.

[[Reigate]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Surrey

Reigate is a town in Reigate and Banstead, Surrey, England. About 22,000 people live in the town. Reigate's postcode is RH2.

[[Karachi-Bela Division]]

CATEGORIES: Divisions of Balochistan (Pakistan)

Karachi-Bela Division (Urdu:کراچی-بلا) was a former Administrative division of Pakistan. It used to be part of the Las Bela (princely state).

[[Into the Storm (2014 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2014 movies, American disaster movies, English-language movies, Found footage movies, Movies set in Oklahoma

Into the Storm is a 2014 American found footage disaster movie. It is about tornadoes and severe storms in Oklahoma. The movie was released on August 8, 2014.

Warner Bros. is the main distributor of this movie.

[[Littlehampton]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in West Sussex

Littlehampton is a seaside town in Arun, West Sussex, England. About 26,000 people live in the town. Its postcode is BN17.

[[Jiří Načeradský]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2014 deaths, Czech educators, Czech painters

Jiří Načeradský (9 September 1939 – 16 April 2014) was a Czech painter, graphic artist and educator. He was best known for his human figures, sometimes with erotic and sexual subtext and context. He was born in Sedlec-Prčice, Příbram District, Czechoslovakia.

Načeradský died on 16 April 2014 in Prague, Czech Republic, aged 74.

[[Myer S. Kripke]]

CATEGORIES: 1914 births, 2014 deaths, American centenarians, American philanthropists, American rabbis, Jewish centenarians, Jewish philanthropists, People from Toledo, Ohio, Writers from Ohio

Myer Samuel Kripke (January 21, 1914 – April 11, 2014) was an American rabbi, scholar, and philanthropist. He was the leader of Beth El Synagogue. He was also known for investing into Warren Buffett.

Kripke was born in Toledo, Ohio. He and his wife, Dorothy, had three children. Their son, Saul, is a philosopher and logician.

Kripke died from natural causes on April 11, 2014 in Omaha, Nebraska, aged 100.

[[California Über Alles]]

CATEGORIES: 1979 songs

"California Über Alles" is the first single off American hardcore punk band Dead Kennedys' debut studio album Fresh Fruit for Rotting Vegetables. The song was released in June 1979. 

The lyrics for the song were written by lead singer Jello Biafra and John Greenway for their band, The Healers. Biafra composed the music during one of his rare attempts at composing on bass.

The song is about Jerry Brown, the Governor of California from 1975-1983 (and later 2011–present). It is sung from his perspective, as a fictional version of Brown shapes a hippie-fascist vision for America. The title is a reference to the first (and no longer sung) stanza of the national anthem of Germany, which began with the words "Deutschland, Deutschland über alles" (literally: "Germany, Germany above all").

The song appeared in the video games Tony Hawk's American Wasteland and the Rock Band series.

[[Hugo Villar]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, 2014 deaths, People from Montevideo, Physicians, Uruguayan politicians

Hugo Villar Tejeiro (20 November 1925 – 15 April 2014) was a Uruguayan physician and politician. He is best known for co-founding the left-wing political party Broad Front in 1971. He was born in Montevideo.

Villar died on 15 April 2014 in Montevideo, aged 88.

[[Brooshal]]

CATEGORIES: Kashmir

Brooshal (بروشل) is an old name for the northern Pakistan, and Kashmir. It was part of the Gilgit-Baltistan region.

[[Deliver Us from Evil]]

CATEGORIES: 2014 horror movies, 2014 crime movies, 2014 thriller movies, 2014 drama movies, 2010s crime thriller movies, 2010s crime drama movies, American horror movies, American crime thriller movies, American crime drama movies, Movies based on books

Deliver Us from Evil is a 2014 crime and horror movie. It is about a New York City police officer who gets pulled into a case that is demon-related. Eric Bana plays the officer, Ralph Sarchie. Olivia Munn plays his wife.

The movie is based on a 2001 book called Beware the Night. Screen Gems distributes the movie.

The movie was released on July 2, 2014.

[[Fé Sciarone]]

CATEGORIES: 1922 births, 2014 deaths, Comedians, Dutch actors, People from The Hague, Radio actors

Félicité Louise Henriette "Fé" Sciarone (12 August 1922 – 8 April 2014) was a Dutch radio actress and comedienne. Her best known appearances include Dood in de jungle (1955), Een merkwaardig geval van zielsverhuizing (1969), De generaal (1976), Dit is uw kans (1979) and Vijf gemaskerde mannen (1982). She started her career in 1950 and retired in 1984. She was born in The Hague, South Holland.

In 1959 she voiced Maleficient in the first Dutch translation of Sleeping Beauty from Walt Disney.

Sciarone died on 8 April 2014 in Amsterdam, North Holland, aged 91.

[[Dorothy Allison]]

CATEGORIES: American crime victims, American feminists, American LGBT people, American novelists, Lesbian feminists, LGBT novelists, Writers from South Carolina

Dorothy Allison (born April 11, 1949) is an American writer. She has won awards for her writing.

[[Kutch (princely state)]]

CATEGORIES: Indian princely states, Gujarat, 1147 establishments, 12th-century establishments in Asia, Establishments in India, 1948 disestablishments in India

Cutch or (Kutch/Kachchh) was an Indian Princely state. It was ruled by the Jadeja dynasty from its formation in 1147 until 1948. On May 4, 1948 it merged with India. The district is now known as Kutch.

[[Catharine Macaulay]]

CATEGORIES: 1731 births, 1791 deaths, English historians, Writers from Kent

Catharine Macaulay (2 April 1731 – 22 June 1791) was an English historian. Between 1763 and 1783 Macaulay wrote her biggest work, The History of England from the Accession of James I to that of the Brunswick Line. Her 1790 work Letters on Education deeply influenced Mary Wollstonecraft.

[[Burmee Colony]]

CATEGORIES: Karachi

Burmee Colony (Urdu: برمی کالونی is one of the neighbourhoods of Landhi Town in Karachi, Sindh, Pakistan. This neighborhood is named after the Muslim Rohingyas refugees who came from Myanmar (formerly Burma). However, this colony has been settled by Sayed Ahmed and late Haji Hilal Ahmed in early 1960s.

[[Yadollah Sharifirad]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, Living people, Autobiographers, Aviators, Canadian writers, Diplomats, Iranian military people, Naturalized citizens of Canada, Prisoners

Yadollah Sharifirad (born March 24, 1946) is an Iranian former fighter pilot and military attaché. He was also in 1978 a member of Golden Crown. Golden Crown was the national aerobatics team of Iran. It was a part of the former Imperial Iranian Air Force. 

Sharifirad was one of the most successful Iranian F-5 pilots during the Iran–Iraq War. He had 5 victories against the Iraqi fighter aircraft (3 confirmed victories and 2 probable victories). The victories include: one Su-22 and four MiG-21s. After that he attacked an Iraqi power station, 3 Iraqi fighters attacked him. The Iraqi fighters shot his airplane down. He ejected and Iraqi Kurdish guerrillas took him back to Iran. A movie called The Eagles was made about this event.

From 1984 until 1987, he was a military attaché in Pakistan. In 1987, the Iranian government ordered him back to Iran and accused him of the espionage for the United States. He spent one year in prison. He was set free after one year and fled to Canada.

In 2010, Sharifirad wrote a book about his life, called Flight of a Patriot." In this book he tells the story of his life from his youth and through taking part in the Iran-Iraq war, his arrest, prison and being tortured, ending with his immigrating to Canada.

[[Bryan Berard]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 births, American ice hockey players, Bill Masterton Memorial Trophy winners, Boston Bruins players, Calder Trophy winners, Chicago Blackhawks players, Columbus Blue Jackets players, Doping cases in sport, Living people, New York Islanders players, New York Rangers players, Toronto Maple Leafs players, Sportspeople from Rhode Island, Ontario Hockey League players, Ice hockey defencemen

Bryan Wallace Berard (born March 5, 1977) is a American retired professional ice hockey defenceman. Berard played a total of 619 games in the National Hockey League (NHL). He played with the Columbus Blue Jackets, Chicago Blackhawks, Boston Bruins, New York Rangers, Toronto Maple Leafs, and New York Islanders.

[[Cheo Feliciano]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2014 deaths, Road accident deaths, Puerto Rican entertainers, Puerto Rican singers, Composers, Musicians

Cheo Feliciano (José Luis Feliciano Vega, July 3, 1935 – April 17, 2014) was a Puerto Rican composer and singer. He was mostly involved with salsa and Cuban music. He was born in Ponce, Puerto Rico.

Feliciano died in Cupey, Puerto Rico, in a car accident. He was 78 years old.

At the peak of his career in the 1960s he recorded nine albums with the Joe Cuba Sextet, and in the 1970s he recorded 15 albums for Fania Records, then the leading salsa music record company.

[[Gallatin, Tennessee]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Tennessee, County seats in Tennessee

Gallatin is a city in Sumner County, Tennessee. It has the population of 31,101 residents. It is named after United States Secretary of State Albert Gallatin.

[[Virgilio Barco Vargas]]

CATEGORIES: 1921 births, 1997 deaths, Deaths from cancer, Presidents of Colombia, Ambassadors of Colombia

Virgilio Barco Vargas (17 September 1921 – 20 May 1997) was a Colombian politician, and civil engineer and member of Colombian Liberal Party. He served as the 27th President of Colombia from 1986 to 1990. Vargas was born in Cúcuta, North Santander, Colombia.

Vargas died in Bogotá, D.C., Colombia from cancer, aged 75.

[[Carlsbad, California]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in California, Settlements in San Diego County, California

Carlsbad is a city in north San Diego County, California. It is near San Diego and it has a population of 105,328 people.

[[Cowboy from Brooklyn]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 movies, 1930s musical movies, 1930s comedy movies, American musical comedy movies, Movies set in New York City, Movies directed by Lloyd Bacon

Cowboy from Brooklyn is a 1938 American musical comedy movie directed by Lloyd Bacon. It stars Pat O'Brien, Dick Powell, Priscilla Lane, Ann Sheridan, Dick Foran, Johnnie Davis, and Ronald Reagan. It was released on July 9, 1938.

[[Pat O'Brien]]

CATEGORIES: 1899 births, 1983 deaths, American movie actors, American radio actors, American stage actors, Cardiovascular disease deaths in the United States, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Emmy Award winning actors, Actors from Milwaukee, Wisconsin

Pat O’Brien (William Joseph Patrick O'Brien; November 11, 1899 – October 15, 1983) was an American movie, radio, and stage actor. He won a Daytime Emmy Award during his career. O'Brien was born in Milwaukee, Wisconsin. 

He began acting in 1920. He appeared in over 100 movies. He is known for his roles in Knute Rockne, All American, Cowboy from Brooklyn, and in Some Like It Hot. 

O'Brien died from a heart attack in Santa Monica, California, aged 83.

[[John Houbolt]]

CATEGORIES: 1919 births, 2014 deaths, Engineers from Maine, Deaths from natural causes, NASA, Scientists from Iowa, Scientists from Maine

John Cornelius Houbolt (April 10, 1919 – April 15, 2014) was an American aerospace engineer for NASA. He is best known for his work on  the lunar mission mode called "lunar orbit rendezvous" (LOR). This was chosen for Apollo program in early 1962. He was born in Altoona, Iowa.

Houbolt died from natural causes on April 15, 2014 in Scarborough, Maine, aged 95.

[[John Slattery]]

CATEGORIES: 1962 births, Living people, Actors from Boston, Massachusetts, American movie actors, American Roman Catholics, American stage actors, American television actors, Movie directors from Massachusetts, Movie producers from Massachusetts, Screenwriters from Massachusetts, Writers from Boston, Massachusetts

John M. Slattery Jr. (born August 13, 1962) is an American actor, director, producer and screenwriter. He is best known for his role as Roger Sterling in the AMC drama series Mad Men. He was part of the Mad Men cast that won two SAG Awards. He has also appeared in the movies Iron Man 2 (2010) and The Adjustment Bureau (2011).

Slattery was born in Boston, Massachusetts to an Irish Roman Catholic family. He married actress Talia Balsam in 1998 and together they have a son, Harry.

[[Gary Speed]]

CATEGORIES: 1969 births, 2011 deaths, Members of the Order of the British Empire, Sportspeople who committed suicide, Suicides by hanging in the United Kingdom, Welsh footballers, Welsh football managers, People from Flintshire

Gary Andrew Speed MBE (8 September 1969 – 27 November 2011) was a Welsh footballer and manager. He played mainly as a midfielder. He was born in Mancot, Flintshire.

Speed played for Leeds United from 1988 to 1996 winning the 1991–92 Football League First Division. He also played for Everton from 1996 to 1998, Newcastle United from 1998 to 2004, Bolton Wanderers from 2004 to 2008 and Sheffield United from 2008 to 2010. After playing, he managed Sheffield United for a short time in 2010. At the time of his death in 2011, Speed was manager of Wales since 2010.

Speed killed himself by hanging on 27 November 2011 in the garage of his home in Huntington, Cheshire, England. He was 42. He was outlived by his wife their two sons, Ed and Tom.

[[Sorrento, Maine]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Maine

Sorrento is a town in Hancock County, Maine. The population was 274 at the 2010 census.

[[LeRoy Neiman]]

CATEGORIES: 1921 births, 2012 deaths, Deaths from natural causes, American artists, People from Saint Paul, Minnesota

LeRoy Neiman (born Leroy Leslie Runquist, June 8, 1921 – June 20, 2012) was an American artist. He is known for his colored, expressionist paintings and screen prints of athletes, musicians, and sporting events. He was born in St. Paul, Minnesota.

Neiman died in New York City, New York from natural causes, aged 91.

[[Ralf Dahrendorf]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2009 deaths, British philosophers, British politicians, Cancer deaths in Germany, Civil servants, Disease-related deaths in North Rhine-Westphalia, German philosophers, German sociologists, German political scientists, Politicians from Hamburg

Ralph Gustav Dahrendorf, Baron Dahrendorf, KBE, FBA (1 May 1929 – 17 June 2009) was a German-British sociologist, philosopher, political scientist and liberal politician.

Dahrendorf was born in Hamburg, Germany. He studied at Hamburg University and at the London School of Economics.

Dahrendorf was a member of the House of the Lords from July 1993 to June 2009. 

Dahrendorf died in Cologne, Germany, aged 80, on 17 June 2009, after suffering from cancer.

[[Augusto Boal]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2009 deaths, Brazilian politicians, Brazilian writers, Deaths from leukemia, Deaths from respiratory failure, People from Rio de Janeiro, Brazilian theatre directors

Augusto Boal (16 March 1931 - 2 May 2009) was a Brazilian theatre director, writer and politician. 

He was the founder of Theatre of the Oppressed. Boal served one term as a Vereador (the Brazilian version of a city councillor) in Rio de Janeiro from 1993 to 1997. He developed the legislative theatre.

Boal died from respiratory failure caused by leukemia, aged 78.

[[Algirdas Brazauskas]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2010 deaths, Deaths from cancer, Presidents of Lithuania, Prime Ministers of Lithuania, Speakers of the Seimas

Algirdas Mykolas Brazauskas (22 September 1932 – 26 June 2010) was the first President of Lithuania from 1993 to 1998 and Prime Minister from 2001 to 2006.

Brazauskas died from lymphatic cancer in Vilnius, Lithuania, aged 77.

[[Your Everything]]

CATEGORIES: 2000 songs, Country music

"Your Everything" is a song performed by country singer Keith Urban. It was released in May 2000. It reached number four on Billboard country charts the same year. 

[[Plains, Georgia]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Georgia (U.S. state)

Plains is a city in Sumner County, Georgia. It is the birthplace of the 39th President of the United States Jimmy Carter. He was born here in 1924. It has the population of 776 residents.

[[Point Pleasant, Ohio]]

CATEGORIES: Unincorporated communities in Ohio

Point Pleasant is a small unincorporated community in Clermont County, Ohio. It is the birthplace of the 18th President of the United States Ulysses S. Grant.

Wilton is a town in Saratoga County, New York. It has the population of 16,173 residents.

[[Baytown, Texas]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Texas

Baytown is a city in the U.S. state of Texas. As of 2016, it has about 76,000 residents.

It lies in the east of Texas, near the Gulf Coast.

[[Algarve]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Europe, Geography of Portugal

The Algarve (from الغرب al-Gharb "the West") is the southernmost region of continental Portugal. The  capital of the Algarve is the city of Faro. There is an international airport and a public university (University of Algarve).

The present region of Algarve coincides with the old province of the same name and with the Faro district. The main economic activity in the region is tourism because its beaches and its historical buildings.

[[One Hundred Years of Solitude]]

CATEGORIES: 1967 books, Books by Gabriel García Márquez, Spanish-language literature

One Hundred Years of Solitude is a book written by Nobel Prize-winning author Gabriel García Márquez. It was published in 1967 and translated to English in 1970. This book is thought to be Marquez's most famous book and one of the best books ever written in the Spanish language.

[[The Autumn of the Patriarch]]

CATEGORIES: 1975 books, Books by Gabriel García Márquez

The Autumn of the Patriarch is a book written by Nobel Prize-winning author Gabriel García Márquez. It was published in 1975. The books is inspired by the dictatorships of Gustavo Rojas Pinilla, Juan Vicente Gómez, and Francisco Franco.

[[Love in the Time of Cholera]]

Love in the Time of Cholera is a book written by Nobel Prize-winning author Gabriel García Márquez. It was published in 1988 and was translated in English in 2007.Gabriel García Márquez

[[Memories of My Melancholy Whores]]

CATEGORIES: 2004 books, Books by Gabriel García Márquez

Memories of My Melancholy Whores (Spanish: Memoria de mis putas tristes) is the last novel written by Nobel Prize-winning author Gabriel García Márquez. It was published in 2004. It was translated in English in 2005.

"The Solitude of Latin America" was a speech given by Gabriel García Márquez. Márquez gave the speech when he was accepting the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1982.

[[Rodrigo García]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 births, Living people, Colombian people, Movie directors, Television directors, Screenwriters, Gabriel García Márquez, People from Bogotá

Rodrigo García (born 24 August 1959) is a Colombian-born television and movie director and screenwriter. He is the son of Nobel Prize-winning author Gabriel García Márquez. 

He directed movies and television series such as Nine Lives and Albert Nobbs, and  episodes of several HBO series, Six Feet Under, Carnivàle, and Big Love.

Barcha was born in Bogotá, Colombia.

In Evil Hour is a novel written by Colombian Nobel Prize-winning author Gabriel García Márquez. It was published in 1972. It was published in English in 1979. Márquez lived in Paris at the time and was about to title this book This Town of Shit or This Shitty Town.

[[Andy Whitfield]]

CATEGORIES: 1971 births, 2011 deaths, Actors from Sydney, Australian movie actors, Australian television actors, Cancer deaths in New South Wales, Deaths from non-Hodgkin lymphoma, Welsh movie actors, Welsh television actors

Andy Whitfield (17 October 1971 – 11 September 2011) was a Welsh-Australian actor. He was best known for his leading role of Spartacus in the Starz television series Spartacus: Blood and Sand. He was born in Amlwch, Anglesey.

Whitfield died from non-Hodgkin lymphoma on 11 September 2011 in Sydney, New South Wales. He was 39. He was outlived by his wife and their two children.

The Story of a Shipwrecked Sailor (Spanish: Relato de un náufrago) is a non-fiction novel written by Nobel Prize-winning author Gabriel García Márquez. It was published as a series in 1955, but the whole book was published in 1970.

[[Clandestine in Chile]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 books, Books by Gabriel García Márquez, Non-fiction literature

Clandestine in Chile is a novel written by Nobel Prize-winning author Gabriel García Márquez. It was published in 1986. The story was based on the dictatorship of Augusto Pinochet and when movie director Miguel Littín was in exile.

Living to Tell the Tale (original Spanish-language title: Vivir para contarla) is the first volume of the autobiography of Gabriel García Márquez. It was published in 2002. The English translation was published in 2003.

[[University of Cartagena]]

CATEGORIES: Colleges and universities in South America, Colombia, 1827 establishments, 1820s establishments in South America, 19th-century establishments in Colombia

University of Cartagena is a university in Cartagena, Bolívar, Colombia. It was established in 1827. It is a public, departmental, coeducational, research university. Its motto is Siempre a la altura de los tiempos. Nobel Prize-winning author Gabriel García Márquez attended the university.

[[Francesco Rosi]]

CATEGORIES: 1922 births, 2015 deaths, Italian movie directors, Italian movie producers, Italian screenwriters, People from Naples

Francesco Rosi (15 November 1922 – 10 January 2015) was an Italian movie director, producer and screenwriter. 

He is the father of actress Carolina Rosi. He is known for his 1979 movie Christ Stopped at Eboli. He won the Golden Prize at the 11th Moscow International Film Festival.

Rosi was born in Naples and died in Rome.

[[Love in the Time of Cholera (movie)]]

[[Ground beetle]]

CATEGORIES: Adephaga

Ground beetles are the Carabidae, a large, cosmopolitan family of beetles. There are more than 40,000 species worldwide, about 2,000 of which are found in North America and 2,700 in Europe. There are a large number of subfamilies.

[[Igor Radulov]]

CATEGORIES: 1982 births, American Hockey League players, Chicago Blackhawks players, Living people, Russian ice hockey players, Ontario Hockey League players

Igor Valerievich Radulov (born August 23, 1982) is a Russian ice hockey left winger. He currently plays for HC Atlant Moscow Oblast of the Kontinental Hockey League (KHL). He has also played for the Chicago Blackhawks of the National Hockey League (NHL).

[[Parkersburg, West Virginia]]

[[Houma, Louisiana]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Louisiana, Parish seats in Louisiana

Houma is the parish seat and the only municipality of Terrebonne Parish, Louisiana, United States. As of 2010, 33,727 people live in Houma.

[[John Christopher]]

CATEGORIES: 1922 births, 2012 deaths, British children's writers, British science fiction writers, Cancer deaths in England, Deaths from bladder cancer, People from Bath, Somerset, Writers from Lancashire, Writers from Somerset

Christopher Samuel "Sam" Youd (16 April 1922 – 3 February 2012), better known by his pen name John Christopher, was a British science fiction writer. He was best known for his novel The Death of Grass and the young adult novel series The Tripods. He won the Guardian Prize in 1971 and the Deutscher Jugendliteraturpreis in 1976.

Christopher was born in Huyton, Lancashire. He was married to Joyce Fairbairn from 1946 until they divorced in 1978. They had five children: Nick, Rose, Liz, Sheila and Margret. He later was married to Jessica Ball until her death in 2001.

Christopher died from bladder cancer on 3 February 2012 in Bath, Somerset. He was 89.

[[Sewol]]

CATEGORIES: 2014 disasters, 2014 in Asia, 2010s disasters in Asia, 2010s in South Korea, April events, Maritime disasters, Transport in South Korea

The ferry MS Sewol, travelling from Incheon towards Jeju Island off the south coast of South Korea, sank on April 16, 2014 near Jindo Island off the southwest coast, resulting in the death of 304 people.

[[Leinier Domínguez]]

CATEGORIES: 1983 births, Living people, Chess grandmasters, Cuban sportspeople, People from Havana

Leinier Domínguez Pérez (born September 23, 1983 in Havana, Cuba) is a Cuban chess Grandmaster.

He won the Cuban Chess Championship in 2002, 2003, 2006, and 2012.

During the 2004 FIDE World Chess Championship he reached the quarter finals, losing to Teimour Radjabov in the tie-break.

His best tournament result was Barcelona 2006, where he scored 8/9 and finished first, ahead of Vassily Ivanchuk, with a performance rating of 2932.

In 2008, he won the CPA chess tournament and the 43rd Capablanca in Memoriam tournament. In the same year he tied for first with Evgeny Alekseev (but lost to him in tie-break) at Biel (6.5/10), ahead of Magnus Carlsen.

On November 8, 2008 he won the World Blitz Championship 2008, held at Almaty in Kazakhstan, with 11.5 points out of 15, ahead of Vassily Ivanchuk, Peter Svidler, Alexander Grischuk and many other top grandmasters.

In June 2013 he won the FIDE Grand Prix in Thessaloniki as a clear first in a field of twelve elite players, among them Fabiano Caruana, Veselin Topalov and Alexander Grischuk.

[[Igor Korolev]]

CATEGORIES: 1970 births, 2011 deaths, American Hockey League players, Aviation deaths, Chicago Blackhawks players, Phoenix Coyotes players, Russian ice hockey players, St. Louis Blues players, Toronto Maple Leafs players, Winnipeg Jets (1979–96) players, International Hockey League (1945–2001) players, Ice hockey centres

Igor Borisovich Korolev (September 6, 1970 – September 7, 2011) was a Russian ice hockey centre. He played 700 games in the National Hockey League (NHL), He played for the St. Louis Blues, Winnipeg Jets, Phoenix Coyotes, Toronto Maple Leafs, and Chicago Blackhawks. He also played 329 games in the Russian Superleague (RSL) with HC Dynamo Moscow, Lokomotiv Yaroslavl, and Metallurg Magnitogorsk, as well as 104 games in the Kontinental Hockey League (KHL) with Metallurg Magnitogorsk and Lokomotiv Yaroslavl.

In 2000, Korolev became a naturalized Canadian citizen. On September 7, 2011, 4:05 P.M. Moscow Time, Korolev was killed in the 2011 Lokomotiv Yaroslavl air disaster. The plane that was carrying the entire roster of Lokomotiv Yaroslavl ran off the runway before it took off, hit a tower mast, caught fire and crashed, killing 43 of 45 passengers on board. He was buried at Mount Pleasant Cemetery in Toronto after a funeral on September 18, 2011.

[[Anish Giri]]

CATEGORIES: 1994 births, Living people, Chess grandmasters, Dutch sportspeople, Naturalised citizens of the Netherlands, People from Saint Petersburg

Anish Giri (born June 28, 1994) is a Dutch chess prodigy. He got the grandmaster title at the age of 14 years, 7 months and 2 days at the 2009 Corus Chess Tournament in Wijk aan Zee in the Netherlands.

Giri is the son of a Nepali-Indian father (Sanjay Giri), and a Russian mother (Olga Giri). Giri was born in St. Petersburg, Russia on 28 June 1994. In 2002, he moved to Japan with his parents. When he lived in Japan, he visited St. Petersburg regularly. Since February 2008, Giri and his family have been living in the Netherlands, in the Dutch city of Rijswijk where his father is working in a research and consulting foundation.

[[Wesley So]]

CATEGORIES: 1993 births, Living people, Chess grandmasters, Filipino people

Wesley So (born 9 October 1993) is a Filipino chess grandmaster. So got the GM title at the age of 14 years, 1 month and 28 days, making him the 8th youngest chess grandmaster.

So's transfer to the United States Chess Federation was confirmed in the November 2014 rating list. Soon after, he left Webster University to focus full-time on chess.

[[Adam Air Flight 574]]

CATEGORIES: 2007 aviation disasters, 2007 in Asia, 2000s disasters in Asia, 2000s in Indonesia, History of Sulawesi, January events

Adam Air Flight 574 was a scheduled domestic passenger flight operated by Adam Air between the Indonesian cities of Surabaya (SUB) and Manado (MDC) that crashed into the Makassar Strait near Polewali in Sulawesi on 1 January 2007. All 102 people on board were killed, the highest death toll of any aviation accident involving a Boeing 737-400.

[[Rod Roddy]]

Robert Ray "Rod" Roddy (September 28, 1937 – October 27, 2003) was an American television and radio announcer.

[[List of British dukedoms]]

CATEGORIES: United Kingdom Dukes, Royalty and nobility, Lists of people

There are over 20 British titles that are dukedoms. Each of which are related to a certain family who have their own residence. Most of them also had large townhouses in London. The British Royal Family also reserve several for their own personal use such as the Duke of Cambridge.

[[Liberty Island]]

CATEGORIES: Islands of New York, Geography of New Jersey, Uninhabited islands

Liberty Island is a small uninhabited island in the New York Harbor in the United States. It is best known as the location of the Statue of Liberty. In 1937, by proclamation 2250, President Franklin D. Roosevelt expanded the Statue of Liberty National Monument to include all of Bedloe's Island. In 1956, an act of Congress officially renamed Bedloe's Island, 'Liberty Island'.

[[Punch-Out!! (Wii)]]

CATEGORIES: 2009 video games, Wii-only games, Wii games

Punch-Out!! is a boxing video game written by Next Level Games for the Nintendo Wii. It is the fifth game in the Punch-Out!! series.

It was first sold at the Nintendo World Store in New York City on May 16, 2009. It was then in other shops from May 18, 2009 in North America, and from May 22, 2009 in Europe.

In January 2015 Nintendo Direct, said that Punch-Out!! and other Wii games would be released for download through the Wii U's Nintendo eShop.

[[Ched Evans]]

CATEGORIES: 1988 births, Living people, Manchester City F.C. players, People acquitted of rape, Welsh footballers

Chedwyn Michael "Ched" Evans (born 28 December 1988) is a Welsh footballer. He was born in St Asaph, Denbighshire. Evans was signed by Manchester City from Chester City's youth set up in 2002. In 2009 he was sold to Sheffield United for £3,000,000. Evans was sent to HM Prison Wymott from 2012 to 2014 for raping a woman. Evans has not played professional football since he was released.

[[Patty Schemel]]

CATEGORIES: 1967 births, American drummers, Entertainers from Washington, Lesbians, LGBT musicians, Living people

Patricia Theresa Schemel (born April 24, 1967) is an American drummer. She was the drummer of Hole from 1992 until 1998. In 2013 she joined the indie rock band Upset.

[[Division of Forrest]]

CATEGORIES: Electoral divisions of Australia, Western Australia, 1922 establishments in Australia

The Division of Forrest is an Australian Electoral Division in Western Australia. It was set up in 1922 and is named for Sir John Forrest, the first Premier of Western Australia and a federal Cabinet minister. It is in the south-western corner of the state, and includes the towns of Augusta, Australind,  Bunbury, Busselton, Capel, Collie,  Donnybrook, Dunsborough, Eaton, Harvey, Margaret River, Nannup and Yallingup.

[[Division of Hasluck]]

CATEGORIES: Electoral divisions of Australia, Western Australia, 2001 establishments in Australia

The Division of Hasluck is an electoral division of the Australian House of Representatives, in Western Australia.

It was set up in 2000, for the 2001 federal election. It is named after Sir Paul Hasluck, the Governor-General of Australia from 1969 to 1974, and his wife, Alexandra Hasluck, an author.

[[Magic in the Moonlight]]

CATEGORIES: 2014 comedy-drama movies, American comedy-drama movies, Movies directed by Woody Allen, Movies set in France, Movies set in the 1920s

Magic in the Moonlight is a 2014 American comedy-drama movie. This is set on the French Riviera in the 1920s. Marcia Gay Harden, Colin Firth and Emma Stone star in the movie. Woody Allen directed the movie.

This movie was released on July 25, 2014.

[[Parkland (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2013 drama movies, American drama movies, Dallas, Texas, Movies based on real life events, Movies set in Texas, Movies set in the 1960s, Movies set in Washington, D.C., English-language movies, Movies based on books, Movies composed by James Newton Howard, American independent movies

Parkland is a 2013 American historical drama movie. It is about chaotic events following the assassination of John F. Kennedy. Marcia Gay Harden plays Head Nurse Doris Nelson. Billy Bob Thornton plays Agent Forrest Sorrels.

The movie was released in autumn 2013.

[[Dylan Tombides]]

CATEGORIES: 1994 births, 2014 deaths, Australian footballers, Cancer deaths in London, Deaths from testicular cancer, People from Perth, Western Australia, Sportspeople from Western Australia

Dylan James Tombides (8 March 1994 – 18 April 2014) was an Australian association footballer. He played as a striker for West Ham United and the Australia U17 and Australia U23 teams. He was born in Perth, Western Australia.

Tombides made his professional debut for West Ham on 25 September 2012 in a 4–1 home defeat to Wigan Athletic in the League Cup. He came on as an 84th-minute substitute for Gary O'Neil.

Tombides died from testicular cancer on 18 April 2014 in London, England. He was 20.

[[Brian Priestman]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2014 deaths, British conductors, British educators, Disease-related deaths in France, Musicians from Birmingham

Brian Priestman (10 February 1927 – 18 April 2014) was a British conductor, maestro and music educator. He was the Music Director of the Denver Symphony Orchestra from 1970 until 1978. He was born in Birmingham, England.

Priestman died on 18 April 2014 at his home in Broze, France, aged 87.

[[Gyula Gömbös]]

CATEGORIES: 1886 births, 1936 deaths, Cancer deaths in Germany, Deaths from testicular cancer, European military people, Prime Ministers of Hungary

Gyula Gömbös de Jákfa (26 December 1886 – 6 October 1936) was a Hungarian military officer and politician. He served as Prime Minister of Hungary from 1 October 1932 until his death on 6 October 1936. He was born in Murga, Austria-Hungary.

Gömbös died in Munich, Germany from testicular cancer, aged 49.

[[Péter Boross]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, Living people, Conservatives, Prime Ministers of Hungary

Péter Boross (born 27 August 1928) is a Hungarian retired politician. He was the second Prime Minister of Hungary. He served as Prime Minister from December 1993 to July 1994.

Boross was born in Nagybajom, Hungary.

[[Péter Medgyessy]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, Living people, Politicians from Budapest, Prime Ministers of Hungary

Péter Medgyessy (born 19 October 1942) is a Hungarian politician. He was the fifth Prime Minister of Hungary. He served as Prime Minister from May 2002 to September 2004.

Medgyessy was born in Budapest, Hungary. 

[[Arseniy Yatsenyuk]]

CATEGORIES: 1974 births, Living people, Civil servants, Economists, Ukrainian lawyers, Prime Ministers of Ukraine, Ukrainian scientists

Arseniy Petrovych Yatsenyuk (Арсеній Петрович Яценюк, Arseniy Petrovych Yatseniuk; born May 22, 1974) is a Ukrainian politician, economist and lawyer. He was the Prime Minister of Ukraine. He became Prime Minister in February 2014. He resigned on 14 April 2016.

[[Ibn Taymiyyah]]

CATEGORIES: Muslims, Philosophers

Ibn Taymiyyah (661-728 AH/ 1263-1328 CE)  is regarded as one of the prominent Sunni Islamic scholars and mujaddids (renewers or revivers) of Islam. His full name is Ahmad ibn Abdul Haleem ibn Abdus Salam ibn Taymiyyah. His titles are Sheikh al-Islam, the Imām, the Scholar, the Mufassir (Exegete), the Faqīh (Jurist), the Mujtahid, the Hāfidh, the Muḥaddith (master of hadith). He was a member of the islamic jurisprudence school founded by Ahmad ibn Hanbal. He was notable for wanting to return Islam to what he viewed as earlier interpretations of the Qur'an and the Sunnah. He lived during the troubled times of the Mongol invasions in Syam. He is the most influential teacher of Ibnul Qayyim.

[[Reagan Era]]

CATEGORIES: 1980s in the United States, Presidency of Ronald Reagan

The Reagan Era or Age of Reagan is an era in American history that lasted from 1981 to 1989. It is used by historians and political theorists to show that the conservative "Reagan Revolution" led by President Ronald Reagan in domestic and foreign policy had a long and lasting impact. 

[[Reagan County, Texas]]

CATEGORIES: Texas counties

Reagan County is a county in Texas. It has 3,367 residents. It has four communities; Big Lake, Best, Stiles, and Texon.

[[Ronald Reagan Ballistic Missile Defense Test Site]]

CATEGORIES: Buildings and structures named after Ronald Reagan, Spaceflight

The Ronald Reagan Ballistic Missile Defense Test Site, commonly referred to as the Reagan Test Site (formerly Kwajalein Missile Range), is a missile test range in the Pacific Ocean. Missiles have been tested there since 1959.

It covers about 750000 and includes rocket launch sites at the Kwajalein Atoll (on multiple islands), Wake Island, and Aur Atoll. It is named after 40th President of the United States Ronald Reagan.

[[Buitreraptor]]

CATEGORIES: Dromaeosauridae, Dinosaurs of South America, Cretaceous dinosaurs

Buitreraptor is a small dromaeosaur from the Cretaceous of Argentina. It was about four to five feet long (1.5 metres).

Buitreraptor has a slender, flat, extremely elongated snout. Its jaws have many small teeth which lack meat-tearing serrations or cutting edges. They are grooved, strongly recurved and flattened. This probably meant it ate quite small animals, like lizards and mammals. 

Since its close relatives had feathers, it is likely that Buitreraptor also was feathered. 

[[Pooja Sharma]]

CATEGORIES: Actors, Year of birth missing (living people), Living people

Pooja Sharma is an Indian model and actress. She appeared in serial Mahabharat on Star Plus.

[[Henri Jules, Prince of Condé]]

CATEGORIES: 1643 births, 1709 deaths, House of Bourbon, Princes and princesses, Dukes and Duchesses of Bourbon

Henri Jules de Bourbon, Prince of Condé  (Paris, 29 July 1643 – Paris, 1 April 1709) was a member of the House of Bourbon and was the Prince of Condé till his death. He was also the only surviving son of the famous Grand Condé. He was known for his bizarre bouts of madness. He was also ranked as a Prince of the blood st the Royal court of Versailles.  At the end of his life he suffered from clinical lycanthropy and was considered insane.

==Marriage and children== 

He was married to Princess Anne Henriette of Bavaria at the Louvre in December 1663. She was a cousin of Elisabeth Charlotte of the Palatinate. The couple had ten children including the next Prince of Condé. He also had an illegitimate daughter with a mistress. He was well educated but had a malicious character.

[[Ernst Florian Winter]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2014 deaths, American historians, Austrian historians, American political scientists, Military personnel of World War II, Naturalized citizens of the United States, Scientists from Vienna, Writers from Vienna

Ernst Florian Winter (16 December 1923 – 16 April 2014) was an Austrian-American historian and political scientist. He was the first director of the Diplomatic Academy of Vienna after World War II. He was also the chairman of the International Council of the Austrian Service Abroad. He was born in Vienna.

Winter died on 16 April 2014 at the age of 90.

[[Sonia Silvestre]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, 2014 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Deaths from stroke, Dominican Republic musicians, Singers

Sonia Margarita Silvestre Ortiz (16 August 1952 – 19 April 2014) was a Dominican singer and announcer. Her best known songs were "Esta Es Sonia Silvestre" (1974), "Yo Quiero Andar" (1990) and "Verde y Negro" (2007). She was born in San Pedro de Macorís, Dominican Republic.

Silvestre died from complications due to a stroke and two heart attacks on 19 April 2014 in Santo Domingo. She was 61.

[[Nenê]]

CATEGORIES: 1982 births, African-American basketball players, Brazilian sportspeople, Cancer survivors, Denver Nuggets players, Living people, Washington Wizards players

Nenê (born Maybyner Rodney Hilário; September 13, 1982) is a Brazilian basketball player. He is a forward-center for the Washington Wizards of the National Basketball Association (NBA). He has also played for the Denver Nuggets from 2002 until 2012. He legally had his named changed to Nenê in 2003.

He was drafted with the 7th overall pick by the New York Knicks in the 2002 NBA Draft. Right after he was draft, the Knicks traded Nenê along with Marcus Camby and Mark Jackson to the Denver Nuggets for Antonio McDyess and a 25th draft pick (Frank Williams). On January 14, 2008, Nenê had a testicular tumor removed at a Denver hospital.

On March 15, 2012, the Nuggets traded him to the Washington Wizards in a three-way trade that also involved the Los Angeles Clippers. JaVale McGee and Ronny Turiaf were sent to the Nuggets from the Wizards, Nick Young went to the Clippers from the Wizards and the Wizards also received Brian Cook from the Clippers.

Esther Ralston (September 17, 1902 – January 14, 1994) was an American actress. She starred in movies, including Tin Pan Alley and on television series, including Our Five Daughters.

Ralston was born in Bar Harbor, Maine. Ralston died of a heart attack at age ninety-one in Ventura, California.

[[Project Ara]]

CATEGORIES: Google

Project Ara is the codename for an initiative by Google. It aims to develop a free, open hardware platform for making modular smartphones. Google says the phone is designed to be used by "six billion people". It will come in three sizes. The project was announced by Google in October 2013. It is led by Paul Eremenko.

David Bateson (born 9 February 1960) is a South African-British actor. He was born in South Africa. He is known best for providing the voice and appearance of Agent 47, the main character of IO Interactive's computer and video game series Hitman.

[[Adam Rose]]

Raymond Leppan (born 20 July 1979) is an South African professional wrestler. He currently works for the WWE where he competes in their developmental territory NXT Wrestling. He competes under the ring name Adam Rose and is also known by his former ring name Leo Kruger.

On the January 30 tapings of NXT, Leppan debuted under the Adam Rose name and had the gimmick of an eccentric rock star.

[[Sri Lankan elephant]]

CATEGORIES: Elephants, Mammals of Asia, National symbols of Sri Lanka

The Sri Lankan elephant (Elephas maximus maximus) is one of the three subspecies of the Asian elephant (Elephas maximus). 

The other two subspecies are the Indian elephant (Elephas maximus indicus) and the Sumatran elephant (Elephas maximus sumatranus). 

The Sri Lankan elephant is the largest of the three subspecies. They are about 11 tall, and can weigh up to 12000. They eat leaves, shrubs, grasses, and other plants. 

This subspecies is the National animal of Sri Lanka and is native to the island country. It once lived over the entire island. They now live in the dry zones in the north, east, and southeast. These zones are mainly dry deciduous woodland, scrubland, grassland, and marshes. There is a small group in the rainforest. 

Sri Lankan elephants are sometimes working animals. They carry timber, transport passengers, and participate in public events like the Procession of Buddha's Tooth. There were many of them in the past. They were aggressively hunted. 

In modern times, these elephants can be seen in Sri Lanka's national parks and elephant orphanages. They have been declared an endangered species, and are protected by law. Killing one carries the death penalty.

[[Blanche Barton]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 births, Living people, American esotericists, Writers from San Diego, California, Religious leaders, Satanists

Blanche Barton (born Sharon Densley; October 1, 1961 in San Diego, California) is an American religious leader. She is the Magistra Templi Rex of the Church of Satan. Satanists address her as Magistra Barton. 

Barton became the High Priestess after Anton LaVey died on October 29, 1997. She held the position of High Priestess until April 30, 2002. Barton has written two books: The Church of Satan: A History of the World's Most Notorious Religion and The Secret Life of a Satanist: The Authorized Biography of Anton LaVey.

[[Tamari]]

CATEGORIES: Condiments, Sauces

Tamari is a Japanese soy sauce. It is milder and less salty than regular soy sauce. It has more fermented soy sauce.

[[Ma Baker]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 songs, Pop songs

"Ma Baker" is a popular song performed by Boney M. The song came off their album Love for Sale. It hit #2 in Britain. The song was remixed and sampled for several other songs. It was only minor in the United States.

The song was released May 2, 1977.

[[Nathan Dempsey]]

CATEGORIES: 1974 births, Boston Bruins players, Canadian ice hockey defencemen, Chicago Blackhawks players, Ice hockey people from Alberta, Living people, Los Angeles Kings players, Toronto Maple Leafs players, American Hockey League players

Nathan Dempsey (born July 14, 1974) is a Canadian retired professional ice hockey defenceman. Dempsey played a total of 260 games in the National Hockey League (NHL). He played with the Toronto Maple Leafs, Chicago Blackhawks, Los Angeles Kings and Boston Bruins.

[[Live Through This]]

CATEGORIES: 1994 albums, Hole (band) albums, Punk albums

Live Through This is the second studio album by Hole. It was released by Geffen Records on April 12, 1994. It got very good reviews. Most of the album was written by Courtney Love and guitarist Eric Erlandson. It was the only Hole album with bassist Kristen Pfaff. Love's husband Kurt Cobain did backing vocals on two songs. Four singles were released from the album, including "Doll Parts". The album was dedicated to Joe Cole, a roadie for Black Flag, who was shot to death during a robbery in December 1991 after attending a Hole show in West Hollywood, California.

[[Pretty on the Inside]]

CATEGORIES: 1991 albums, Hole (band) albums, Debut albums, Punk albums

Pretty on the Inside is the first studio album by Hole. It was released on September 17, 1991 in the United States on Caroline Records. In Europe it was released on City Slang. One single, "Teenage Whore", was released from the album. The album was produced by Kim Gordon and Don Fleming. It has sold over 200,000 copies in the US. All of the songs on the album were written by Courtney Love and Eric Erlandson apart from the last song "Clouds".

[[Del Shannon]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 1990 deaths, American rock musicians, Deaths by firearm in California, Musicians from Michigan, Musicians who committed suicide, Singers from Michigan, Suicides by firearm in the United States

Charles Weedon Westover (or Del Shannon; December 30, 1934 – February 8, 1990) was an American rock and roll singer and musician. He had several popular songs, including "Runaway" in 1961.

Del Shannon was born in Grand Rapids, Michigan. He shot himself dead with his rifle at age fifty-five in Santa Clarita, California. He was cremated.

[[Holiday in Cambodia]]

CATEGORIES: 1980 songs

"Holiday in Cambodia" is the second single off American hardcore punk band Dead Kennedys' debut studio album Fresh Fruit for Rotting Vegetables. The song was released in May 1980. 

The cover art for the song was taken during the Thammasat University massacre on 6 October 1976 in Thailand. It shows a member of a right-wing crowd beating the corpse of a student protester with a chair. The song is against both Eastern totalitarianism and Western complacency. The original version of the song features the satirically quoted word "niggers", later performances of the song by the Dead Kennedys, as well as other artists have replaced the word with "brothers". Biafra, however, has often replaced the word with "blacks".

Lead singer Jello Biafra was sued by the other members of Dead Kennedy because he would not allow the song to be used in a Levi's Dockers commercial. Biafra opposed Levi's because he believes they use unfair business practices and sweatshop labor. The other members of the band said that they had had their royalties defrauded. "The record industry has been skimming royalties owed artists since the beginning," according to Dead Kennedys guitarist East Bay Ray. "This case is no different from blues musicians being taken advantage of in the twenties and thirties. Many people doubted the claims we made against our former record label back in 1998 but with this announcement there is no denying we were the victims here."

[[Julie Bindel]]

CATEGORIES: 1962 births, Living people, British feminists, English LGBT people, English journalists, Feminist writers, Lesbian feminists, LGBT journalists, Radical feminists, Writers from Leeds

Julie Bindel (born 20 July 1962) is an English writer. She is a lesbian and radical feminist. She lives in Crouch End, London. She is a freelance journalist. Her work is often published by The Guardian. Bindel edits Gaze: A Modern Review.

[[George Deukmejian]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2018 deaths, Governors of California, Politicians from New York, US Republican Party politicians, State legislators of the United States, 20th-century American politicians

Courken George "Duke" Deukmejian, Jr. (dj; June 6, 1928 – May 8, 2018) was an American politician. He was a member of the Republican Party.

He was the 35th Governor of California from 1983 to 1991. He was also California Attorney General from 1979 to 1983.

Deukmejian died at his home in Long Beach, California on May 8, 2018 at the age of 89.

[[Veruca Salt]]

Veruca Salt is an American alternative rock band. Louise Post and Nina Gordon started the band with drummer Jim Shapiro and bassist Steve Lack in 1993. In 1994 their first album American Thighs was released. Gordon left the band in 1998. In 2013 she joined the band again. On June 22 2014 the band's original members will perform together for the first time in 19 years.

[[Moscow State University of Geodesy and Cartography]]

CATEGORIES: Colleges and universities in Russia, 1779 establishments, 18th century establishments in Russia, 1770s establishments in Europe, 1770s establishments in Asia

Moscow State University of Geodesy and Cartography (Моско́вский госуда́рственный университе́т геоде́зии и картогра́фии) is a university in Russia. It is one of the first universities in the world dedicated to geodesy and cartography. It was established in 1779 and has six faculties.

[[Moscow State University of Land Management]]

CATEGORIES: Colleges and universities in Russia, 1779 establishments, Buildings and structures in Moscow, 18th century establishments in Russia, 1770s establishments in Asia, 1770s establishments in Europe

State University Of Land Use Planning (Государственный университет по землеустройству) is a university in Moscow. It is dedicated to study of land management. The university was established in 1779. It has 7 faculties.

[[Antimatter fuel]]

CATEGORIES: Antimatter

Antimatter, when it comes into contact with regular matter, releases a huge amount of energy. This energy is in the form of an explosion. This explosion can be harnessed for electrical means (Creating electricity) or as a thrust (Because antimatter has to be created, it would be extremely inefficient to use for electricity.) Since newtons laws state that if you push something, you get pushed. That is how rockets work. The antimatter can be exploded and forced behind the rocket, pushing the rocket forward. But antimatter reactions can produce harmful discharges of high energy gamma rays. High energy gamma rays break down molecules in cells and can also make the rocket engines radioactive. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) is currently doing research to reduce this harmful side effect.

[[Lou Brissie]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2014 deaths, American baseball players, American military people, Cleveland Indians players, Deaths from heart failure, Disease-related deaths in the United States, Oakland Athletics players, Sportspeople from Georgia (U.S. state)

Leland Victor "Lou" Brissie (June 5, 1924 – November 25, 2013) was an American baseball starting pitcher. He played for two Major League Baseball teams—the Philadelphia Athletics from 1947 to 1951 and the Cleveland Indians from 1951 to 1953. He was a symbol for the disabled and veterans after getting leg injuries in World War II. He was born in Ware Shoals, South Carolina.

Brissie died from heart and lung failure on November 25, 2013 in Augusta, Georgia. He was 89.

[[Walter Frosch]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, 2013 deaths, Cardiovascular disease deaths in Germany, Deaths from cardiac arrest, German footballers, People from Ludwigshafen, Sportspeople from Rhineland-Palatinate

Walter Frosch (19 December 1950 – 23 November 2013) was a German professional association footballer. He played as a defender. He was a player for SV Alsenborn, 1. FC Kaiserslautern and FC St. Pauli between 1970 and 1979. He was born in Ludwigshafen, Rhineland-Palatinate (then part of West Germany).

Frosch died from a cardiac arrest on 23 November 2013 in Hamburg, aged 62.

[[Presidential portrait (United States)]]

CATEGORIES: Art

An Official Presidential Portrait is an oil portrait painted of a President of the United States of America. In recent years, the official portrait of the President is a photograph until after they leave office.

The tradition started with Gilbert Stuart's portrait of George Washington. Presidents often display the official portraits of Presidents they admire (on loan from the National Portrait Gallery) in the Oval Office, or around the White House.

[[Everett Kinstler]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2019 deaths, American painters, American comics artists, American educators, People from New York

Everett Raymond Kinstler (August 5, 1926 – May 26, 2019) was an American portrait artist. He painted official portraits of businesspeople and also Presidents of the United States. He painted portraits for Gerald Ford and Ronald Reagan.

[[List of mammals of Great Britain]]

CATEGORIES: Mammals of Europe, Great Britain, Lists of animals

This is a list of mammals of Great Britain. 

The Great Britain mammal fauna is impoverished compared with that of continental Europe. This is because there was only a short time between the last ice age and the flooding of the land bridge between Britain and the rest of Europe. The list only has land species which crossed before the creation of the English Channel, and those later brought in by humans.

Native (indigenous) species have three possible definitions:

This list includes mammals from the small islands around Great Britain and the Channel Islands. There are no endemic mammal species in Great Britain, although four distinct subspecies of rodents have arisen on small islands.

[[Derek Cooper]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, 2014 deaths, Deaths from Parkinson's disease, Disease-related deaths in England, English journalists, Writers from London

Derek MacDonald Cooper (25 May 1925 – 18 April 2014) was a British journalist. He wrote about food, wine and whisky. He worked with The Listener, The Observer, Home & Garden and Saga Magazine.

He created the idea of BBC Radio 4’s weekly program The Food Programme. He was born in London, England.

Cooper died from Parkinson's disease in London, aged 88.
